PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform senators that in recent times I have received a steady and increasing stream of letters from citizens very concerned by the behaviour of senators at question time. To the listener on the radio or the viewer of television, interjections which we in the chamber may understand often appear to be merely a barrage of noise.

INTERJECT.PARA: I am concerned that continuation of this behaviour will cause damage to the standing of the Senate and to public confidence in the political system. I believe it is the responsibility of us all to raise the standard of demeanour in the chamber, and accordingly I have written to the Leader of the Government and the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate concerning the need to improve the standard of behaviour at question time, and I ask that all senators assist the leaders and me to bring about that improvement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, my question is addressed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer, and it is in reference to the so‐called superannuation surcharge. Is it not true that on the PM program last Wednesday night you referred to this measure as a tax? Isn't it a fact that in the course of the Prime Minister's abuse of the superannuation industry last week he said, `Let's call a spade a spade'? Why, on other occasions since then, are you continuing to defy the Prime Minister's advice to call a spade a spade? Why won't you obey the Prime Minister's directive and admit a tax is a tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam President. Senator Sherry, a tax is a tax; a surcharge is a surcharge. And I have to tell you, Senator Sherry, that you have got up time and time again and referred to it as a surcharge.
—And a tax!

—No, as a surcharge. In fact, even in your question you referred to it as a surcharge. Senator Sherry, I would have thought you could have done better than that. I really thought today was a good chance for you, in young talent time over there, to have done better.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator, I do not know if you have your pencil out this time, but could you get it out so we can resolve this issue? A tax is defined as a compulsory unrequited payment demanded by government for its support. A surcharge can be defined as an additional charge. It can be a charge on an existing tax which is applied in a particular circumstance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you tell them before the election to read the fine print?
—Senator, you have asked this question so many times! I have given you the answer, exactly the same answer, so many times that I am amazed that you continue to persist.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am pleased to see you admit that it is an additional tax. Why did the Treasurer, Mr Costello, say on the John Laws program, `Well, what it says is that for anyone whose taxable income is over $85,000'—and that was inaccurate, by the way—`the tax'—and these are the words of the Treasurer, Mr Costello—`that is collected on employer contributions will be 30 per cent rather than 15 per cent.' Small business, big business, accountants, lawyers, your own budget papers, everyone in here knows it is a tax. Will you now be honest with the Australian people and with this Senate and refer to it as a tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry, I think that was almost word for word a question that you asked me about three or four weeks ago.
—You didn't answer it then.

—I thought I gave an excellent answer then. In fact, I got a number of phone calls from constituents who said, `Surely Senator Sherry understands this now', and I said, `Don't be so hopeful. It is like a broken record; it clicks in every two weeks.'

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Sherry, the question has been responded to on many occasions. It is a surcharge. We have described it as a surcharge; it remains a surcharge, Senator Sherry, and there is nothing else I can add to it, I am afraid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, my question is also directed to the Assistant Treasurer. I refer to recent business surveys which show increased confidence and an improved economic outlook for Australia in 1997. Will the minister outline the basis for this improvement in business confidence? Do Australians have good reason to expect that economic growth will strengthen during 1997?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam President, and thank you Senator Chapman, for this question which shows once again that the coalition government focuses on the main game. The Labor Party relentlessly gets diverted from issues, refuses to get into heavy policy issues—even Senator Sherry! So I welcome the question.

ANSWER.PARA: The reality is, Madam President, that the government is pleased that recent business surveys suggest renewed confidence about economic conditions. For example, the ACCI‐Westpac survey of industrial trends reported a surge in business confidence in the March quarter. The number of respondents expecting worse conditions halved to just nine per cent, with those expecting improvement rising from 30 to 35 per cent.

Madam President, the survey reported business confidence to be at its highest level since December 1994, which of course is just after Labor put up interest rates. Do you remember that? Interest rates went up three times in six months. That is what Labor did.

In addition, a major survey conducted by the Australian Institute of Company Directors and KPMG shows that 70 per cent of company directors think that growth will pick up over the next year, and 50 per cent of com panies with revenue above $1 billion anticipate sales above budget.

This comes on top of a rise in company profits before tax of 17 per cent in the December quarter. But the good news does not end there. The bulk of economic indicators released for this quarter suggest stronger growth over the rest of the year. For these reasons, both the government and private forecasters expect growth to strengthen over 1997.

The good news continues. ANZ job advertisements were up 1.8 per cent in February, the third increase in four months. Retail trade was up 2.7 per cent in January. Business investment rose 0.6 per cent in the December quarter to be 20 per cent higher than in December 1995. In housing, private approvals rose 7.6 per cent in January, adding to evidence that the housing sector is in recovery after the long slump under Labor. Motor vehicle registrations were up 2.9 per cent in January. On the interest rates front, variable home loan rates are at their lowest levels since the 1960s. There have been three cuts in official interest rates, and lower business rates including small business rates. These cuts will continue to flow through to stronger growth in the coming months. Inflation is at low levels with the CPI rising just two per cent in the December quarter and 1.5 per cent in the year to December.

In summary, we have good indicators for the March quarter, we have very low inflation, strengthening business confidence, some of the lowest interest rates in three decades and good prospects that the world economy will remain supportive of the Australian economy. All these factors give confidence that growth will pick up over the remainder of the year. That is good news for workers; bad news for the Labor Party; good news for small business and good news for families. We welcome the spate of indicators which are now coming in and which add to confidence in the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of a former colleague, former Senator John Stone. Welcome on your return to the Senate.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Can you say for how many people the superannuation funds currently have tax file numbers? How much has this figure improved over recent months and what target are you trying to achieve by the end of this financial year?

—In relation to tax file numbers, Senator Sherry will know that, from 16 February, superannuation funds have been seeking the use of tax file numbers from their members. That is in the order, Senator, of one month ago. We know that the superannuation funds are very keen to collect tax file numbers. Indeed, Senator Sherry, that was your policy, I remember.
—It wasn't a tax.

—Senator Sherry, it was your policy to bring in a bill to assist the superannuation funds to collect tax file numbers. You have been very supportive of that and, of course, a bill which allowed superannuation funds to collect tax file numbers has gone through this parliament, and since 16 February superannuation funds have been collecting them. That is roughly four weeks, and we know that the superannuation funds are keen to pursue this with great vigour. It is our hope that the vast proportion of Australians will respond to this request, not only, of course, for the reasons which you well know, but also because it will certainly help the administration of the superannuation industry. That is why you supported it and that is why we support it.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Kemp should know that our support of the use of tax file numbers is to allow members to consolidate their accounts, not to collect a new tax. I am surprised you do not know this information, Senator Kemp, given that there is going to be a need to collect seven to eight million tax file numbers from individual taxpayers. Why is the government imposing a penalty tax of 15 per cent on low and middle income earners who cannot provide their tax file numbers in the time required by the proposed legislation?
—This is the usual scare tactic that Labor uses to cover up their total lack of policy. You will be aware—
—You can allay the scare; you can rule it out.
—Listen to this. Get your pencil out again so we do not confuse you.
—Senator Kemp, address your remarks to the chair.

—Thank you, Madam President. I was being unduly provoked from across the chamber. Lower and middle income people will not be affected by the surcharge measure. as you know, Senator Sherry. All they have to do to avoid the surcharge is supply their tax file number.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I refer the minister to Labor's Hindmarsh Island Bridge fiasco and its subsequent embarrassing backflip. Is the minister aware of the following statement by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, when he said only last week:

QUESTION.PARA: You are allowed to learn in politics. The Hindmarsh Island Bridge issue was our problem. We were the inhibitors of the Hindmarsh Island Bridge going ahead and there is no question about that. I do not deny our responsibility.
In light of this capitulation by the opposition, will the minister be reintroducing the Hindmarsh Island Bridge Bill 1996 and, if so, when?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Knowles for the question. I am delighted that Labor has finally seen the light. It is a pity that it has taken so long and cost so much. I am thankful for Mr Beazley's statement because I intend to move a notice to restore the bill in the Senate this afternoon and recommit the bill later this week. The Hindmarsh Island Bridge saga highlights what a second‐rate government the Labor Party was and what a third‐rate opposition they now are. You will recall that taxpayers' money was wasted by Labor on this issue—and it could have paid for the construction of the bridge. It also happens to be ATSIC money that could have been spent on essentials like health, housing and infrastructure. The taxpayers will not forget it, nor will they forgive the Labor Party for its incompetent handling of this matter. They will not forget the four inquiries that have been held and the $4 million plus that has been wasted. They will not forget Labor's blind obstruction on this bill earlier this year.

ANSWER.PARA: What was also interesting was the timing of the announcement of Mr Beazley. It was significant that he let it slip out on a Friday night, on the eve of a major national sporting event—the Grand Prix, you will recall—when he hoped media and public attention would be diverted. He actually refused to go on television that night. He refused to go. It also happened to be six days before the application to the Federal Court seeking to force me to appoint another section 10 reporter. Mr Beazley could not afford that because he had already insisted, and was still insisting, that there was no need for another inquiry.

I can tell you that my legal advice was rock solid. The Commonwealth would almost certainly have lost the case and been forced to appoint another reporter. Labor knew that they had a choice: either do a backflip and support the legislation or wait for the Federal Court to find that they were completely wrong on the need for an inquiry and then support the legislation. Mr Beazley took the easiest option, but by doing so, of course, he left his shadow minister, Mr Melham, and Senator Bolkus over there and Senator Collins, out on a limb and then cut it off. He cut it off because they were the ones who were arguing in here for the necessity for us to go ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't won a court case yet.

—Senator Bolkus's legal advice was not worth the paper it was written on and he is still continuing this saga. They were the ones who strongly opposed this legislation, who put up nonsensical arguments and said that they would never support the legislation as proposed by the government. I cannot really blame Mr Beazley; after all they were the ones on that side who misled him on the issue. They sold him the dump by convincing him that there was no need for another reporter. Then, when the matter looked like going to court, they had to admit their deception. Mr Beazley has cut them adrift in a leaking boat. How Daryl Melham can continue as shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs is beyond me. His leader is no longer listening to him. He no longer trusts him and has cut him adrift, and Senator Bolkus and Senator Collins are adrift in the same boat.

ANSWER.PARA: What we have is a highly confused opposition. In government they opposed the Hindmarsh Island Bridge. Then, last year, they supported it, but would not support legislation to allow it to proceed. Now they say they will support the legislation. Actually, they do not what they are doing, and that is no surprise because who knows what the Labor Party stands for today? It typifies the Labor Party as a whole. What does it stand for, Madam President? We still do not know.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. A million lower and middle income earners—nurses, shop assistants, drivers and hotel employees, for example—will have to pay your new 15 per cent superannuation tax. Why have you broken your election promise not to increase existing taxes or introduce new taxes? Would you still regard this as a fair measure?

—Senator, I do not think you listened to my last answer. One of the problems in writing out questions before question time is that you do not actually take account of the answer that is given to you, so your assertion about a million people paying the surcharge is complete and utter nonsense. As I have explained to you, Senator Sherry, no lower or middle income people need pay the surcharge; all they have to do is supply their tax file number. So getting up and talking in the way you have, Senator Sherry, is just designed to scare people, and not to add to the sum of human knowledge.

BREAK.PARA: Is it a fair measure? Well, Senator, the Labor Party supports the 15 per cent. Have you forgotten your own policy or are we about to see the big double‐pike backflip? You support the 15 per cent and you get up—
Senator Sherry interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry, this is your question that the minister is answering and you will have an opportunity to ask a supplementary question at the end, if you wish.

—Senator, I would have thought that everyone accepted that the 15 per cent was fair, and that is the reason I thought, initially, that the Labor Party decided to support the 15 per cent, so I am amazed that you would stand up and ask that question.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Sherry, tax file numbers are going to be far easier to collect, let me tell you, than memberships for the Labor Party. You would have noted that in Victoria one‐third of the members of the Labor Party have their fees paid by somebody else. So, Senator Sherry, I know you might be worried about this sort of issue, but you should not project the problems the Labor Party may be having with its members onto the problem that superannuation funds may have with their members, because they will not have those problems. Our measure, to sum up—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a great admission—`they won't have those problems'.

—They will not. They will not because there is a great incentive for people to supply their tax file numbers. So, Senator Sherry, in your supplementary question, it would be very interesting for you to make it absolutely crystal clear that the Labor Party policy is still to support the 15 per cent surcharge.

—I have a supplementary question for Senator Kemp. He may be interested to know that the one million figure is not mine; it is a figure supplied by William Mercers, Coopers and Lybrand, AMP, ASPA, LISA and many other organisations that believe the one million figure is conservative. Why is it that the one million lower and middle income earners will pay, on top of the 15 per cent superannuation tax, an advance instalment tax of 7.5 per cent? That is a total new tax of 22.5 per cent. Is that not an unfair measure?
—The measure, Senator, is the 15 per cent, which I am not sure whether you support or not from the way you are going over this. What a surprise, Senator Sherry—
—Senator Kemp, direct your remarks to the chair.

—Thank you Madam President. What a surprise that the superannuation funds, and the few other names that you mentioned, would want to, at this stage, highlight what they see as problems. We know that there is a lot of angst out there amongst high income earners who could lose a major tax concession. We know that is the case. Of course people are going to get up and complain, but this is above all a fair measure. Your figure of a million people is absolute nonsense because the reality is, as you know, that not one of them need be liable for the surcharge. All they have to do is supply their tax file number.
—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and relates to the minister's recent decision on Point Lillias. What was the `urgent national interest' on which your decision was based?

—The honourable senator may not be aware that there was a fire on Coode Island in 1991. Since then Victorian governments have committed themselves to moving the chemical storage facility which was deemed to be no longer appropriately sited in the centre of a major city. Health and safety reasons were the primary urgent national interest considerations. There was also the future economic opportunity consideration with the need for a facility which would not be so constrained in the future and which could grow to allow the further development of the chemical, rubber and plastics industry in Melbourne, which is vitally important to the economic future of Victoria and Australia.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Since health and safety are the apparent reasons for the urgent national interest decision and considering Geelong and Lara are as close to Point Lillias as many parts of Melbourne, why is it that the health and safety of the residents of Geelong and Lara are less important than the health and safety of Melbourne residents?

—When I paced it out from Coode Island—not totally paced out because that is across water and, unlike some here, I do not claim to walk on water—my observation was that residences in Melbourne, such as those in Footscray—the good suburb of the battlers—were much closer. They are entitled to have such a facility moved further away from them. It is much closer to those in Melbourne than those in Geelong—that is right, is it not, Senator Carr?

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Why does the definition of assessable income for the new 15 per cent superannuation tax include eligible termination payments when such eligible termination payments are already taxed when received by the individual upon ceasing employment? Is this not in effect a tax on a tax—a double tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry, I do not know why you do not read the press statements which are put out and designed to help even people like you deal with these issues. I can refer you to a press release on 5 February which dealt with the issue of golden handshakes. It answers the question that you raised. It stated:

ANSWER.PARA: In the budget the government announced that the contribution surcharge would also apply to golden handshakes. The term relates to eligible termination payments which are financed directly by the employer rather than through superannuation, either defined contribution or defined benefit funds. It should be noted—
take this down, Senator Sherry—
that the definition does not include bona fides redundancy and approved early retirement payments to the extent they are within the income tax exemption limits.
Have you got that? It then states:
The Treasurer, Mr Costello, considers these limits to be generous enough to ensure that the majority of such payments would be outside the scope—

TALK.START.PARA: —Majority?
—Yes, the majority. It goes on:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . of the golden handshake definition entirely. I also consider that it is necessary to include the excess payments over these limits in this definition to prevent such payments being used to avoid the surcharge.
I think that answers Senator Sherry's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Kemp obviously has not read the definition of assessable income in his own legislation. Is it not true—and let me give you an example—that most of the 22,000 Telstra employees that are to be made redundant will have to pay the new 15 per cent tax plus the 7.5 per cent advance instalment tax even though very few of them would earn more than $70,000 a year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Each person will be assessed on an individual basis. If they earn $60,000 per annum—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Sherry interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —What time of the year did they retire? I cannot answer a question which is as poorly framed as the one you have just asked. In relation to eligible termination payments, as you know I have already answered that in general terms. The taxation of those depends on a wide range of factors as you know. Each individual will be assessed.
—And taxed.
—I make it very clear to you, Senator Sherry, that no low or middle income people need pay the surcharge. All they have to do is supply their tax file numbers.
—That's not true.

—I know that you worked for the Transport Workers Union as their superannuation adviser. I trust you confined yourself to superannuation work, but you might like to advise, Senator Sherry, who sits in front of you—(Time expired)

—My question without notice is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, the Minister for the Environment. The federal government has spent $200,000 preparing a world heritage nomination which reads, `The Sydney Opera House, in its harbour setting, reflects the outstanding universal values of a recent architectural masterpiece in an ancient, still evolving cultural landscape.' I ask: why have you and the Prime Minister, who is so keen to live in Sydney, refused to lodge that nomination which would give this Australian icon the status it deserves as one of only four 20th century buildings in the world to be so listed? Is it cultural cringe, some lingering fear or an inability to deal with the genius of Joern Utzon that has led you to veto the Sydney Opera House getting the international status it so richly deserves?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —We are all very proud of the Sydney Opera House. We think it is a fine piece of contemporary architecture and something we can hold out to the rest of the world very proudly. That is one issue. The second issue is whether it was appropriate for us to put it forward in the terms of the proposed reference, and we decided at this time that it was not.

ANSWER.PARA: The reference, which was planned by the former government, was to be the Opera House in its harbour environment. That raised complex questions of exactly what was being listed and what would become the responsibility of the listing party towards other harbour assets. It raised complex questions of where the Opera House would fit within urban planning questions and the responsibility that the Commonwealth would assume in relation to those urban planning questions as the party submitting the nomination.

At this time, we do not have satisfactory answers to those questions. We do not have satisfactory answers to issues relating to the additional costs that might flow as a result of such a nomination and conflicts that could arise out of urban planning matters for which the world listing would be used as the basis of the legal argument. So because of those unsettled, unresolved matters, and because of our determination to only put forward listings where we have plans of management in which we have confidence, we have decided not to progress the listing at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister if he could outline an example of the concern he has as far as the complexities go. Is one the CML building, that ugly and crass intrusion on the Opera House precinct, which might cost as much, I read, as $800 million to buy and demolish? Would he consider the suggestion that to pay for that, if that were necessary, he withdraw the diesel fuel levy to mining corporations for the next year, which happens to total exactly $800 million? I ask him: what is the more important thing—lining the pockets in tax rebate terms of the mining corporations in this country or giving the people of Sydney and Australia the nomination, which they deserve, and the protection of that site, which it deserves?

—In some ways I think the honourable senator has just proven the case. He said that, once the Commonwealth listed, it should, therefore, become liable for buying out the CML building at a cost of $800 million. That is not what world heritage listing is all about, Senator. There has been no other listing proposed of this type that would raise these types of issues of urban planning. Until our concerns are resolved satisfactorily, we will not progress with the listing.

—My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Why does the definition of `assessable income' for the new 15 per cent superannuation tax include redundancy pay? How many low and middle income earners retrenched by your government will be affected by this outrageous measure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —There seems to be a problem with you drafting these questions, Senator Sherry, because you simply do not listen to the answers which have been given to you. We dealt with the issue of redundancy pay in an earlier question.
—But you didn't answer.
—Yes, we did. Because I happen to have it here, I can actually read it to you. This is in relation to golden handshakes. It should be noted that this:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . definition does not include bona fides redundancy and approved early retirement payments to the extent they are within the income tax exemption limits.
This is the press release, Senator Sherry, and I am happy to post you one. But there are a few drawings on this one that I would not want to show you, Senator.

So, Senator Sherry, the question that you raised was answered elsewhere. The fact of the matter is, Senator Sherry, that I would like you to confirm now that you support the 15 per cent surcharge because the whole thrust of your questions has been a deliberate attempt to ease the Labor Party away from its support of the 15 per cent surcharge, which I must confess rather surprises me because at one stage your leader and you were saying it was a very fair measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, Senator Kemp has not read the definition of `assessable income' in his own legislation, but maybe he could just rule it out; rule out that not one Australian worker will have redundancy pay included in the definition of `assessable income' for the purposes of the government's new 15 per cent tax. Rule it out, Senator. Is it not true that thousands of employees who have already been made redundant and will be made redundant are required to pay the new 15 per cent tax plus the 7.5 per cent advanced instalment tax even though very few of them earn $70,000?
—We have discussed at length the position of low and middle income earners in at least three answers I have given. I think it is an extraordinary thing that the Labor Party is attempting to defend—
—We are defending the battlers.

—You are not. That is what you are not doing because the position of low and middle income earners is fully protected, as you well know, by the system we put up. You are wrong, Senator Sherry. I have read out to you the statement that was made on 5 February in relation to redundancy payments.

BREAK.PARA: But what you are trying to do, Senator Sherry—and it is the old Keating Labor Party, it has to be said—is protect the tax concessions that are now available in bucketfuls to high income earners by pretending quite falsely and needlessly that lower and middle income earners are going to be affected. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of the Minister of State from the Irish parliament, Mr Austin Currie, and Mrs Currie. I trust you will have a very happy and enjoyable visit to this country.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, I refer to a recent report which indicated that the problem of drugs and alcohol was at the top of the list of concerns of young people. Eighty per cent of the 400 young people surveyed by the Herald‐Sun indicated that they were concerned about their generation's use of drugs and alcohol. Concern over drugs and alcohol was four times higher than concerns about suicide, which rated 19 per cent, and twice as high as concerns about youth unemployment, which rated 40 per cent. Would you please outline the government's approach to these significant social problems.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Troeth for the question. My attention has been drawn to the survey by the Herald‐Sun indicating that 80 per cent of the surveyed participants expressed concern over drugs and alcohol, which was twice as high as the concerns about youth unemployment and four times higher than that about youth suicide. That perhaps is not a surprise when you consider that drugs and alcohol are more likely to affect a wider range of young Australians.

BREAK.PARA: It is very important that the Commonwealth and state governments do whatever they can to make young people feel positive and confident both about themselves and the future they face. Part of that role is in ensuring that young people are aware of the effects of drugs and alcohol and that they have the right information to enable them to make an informed decision.

On this matter, I am very pleased to note that there is strong cooperation and collaboration between the Commonwealth and the states on the issue of drug education. I do not assume there would be one member of parliament who is not concerned about the impacts of drug and alcohol and what they potentially do to young Australians.

The national initiatives in the drug education project is a major collaborative effort between the state, Commonwealth and territory health and education agencies, police, parents, students and drug education agencies. It promotes the importance of drug education in schools, and involves and works with principals, administrators, teachers and the broader community.

A number of initiatives that are being implemented under the program at a cost of about $2.6 million, nearly $2.7 million are: community seminars in every state and territory to encourage a whole community response to drug education issues; professional development initiatives for drug education teachers conducted in government, Catholic and independent school systems in each state and territory; the implementation of drug education `Do it' series, booklets about curriculum development, pre‐service and in‐service training and strategies to enable schools and agencies to provide drug education for students; and the implementation of the `How will you feel tomorrow?' adolescent alcohol education kit, which is designed fro 13‐ to 17‐year olds, a kit which aims to reduce the incidence of binge drinking amongst those teenagers.

Further initiatives include the development of a CD‐ROM for adolescents on healthy lifestyles and a video on harm minimisation for use by parent organisations and teachers in schools; a teachers' kit on cannabis for use in schools, which has been developed to provide teachers with up‐to‐date information and teaching strategies on cannabis for secondary school students—

TALK.START.PARA: —Cannabis for use in schools—that would be popular.

—Senator, you may think the problem of drugs and alcohol in schools is a laughing matter; I do not. A booklet which specifically targets parents on drug education issues is being produced to provide them with factual information and tips on how to communicate effectively with their children about illicit drugs.
—I have a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, dance party drugs are also an alarming development in this area. How is the government addressing this development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is also funding a major national education project concerning dance party drugs. The project is being conducted through a number of research bodies with, again, state and territory cooperation. The project will develop and test educational materials for venue operators and patrons on the risks of ecstasy and other dance party drugs. The strategy will include an information kit for venues, information for young people and research about patterns of use of dance party drugs.

ANSWER.PARA: National protocols for conducting safer dance parties are also being developed to ensure that this form of entertainment can be undertaken safely. Attention is also being given to improving national information on illicit drug use. A national trial of an illicit drug reporting system is about to commence, It is based on a 12‐month trial undertaken in Sydney, and it will aim to provide early warning indicators of the availability and use of illicit drugs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. The Institute of Chartered Accountants believe that 60 per cent of their membership are going to advise their higher income clients to dump superannuation in favour of more tax effective investments such as their own homes, nega tively geared properties and share portfolios. Have you received a copy of this submission or been informed of this evidence, and what is your response to their claims?

—I thank Senator Sherry again for this question. I am glad he at last gets back to the nub of the game. The nub of the game is to ensure that the very substantial tax concessions which are available to high income earners will be lessened after the surcharge and it will be a fairer system. Senator Sherry, I put it to you that high income earners will, of course, make choices as to what they wish to do. The tax laws will be applied fairly without fear or favour. We believe that the system that we have put in place is a fair system. If some of the high income earners find superannuation less attractive, they have that choice. But we believe that superannuation still, after the surcharge, remains a very attractive option.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, thank you for admitting that some higher income earners are going to avoid this new superannuation tax. In that case, was Treasury giving false evidence to the Senate economics estimates committee when it said that not one dollar would be lost from the $1.5 billion estimated to be collected from the new super tax due to high income earners switching out of superannuation? Will you stand by the estimated revenue projections of $1.5 billion from this new 15 per cent tax and will you assure the Senate that the shortfall will not be collected from people who earn less than $70,000?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry, we stand by the estimates that are based on the best forecasts available.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we do. But the interesting thing is whether the Labor Party is going to continue to support this fair measure. What we are seeing is the classic attempt to position the Labor Party to back down. This is a fair measure, Senator Sherry, which was initially supported by the Labor Party. It will help restore fairness and we believe that we stand behind the estimates which were made for the budget.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. Minister, can you confirm that the employment figures show that a loss of 27,200 full‐time male jobs in February came mostly from the manufacturing sector? Are you aware that the Australian Business Chamber is predicting a loss of a further 7,000 jobs in the manufacturing sector over the next six months? Can you confirm that manufacturing has been the largest single contributor to job losses—accounting for about a third of all retrenchments—during the first 12 months of your government? Do you concede that your $5 billion of cuts to industry assistance are contributing to the current decline in manufacturing? What are you going to do about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to remind Senator Murray that the whole thrust of our economic program, from all economic ministers in this government, is the creation of jobs—the creation of real jobs. This is the reason why we addressed the budget deficit, which we inherited after 13 disgraceful years of Labor. We had no option but to address it. In the process, what we have ended up with, of course, is a series of substantial reductions in interest rates. It is interesting to look at those interest rates in Australia today compared to what they were in the years of Labor, when I recall interest rates going to 21 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: What we also have now too is the lowest inflation rate in decades. I think Mr Costello said it is the lowest inflation rate we have had since man walked on the moon. One of the difficulties that some businesses are encountering—it is a real issue that is being encountered by business, mainly in the small and medium enterprises—is that for the first time in 25 years they are operating in a low inflation regime. There are a lot of people in the business sector who have not operated in that low inflation regime. So it is something that really is important to them. But it is much better to be in that regime than in one where you have high inflation and high interest rates, where prices are going up and where the returns made on the surface look all right, but it is a paper increase and it is phoney.

As to the latter part of your question regarding the reduction in certain business incentives, no, I do not agree with you that that has had the effect. We have had a period of only 12 months in government. That came after a period of 13 years of Labor when we had the highest number of bankruptcies, high interest rates and all those things that basically destroyed business. But more importantly, those things destroyed the confidence of the business sector. What we are in the process of doing is restoring that confidence, which will mean more investment and more real jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, the $5 billion worth of cuts was in your budget; it was to industry assistance and it has hurt badly. Has this issue of manufacturing jobs losses been considered by the do nothing Prime Minister's cabinet employment committee or is the government not worried about keeping the jobs we already have?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Manufacturing is a very important industry in this country. Everyone agrees with that. But a lot of the manufacturing in Australia flows from a lot of other investments in a lot of other industries. One in particular is in the portfolio that I represent, which is the resources sector. If we are going to get the benefits that flow on to this economy through the manufacturing sector, we are going to have to get the investments that are projected before me.

ANSWER.PARA: I have said this over and over again: currently before me there are $40 billion worth of projected investments within the resources, gas and oil sectors. They will not all come to pass; I am the first person to admit that. But as a government and as a parliament, if we are interested in the future of this country, in expanding the manufacturing sector and in expanding real jobs in the community, we should be doing everything in our power to ensure that that investment comes to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Why has the government ruled out a change to its universally condemned collection mechanism of the new superannuation tax? Why will the estimated cost of between $50 million and $100 million have to be borne by all fund members' accounts, particularly those lower and middle income earners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason we have ruled out a change, Senator, is because the other options, including the Labor option, would involve unacceptable costs on small business.
—That is not true, and you know it!

—Senator Mighty Mouse jumps up. If Senator Sherry had been honest in your party room, Senator, he would have revealed to you that the Labor option would involve unacceptably high costs on small business. We are not going to go down that route. We have assessed a variety of options which were put up. We have decided on the option which we think is the best and fairest option.
—The superannuation funds don't agree with you. No-one agrees with you.

—Senator Sherry says that the superannuation funds do not agree with us. Big deal. Big deal that the superannuation funds do not agree with us. What a surprise! What a total surprise. It is also, of course, the superannuation funds—who administer superannuation and who have the systems, one hopes, in place to ensure these things can be done efficiently—who wish to pass the administration off elsewhere. That is no surprise, Senator Sherry. We understood that from day one.

ANSWER.PARA: We have assessed a variety of options which have been put forward. I would be interested to hear in your supplementary question what the Labor Party option is. It would be rather enlightening for this chamber to find out what option you are proposing. I wonder if it is the ASFA option, Senator Sherry. Why don't you enlighten us?

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Kemp may be interested to know that even small business condemns this collection mechanism. Everyone condemns the collection mechanism, including small business. Senator, isn't this collection mechanism just a farce? Why do you continue to pretend that this issue is not a tax? Why do you continue to pretend it is a surcharge? That is why the whole issue has lapsed into an absolute farce.

—We seem to have got back to question one again. Senator Sherry, this is a series of very poorly drafted questions. Senator Sherry, let us get the system clear so even you understand it. The superannuation funds have to know the names of their members. Correct? The superannuation funds have to know the contributions applicable to those members. Correct? The superannuation funds are now collecting tax file numbers, which they would have done even under your system. Correct?
—They can't get them.

—Senator Sherry, what they have to do is to supply that information to the Taxation Office. What is so crushingly complex about this? That is what they have to do. This is a total beat‐up, and, Senator Sherry, you did not tell us your option. You did not tell us the Labor Party option.
—I told you our option.
—No, you didn't. You had your chance, and you ducked it.

—My question is to the Minister for Resources and Energy. It relates to the reduction in greenhouse gases and the positive response by Australian industry. Last year we saw the first signing of the greenhouse challenge cooperative agreements between government and industry. Can the minister confirm reports that this program has been strongly supported by business and industry? What have been the outcomes of these cooperative efforts between the coalition government and industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Patterson for that question because it is a very important one in the current context. Australian industry is strongly supporting the coalition's greenhouse challenge program to voluntarily reduce their emissions. The number of companies committed to developing cooperative agreements is increasing. We now have passed the 100 mark of companies and industry associations committed to the program through agreements and letters of intent. They cover a wide range of industries reflecting the breadth of industry support for the program.

ANSWER.PARA: The government was committed to accelerating the implementation of the greenhouse challenge program when it came to office. The fact is that we now have over 100 companies and industry associations supporting this program. That, within less than a year since coming to office, is testament to the government's achievement of cooperation with industry not only in this area but in so many others.

The number of companies that have developed cooperative agreements is also increasing. Two signing ceremonies were held last year with my colleague Senator Hill and Minister Moore with 17 companies and five industry associations signing cooperative agreements with the government. The agreements signed to date demonstrate that companies can deliver significant emission savings. The agreements cover over 250 major sites across Australia. These sites contribute 46 per cent of Australia's emissions from the industrial sector.

The agreements have identified over 420 actions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. These actions are estimated to reduce the aggregated emissions of the 17 companies by approximately 15 per cent for the year 2000. More companies are getting their agreements ready for acceptance by this government.

Two signing ceremonies have been scheduled for the next two months. A signing ceremony focusing on the electricity sector will be held next week at Parliament House. This will be followed by another signing ceremony in Brisbane on 1 May, which will focus on the expansion of the program and the innovative actions and R&D identified by some companies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. More agreements are expected to be ready in the second half of the year.

The government will be ensuring that the momentum for this program continues. The Greenhouse Challenge Office will continue to work closely with industry associations to promote the program. The office will also continue to provide a range of assistance to companies developing agreements. This includes workbooks on how to develop cooperative agreements, workshops to provide hands-on guidance and case studies of what has been implemented by other companies to reduce energy use and greenhouse emissions.

Cooperative agreements are not static documents, and those that sign agreements will be reporting to the challenge office in implementing their actions. The program captures the capacity of industry to reduce its emissions to minimum levels consistent with their growth and competitiveness.

The benefit of greenhouse challenge is not just greenhouse oriented. It has meant that companies and organisations have been able—by saving energy—to significantly reduce their input costs, thus making our industries more competitive, which in turn will lead to more jobs in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer. Where in the Treasurer's budget night announcement of the new superannuation tax does it indicate that federal and High Court judges and state public sector employees would be exempt from this measure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to High Court judges, we have indicated that, under the constitution, existing High Court judges will not be liable for the surcharge. That is a statement that the Treasurer has made. That applies to existing judges; that does not apply to new appointments.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to state schemes, I refer you to the press release which looks at the issue of constitutionally protected schemes in the states. As you are aware, we are having discussions with the states so that the surcharge can be applied in an equitable and fair manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. It is interesting, Senator Kemp, that the Treasurer only discovered these particular problems some five months after the budget announcement, and we only received the legislation in the last few weeks. How can you call this a fair tax measure when more than 25,000 Australian employees could be exempt from the tax? How much revenue do you estimate could be lost by these exemptions from the taxation net?
—Good question.

—It is an absolutely hopeless question. The reality is that we have explained the position to you clearly in relation to the existing federal judges. In relation to the states, we have indicated today and we have indicated in the press release that we are having discussions with the states to ensure that the surcharge is applied to those who are liable—high income earners. I put it to Senator Sherry that the situation is clear from the statements in the press release put out by Mr Costello. It is a fair measure, and I hope the Labor Party will continue to support us.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the eight answers given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to questions without notice asked by Senator Sherry today, relating to the superannuation surcharge.

Senator Kemp has been in the position of Assistant Treasurer since the demise of his predecessor, Senator Short, for some seven months. He has now had one month more than Senator Short had to get across the detail of this new superannuation surcharge. I note in passing that Senator Short is off to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. Senator Kemp is really going to need some reconstruction and development if this superannuation tax provision goes through.

BREAK.PARA: In the seven months that Senator Kemp has had this position of Assistant Treasurer, you would think that he would at least be across the reasonable detail of this proposed new superannuation surcharge—or, whoops, it is a tax. You would think Senator Kemp would by now be able to answer not really technical questions but broad policy questions that go to the collection of this proposed new tax.

We have asked Senator Kemp about our specific concerns, broad concerns that a minister could expect to reasonably be able to answer—after all, Senator Kemp has carriage of this matter. He is the one responsible for going around industry and consulting and listening—he is doing none of that, by the way. He is not listening to everyone who is complaining about this new superannuation tax. Senator Kemp is responsible directly for the administration, consultation and the passage of this legislation through the Senate. I put it to you that, after seven months, Senator Kemp cannot answer in any reasonable detail very many—if indeed any—questions put to him about this issue.
One of the critical issues is the lack of honesty of Senator Kemp, of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) because they will not call the tax a tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —A spade a spade.

—A spade a spade. At the last election the coalition promised there would be no new taxes and no increase in existing taxes. What does the Prime Minister present us with; what does the Treasurer present us with; and what does the Assistant Treasurer present us with? No, it is not a new tax—it is only the government's largest revenue earner with $1.5 billion over three years—it is a surcharge.

BREAK.PARA: People in the community say it is a tax—accountants, lawyers and everyone, including your own party members, Senator Kemp. We know they have complained bitterly. They say it is a tax. Senator Kemp on PM last week said it is a tax. More important is the unfairness of this new tax because the collection of this new tax requires superannuation funds to collect seven million to eight million tax file numbers on 16 million superannuation ac counts—that is all, only six, seven or eight million tax file numbers. That is all that is required.

Particularly in the first year of this tax, operative from August last year, all the evidence—not from the Labor opposition but from superannuation funds, AMP, Jacques Martin, LISA, Coopers and Lybrand, and William Mercer—is that the tax file numbers will not be collected in the first year. They will be lucky to get even half the tax file numbers in the first year.

What happens if a fund does not provide the tax file number because the members have not been able to provide it? They get taxed the full 15 per cent. It is not our assertion but the assertion of industry that one million lower and middle income earners will have to pay this new 15 per cent tax. On top of that there is the advance instalment of 7½ per cent, a new 22½ per cent tax on top of the existing 15 per cent tax when they leave the fund. You in the government may choose to ignore Senator Kemp's incompetence in handling these issues. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I would like to add my congratulations to my colleague Senator Short on his very senior appointment to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. I think it would be very difficult to get a better man to fill this important position, particularly at a very critical time in the development of the European Community and the move towards a common currency which is going to have widespread ramifications right across the community.
—I take a point of order. We all know that Senator Watson is unparalleled as a lickspittle in the government but what on earth does this have to do with the motion before the chair?
—I am quite sure that Senator Watson was going through some preamble and is now about to address the motion to take note of the answer.

—It was an acknowledgment of a very important appointment. I was responding to a matter which was raised by Senator Sherry. Obviously, Senator Faulkner, you do not listen to your own back bench—and it is about time you did.

SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon Senator Kemp came under what I suppose you would have to say was sustained attack from the opposition. Those up in the gallery who have any knowledge of superannuation would know that Senator Sherry asked all the wrong questions. It was not very difficult for Senator Kemp to deflect the questions very adequately.

We all know that the emphasis of Senator Sherry's questioning was on the tax file number arrangements and the liability for tax of a number of people if they do not lodge their tax file numbers. But what Senator Sherry did not tell people—and I think this is important—is that when people become aware of that situation, or at any time, they can apply and get a refund of the tax they have paid. We all know that tax file numbers have been pretty essential for a long time in terms of both taxation and superannuation. There has been some concern by major players about the extension of tax file number scenarios. For this reason a Privacy Commission was appointed and before any legislation of importance in relation to tax file number applications is put there has to be a consultation with the Privacy Commissioner. That has all happened.

Let me go back a little in terms of history and look at the tax file number. I recall that about a decade ago I was privileged to serve on the public accounts committee when it was looking at major reconstruction of the Taxation Office and a concept of putting in a major computerisation network which turned out to be worth something like a billion dollars. But what was really needed at that time and which the public accounts committee drew attention to—and which your party picked up—was the need for a more adequate system and for centralisation to be able to cross‐match.

There was a lot of evidence that the tax office was having a great deal of difficulty in terms of its cross‐matching. So we had the scenario that associated with this big investment there had to be some sort of cross‐matching mechanism. A tax file numbering arrangement was the best way out. I must admit that over the years, particularly in the initial years, it was somewhat embarrassing to me because the debate got a little off‐line and went into the Australia card. But it is interesting that with our tax file number system we have something that is perhaps a little more intrusive than we would have had under the Australia card proposal. We all know that these have been contentious issues but at all times the Privacy Commissioner has had a great deal of say in relation to what has happened.

I must say something about the timing and the choice of attack this afternoon. Why this afternoon? Why has it taken Senator Sherry so long to suddenly discover all these issues? The legislation is now in the parliament and generally there is a convention, particularly when issues that parliamentary committees are looking at have been introduced into the parliament, that we each have our say at those committees.

The Senate select committee that I chair, of which Senator Sherry is a member, only last week took evidence from a selection of about 70 people and organisations who put in some very useful submissions to the committee. The committee is currently in the process of preparing the report, which has been prepared under great time pressures. It is unfortunate that I, Senator Sherry and others have been drawn into this debate because it is difficult for us as we must not reveal the thrust or the content of the report. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to take note of none of Senator Kemp's answers because none of them were answering the questions. What I really want to take issue with Senator Kemp over is his continued assertion that no middle and low income earners have to pay this tax. This is grossly misleading the Australian public and grossly misleading this chamber. Every piece of evidence given to the Senate select committee shows that there is going to be thousands and thousands of Australians who earn less than $70,000 affected. In fact, every single member of every single super fund in this country is going to pay to raise the tax.

BREAK.PARA: The conservative estimates are that it is going to cost $100 million in set‐up costs. That has been worked out at $12.50 extra admin fee for every member of every fund in Australia. That is just the set‐up costs. Then you have the running costs, which are ongoing. That has been costed at between $25 million and $30 million every year hereafter. That works out at an extra $3.75. So when you stand up and say that nobody who earns less than $75,000 is going to be affected, what about the $12 and the $3? Is that no effect?

Then we come to the question of supplying the tax file numbers. Even your own tax office officials sat in front of the committee and said that after the mail‐outs that you are going to organise, which you committed to, and the efforts that they are going to make, they think they will have done okay if they have 40 per cent of the tax file numbers. That means 60 per cent of people who have the fund account are going to be affected. Well over one million ordinary Australians who earn less than $75,000 are going to be up for your surcharge tax. That is what is going to be happening. They are all going to be up for it.

And you have eligible termination payments. Your own definitions in your own legislation, which you do not seem to have read, clearly show that of the 9,000 Telstra workers who have been laid off since July last year a vast majority—the prize for being laid off under your government—are now going to be categorised as high income earners. Assessable income under your definition in your legislation. All because you do not want to get caught breaking one of your core promises.

You say that we are in a situation where there are going to be costs. I want to read to you, Senator Kemp, the evidence given by AMP last week where they explain exactly why you saying that there are heaps of extra costs to all those 900,000 business is just an absolute furphy. If you could take the blinkers off you would see that. This is Mr Kevin Casey from AMP—not ASFA, not Sue Ryan; AMP:

One the arguments being mounted against this is that it would increase the compliance cost on employers by their having to provide this information on group certificates. But concurrently with the announcement of the surcharge legislation, the government has also announced changes to the maximum deductible contribution that could be claimed by an employer in respect of the employees.
This is one of yours; do you recognise that?

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't that fair? You're not attacking that, are you?
—No, I am supporting it.

BREAK.PARA: Previously, for employers with 10 or more members they were able to average that out across the number of employees. The government decided, for quite legitimate reasons, to withdraw that concession and now every employer—
Listen to this, Senator Kemp—

must actually keep the amount of contribution paid in respect of each and every employee through the year. Not only that, they have to actually keep the date of the payment of the last contribution because the scale is actually based on age and the age is determined at the date of the last contribution so the employers have already got to keep this information now in respect of determining how much they can claim in respect of each and every employee, and for tax substantiation purposes.
(Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join in this debate and note that Senator Sherry was worried about answers to questions. I thought the questions were rather pathetic and, indeed, entirely predictable because, Senator Sherry, what you are doing is attempting to reposition the Labor Party. You are pretending, in quite a malicious fashion I believe, that low and middle income earners are going to be hit. What you are really doing, is trying to protect the big end of town; that is, the Keating Labor Party, and we are seeing the Keating Labor Party coming through with you, Senator Sherry. Senator Conroy runs, as one would expect, the ASFA line—and why wouldn't he run the ASFA line?—and so does Senator Sherry. It is no surprise that the superannuation funds are prepared to attack this measure and the mechanism which the government has decided to use to collect the surcharge.

BREAK.PARA: What we have not got clear is: we think the Labor Party still supports the 15 per cent. I notice that Senator Sherry was a bit loathe to really confirm that—
Senator Sherry interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —but now, by way of interjection, he seems to be trying to confirm it.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Sherry interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is good to hear. But we did not hear the mechanism by which the Labor Party wishes to have the surcharge collected.
—A tax.

—I challenged Senator Sherry a couple of times to make crystal clear what was the Labor Party collection approach. I have to say, Senator, that you ducked it on a couple of occasions—I think, very sensibly. I do not knock you. The reality is that once you, Senator Sherry, show how you would choose to collect it, I suspect that you would be subjected to a large amount of pressure from people whom you were determined to put the administration cost on.
—The higher income earners?

—Senator Sherry, you want to put the administration costs on small business. That is the Labor Party approach. Its approach has always been to attack small business. Senator Sherry is proceeding down the well worn Keating track of continuing to attack small business and proposing what I think is a Labor Party option, although neither Senator Sherry nor Senator Conroy was prepared to get up and be quite explicit.
—You'll get our amendments next week.
—We will have your amendments next week! After seven months of debate, Senator Sherry still finds it impossible to stand in the chamber and be crystal clear—
—We only got the last two bills last week—you keep amending them.

—Don't be so sensitive, Senator Sherry. Mr Acting Deputy President, it is a bit hard to speak with the glass jaw breaking over there. The sound is deafening over here. Senator Sherry, you know that you had the chance to explain very clearly what the Labor Party's position was on the collection approach and what your option was, and you ducked it. You said that, after all these months, you are still not in a position to do it.

BREAK.PARA: What we have here is a major attack on a very fair budget measure. That is what we are seeing. Let us not hide or resile from that issue. Out in the community, there are many groups, particularly high income groups, who would wish to see this measure fall over. What is absolutely disgraceful about the debate which has ensured today are the scare tactics which Senator Sherry has attempted to run, the end result of which is to protect the very generous concessions that high income earners currently receive.

Senator Sherry, I think this has been a most unedifying performance by you. If you supported the 15 per cent surcharge—not the collection mechanism—then the onus was on you to actually indicate that to us. Are you that gutless? After all these months you could not stand up and tell us exactly what the Labor Party wanted to do. That is the issue that emerged today—an issue which you comprehensively ducked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) just said that we are so gutless that we have not stood up and said where we stand on this tax. He comes from a party that would not tell the electors before the last election where they stood on any policy issues whatsoever and tried to gull Australia into believing that they supported everything they stood for. One of the things that they tried to gull Australia into believing—and, in fact, may well have succeeded—is that there would be no new taxes or no increase in existing taxes. What we now have quite clearly on the record is that that was meant only to win votes; it was not meant to be delivered in government.

SPEECH.PARA: Feeble is the only way you can describe the performance of the Assistant Treasurer today—not just today but every day he stands in this place and has to answer a question. He does not know the answers to basic questions on his portfolio. Rather than say that and sit down, or rather than take the time that he should to find his brief and answer at least from what the public servants have written for him, he blusters, he waffles, he tells tales and he diverts the debate away from him to other things that are not relevant. This does not go unnoticed. The gallery knows that this is an incompetent person in the position of Assistant Treasurer.

It must be particularly galling to Senators Watson and Short, who sit behind him and who have had some experience in this area, to recognise that, despite the fact that they are not on the front bench, the person who shoulders the responsibility for the government in this area is inferior to the task. I had a lot to say about Senator Short when he was the minister but, by God, come back Shorty, in the face of this performance, because he would be able to deal with some of the technical elements that Senator Kemp cannot.

There were eight questions asked of Senator Kemp today about this iniquitous tax, which it really is and which Senator Kemp admitted to it being on the PM program the other day. But, of course, he corrected himself in a piece of crisis management engineered by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) to save the government's face. The inescapable truth of this so-called surcharge is that it is a tax. Everyone knows that it is a tax. The government will not admit it because, if it does, it will admit to breaking a core promise. As a consequence, honest Australians, middle and low income earners, will shoulder a much higher cost in paying this tax just to save the government's face.

What were the questions? The first question was obviously about the tax, or the surcharge. Then we wanted to know about the tax file numbers and how the government calculated the target number that it would collect. We wanted to know why would a million middle income earners have to pay out the super taxation that the government has proposed. What answer did we get to that second question? We got a story about how difficult it might be for the Labor Party to sign up new members—nothing to do with the so-called battlers, nothing to do with the question posed and nothing to do with the very serious question of how it was calculated that a million middle income earners would be hurt by this super taxation.

We asked for a definition of assessable income. What did we get? We got an around the trees, around the bushes diatribe which dodged that question—an essential question to this whole debate. We asked about assessable income, including redundancy pay. The minister was asked explicitly to confirm what he was trying to allege in this place—that low and middle income earners would not have their redundancies taxed. Did he do it? No, he did not. What does failing to do that signify in this debate? It signifies a cover‐up and gives credibility to the assertion, which is, in fact, the truth of the matter, that middle and low income workers who are in redundant positions will have, or are at risk of having, part of their superannuation taxed in this way.

He was asked about the switching from superannuation to other forms of investment, by those who can afford it, in order to escape paying tax. Most blue‐ and white‐collar workers in Australia do not have the discretionary income to pursue other forms of investment to avoid this tax. High income earners have that discretionary income. The government has told this Senate, through its committees, and it was reinforced by the minister today—(Time expired).

Let me say a couple of other things before getting on to that. First of all, Senator Cook's comments about Senator Kemp are absolutely ridiculous. Senator Kemp is doing a fantastic job as Assistant Treasurer, a great job as Assistant Treasurer. The way that he is absolutely killing Senator Sherry in question time day after day is a truly great embarrassment for the Australian Labor Party. The problem is that they do not have anyone to replace Senator Sherry. That is an absolute indictment of the quality of the team on that side. Senator Cook spoke before me and did not exactly cover himself with glory considering he is a former minister for industry and his other capacities.

—Senator Cook was a member of a government that promised not to increase the overall tax burden and promised to honour the l-a-w, law, tax pledge in the 1993 election. Let me hear nothing from the other side of politics about taxes.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, if you look at what happened to the whole superannuation system under Labor, you will find that it was those decisions, particularly the introduction in the late 1980s of the contributions tax as a deliberate means to pull forward revenue, that caused the problems in the superannuation industry that we are all trying to grapple with today.

Senator Sherry does not seem to have advanced his cause or his thinking in this area since the budget. All we heard today was a cracked record saying the same old negative things that Senator Sherry has been saying since day one, the same things that he was putting to me when I was minister. He has not progressed it one iota since then.

Talk about being hit with a wet lettuce: Senator Kemp today left you, Senator Sherry, for dead because your questions are completely based on false allegations and false assertions. I am sure you know that. You are simply wrong about most of the things you are saying.

There are two issues in this: the first one is the surcharge, and the second is the imple mentation mechanism. As I understand it, and perhaps Senator Sherry will reconfirm this, Labor do support the 15 per cent surcharge, although they seemed to back off today in an unequivocal nature. What Senator Kemp has been really concentrating on is the implementation mechanism. As he said in question time today, we have looked at all the various options for implementation and we have come to the conclusion that the proposal that we have is simply the best of the alternatives. For Labor to go on and on about that without offering an alternative to the proposal that we have is just scandalous.

The fact is that what Labor appears to be trying to do is to impose the burden on a million small and medium size enterprises in Australia to absolve 130,000 or so superannuation funds from being involved in some additional administrative costs. That is a ridiculous argument to attempt to mount.
