SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of the Senate, I present the communique of the National Schools Constitutional Convention, which was held here in Parliament House between 6 and 8 March 1997. There were 110 students from schools from all over Australia attending the convention, organised by the Constitutional Centenary Foundation. I attended on the Saturday afternoon to receive from them the communique which they prepared, and with the consent of the Senate I propose that it be incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: The communique read as follows —
National Schools Constitutional Convention
6‐8 March 1997, Parliament House, Canberra
Communique
The second National Schools Constitutional Convention was held in the Main Committee Room, Parliament House, Canberra on 6‐8 March 1997.
One hundred and twenty student delegates from 110 schools from all Australian states and territories took part in the Convention organised by the Constitutional Centenary Foundation.

The Schools Constitutional Conventions are a project of the Foundation to promote understanding and informed discussion amongst young Australians about the Australian Constitution and system of government. Student delegates from every Austral ian school in the catholic, government and independent education sectors are given the opportunity to participate in regional and state/territory schools constitutional conventions, where they are either selected or elected to attend the National Convention.

The Convention was opened by the Hon. Dr. David Kemp, Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Convention sessions were chaired by Professor Cheryl Saunders, Deputy Chair of the Constitutional Centenary Foundation. Other speakers included: Father Frank Brennan, Senator Bill O'Chee, Ms Pat Turner, Sir David Smith, Professor Don Markwell and Ms Gladys Berejiklian.

Student delegates were addressed by His Excellency the Honourable Sir William Deane, Governor‐General of the Commonwealth of Australia at a welcome reception at Government House. As part of the Convention program, delegates attended Question Time in the House of Representatives and met with Members of Parliament at afternoon tea.
The ACT Minister for Education and Training, Mr Bill Stefaniak, welcomed the students to Canberra at an evening function in the Rose Garden at Old Parliament House.

The Conference dinner was addressed by His Excellency, Dr. Bhandra Ranchod, the South African High Commissioner. At the conclusion of the Convention, Senator Margaret Reid accepted the Communique to convey to the Prime Minister and the Commonwealth Parliament.
Assistance for the Convention was provided by the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, with sponsorship from the Australian Mutual Provident Society (AMP) and BHP.
The convention delegates discussed two issues: Constitutional guarantees against racial discrimination; An Australian Republic?
The conclusions of the Convention on these issues were:
Constitutional Guarantees Against Racial Discrimination

The Convention resolved, by a large majority, that section 25 should be removed from the Constitution. Section 25 accepts that a State might refuse to allow some Australian citizens to vote in State elections on the grounds of their race. The sanction which it offers is weak and involves excluding the same citizens from the population figures used to decide how many Members of the House of Representatives will be chosen from each State. While the section no longer has much practical significance, it seems out of place in a modern Constitution.

The Convention discussed at length whether section 25 should be replaced with another provision and, if so, what that should be. In the end, it resolved that the Constitution should guarantee a right to vote to all Australian citizens, along the following lines:
"No government in Australia shall have the power to discriminate against any Australian citizen by denying them the right to vote".
The Convention agreed that the wording of the section should allow necessary restrictions to be placed on the right to vote by, for example, setting the minimum voting age.

The Convention also recommended that the preamble to the Constitution should recognise the prior occupation of Australia by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, and their culture. It also noted the exclusion of Western Australia, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory from the current preamble and resolved that they should be included.

The Convention discussed a range of other ways of dealing with racial discrimination, outside the Constitution. Those mentioned included better education about racial discrimination and human rights generally and the importance of political and community leaders speaking out against discrimination and setting a good example themselves. The Convention also endorsed the importance of educated, open and tolerant public debate on these issues.
An Australian Republic?
The Convention resolved, by a substantial majority, that Australia should become a republic.

A substantial majority of delegates favoured selection of a republican Head of State by a two thirds majority of each of the two Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament. The Head of State should be appointed for a five year term and should be able to be removed by the Parliament.

The Convention recommended that the powers of the Head of State should be spelt out in the Constitution to a greater extent than is the case at present, so that the main rules concerning the exercise of powers by the Head of State would be at least partly codified.

The Convention agreed unanimously that all parts of Australia should become a republic at the same time, on the basis of agreement within each State and Territory. It was also unanimously agreed that Australia should stay in the Commonwealth.

The Convention noted the importance of education about the republic and other constitutional issues, so that Australians understand their own system of government and can make informed decisions on these important questions.
For further information about the Convention, contact:
Ms Marian Schoen, Executive Director, Constitutional Centenary Foundation
155 Barry Street CARLTON Victoria 3053. Tel:(03) 9349 1846 or Fax: (03) 9349 1779

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —During debate in the Senate on 5 March 1997, the Acting Deputy President undertook to refer two matters to me. In debate on a motion to suspend standing orders, Senator Carr stated that one of the matters in issue was `the manner in which votes are brought in this place'. Senator Campbell raised a point of order that this constituted offensive words against the Senate contrary to standing order 193(3). The Acting Deputy President invited Senator Carr to make it clear that he was not reflecting on the Senate, and, on receiving an apparent assurance from Senator Carr that he was not, allowed him to proceed. Senator Campbell objected to this, suggested that it was establishing a bad precedent and asked that it be referred to me.

SPEECH.PARA: Where expressions are used which are open to an interpretation that makes them contrary to the standing orders, it is always open to the chair to ask the senator speaking to clarify their meaning and intention, and, if that meaning and intention is not contrary to the standing orders, to allow the senator to proceed on that basis without withdrawing the words in question. The Acting Deputy President was therefore entitled to accept the assurance of Senator Carr that he was not reflecting on the Senate and to allow him to proceed on that basis. I must say, however, that the assurance given by Senator Carr was itself somewhat ambiguous, and perhaps the chair should have sought further clarification of his meaning. Senators should remember that the standing orders prohibit reflections upon the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —During debate on the report of the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee on the telecommunications package of bills, Senator Schacht recounted how the committee had heard from many witnesses together and allowed them to exchange views in the course of the committee's hearing. He suggested that the Procedure Committee should consider changes to the standing orders relating to the operations of committees to facilitate this process. The Acting Deputy President undertook to refer this matter to me also.

INTERJECT.PARA: There is nothing in the standing orders which prevents committees adopting the form of proceedings mentioned by Senator Schacht, and committees in the past have adopted that mode of operation. I do not think, therefore, that there is any requirement for the Procedure Committee to examine the matter.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On Thursday 6 March I informed the Senate that I had received a report from the Department of the Senate on an investigation into travelling allowance payments made to Senator Colston, that I had asked Senator Colston to respond to the report by no later than today, and that I would table the report and Senator Colston's response. Yesterday I received a further report from the Department of the Senate and I asked Senator Colston to respond to that report also.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Colston has requested an extension of time for him to respond to both reports as he has to examine associated documents. I have now asked Senator Colston to respond to both reports by no later than Monday 24 March, and I have indicated that I will table both reports in the absence of his response if it is not received by that date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

Madam President, on behalf of the opposition I register a strong protest at your failure to table the report into Senator Colston's alleged misuse of his parliamentary entitlements. You gave an undertaking, Madam President, to table that report today, together with all correspondence and related documents. We expected you to fulfil that undertaking, and we are not persuaded by the reasons that you have put forward for failing to do so.

The allegations against Senator Colston are serious and, if proven, they affect his capacity to sit in the Senate. You have indicated that the delay is a consequence of a request from Senator Colston for more time to prepare his explanation. That is not acceptable. Senator Colston has had 12 days in which to respond. I say that surely that is sufficient. There was not such delay in the prime ministerial approval for the upgrade of Senator Colston's staff. There was no such delay in doing the deal with Senator Alston and Senator Hill over the deputy presidency of the Senate.

Neither you, Madam President, nor Senator Colston apparently see any need to delay today's tabling of the Senate report on the detail of senators' travel arrangements going back five years. Nor, I say, should that document be delayed in its tabling. It is not as though Senator Colston does not have sufficient staff resources to assist him in responding to this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —More than anybody else.
—That is right. Unlike most other senators, he has five staff, including two staff at higher levels.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam President, the opposition does not believe the delay in the tabling of this report until Monday of next week is justified. We do accept that the additional report to which you have referred should not be tabled until Senator Colston has had a reasonable time to respond to it. If further irregularities have come to light since the report by the Department of the Senate was first given to Senator Colston, then it is appropriate that he be given the time to respond to them, but we do not accept that as an excuse for delaying the tabling of the original report. Surely in this case Senator Colston's answers to those first allegations will not be different now that there is a further report.

Senator Colston is now the subject of several departmental inquiries into alleged misuse of parliamentary entitlements—none of which, I might add, have been requested by the opposition. Two of these inquiries are being conducted by the Department of Ad ministrative Services. The first was requested by the minister after television footage indicated misuse of the self‐drive vehicle provided to Senator Colston in his capacity as Deputy President. The second, as I understand it, relates to the use of his charter allowance in Queensland. Anonymous spokesmen for the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Jull) have indicated that the inquiries are even broader than this, but we have had no official confirmation to that effect. A third inquiry is being conducted by the Department of the Senate on its own initiative, and of course it is this inquiry that was later enjoined by Senator Colston, although we are not certain of the precise timing of that.

Madam President, until now we have accepted the government's word that Senator Colston would be treated no differently from any other parliamentarian in a similar position. Today's developments indicate that this is no longer the case. There is no doubt that he has had sufficient time and opportunity to respond to the initial Senate report. He has, nevertheless, successfully sought to defer the matter.

We are justified in asking why Senator Colston requires more time to prepare his defence. Is it the case that perhaps he is having difficulty remembering the exact details of the 777 days of travel allowance claimed in just four years from the financial years 1992 to 1996? Is he having trouble accounting for the $117,610 claimed over that four‐year period? Is he unable to explain why, in the financial year 1993‐94, he claimed travel allowance for a total of 265 days—and 265 is 72.6 per cent of the year? Is he unable to explain why he claimed $41,475 in travel allowance in that year when he was a parliamentary officeholder for only eight weeks and he was, in fact, a backbencher for the rest of the year?

Is he unable to explain why Senator Hill, the then Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, claimed 155 days while he, Senator Colston, claimed 265? Is he unable to explain why the then Leader of the Opposition in the Senate claimed $27,260 in travel allowance while Senator Colston claimed $41,475? Is he unable to explain why the then Minister for Defence and Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Robert Ray, claimed $23,450 and the then Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Alston, claimed $28,205 in travel allowance, yet he, Senator Colston, claimed $41,475?

Is he unable to explain why, on one occasion in 1993, he claimed travel allowance for 29 consecutive days and on another occasion in the same year for 28 consecutive days? Perhaps his recollection is faulty about those 28 consecutive days claimed from 27 July 1993 onwards when he claimed four days in Melbourne, one in Sydney, then three in Sydney, two in Canberra, four in Melbourne, three in Canberra, two in Sydney, seven in Canberra and two in Canberra, for a grand total, on the trot, of $6,160. Is he unable to explain why he, Senator Colston, claimed 15 or more consecutive days of travel allowance on 11 occasions since 1993?

Madam President, is he unable to explain why, between October 1993 and February 1996, he took five trips to Norfolk Island totalling 29 days and claimed over $4,000 in travel allowance? Is he unable to explain why, in the same period, he took five trips to Cocos Island and to Christmas Island totalling 17 days and claimed over $2,400 in travel allowance? Is Senator Colston unable to explain how he claimed travel allowance in Canberra for 9 June 1996, when the Senate records indicate that he stayed in Perth that night? Is he unable to explain why he claimed travel allowance in Canberra for 8 September 1994 when television footage has shown him opening a jobskills program on the Gold Coast?

Is he unable to explain why, on 7 April 1996, his duties on the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances were so onerous that they required him to claim travel allowance for Easter Sunday? Put simply, it is not surprising that, given the magnitude of Senator Colston's travel allowance claims, he is having difficulty coming up with a plausible explanation.

Is it not a fact that Senator Colston is having trouble explaining all of the irregularities and discrepancies which have emerged in relation to his use of parliamentary entitle ments because that use has, in fact, been abuse? Is it not the case that neither two weeks, two months or even two years in this case would be enough for Senator Colston to explain why his travel allowance claims do not constitute a systematic exploitation of every favourable interpretation of the travel allowance provisions?

The Prime Minister, Mr Howard, gave an undertaking that Senator Colston would not be given preferential treatment. At least three other parliamentarians have been the subject of allegations concerning the recent use or misuse of their parliamentary entitlements. One of them has paid back a sum of money and provided a full and public explanation of the circumstances surrounding the repayment. Two others are subject to investigation by the Australian Federal Police. Consistency demands that Senator Colston be given no special favours.

The Senate is entitled to know whether the irregularities and discrepancies are merely mistakes by the Department of the Senate or poor staff work by all of Senator Colston's employees or whether they constitute systematic fraud against the Commonwealth. Senate travel documents have disappeared. Investigations are being carried out by staff who, in my view, are neither equipped nor trained for such investigations. Rights are being extended to Senator Colston which were denied to Mr Cobb and to ex‐Senator Woods. Madam President, you should end this farce now. I ask you to reconsider your position and to seek advice from the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) as to the appropriate course of action you should now take.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will contribute only briefly. We have just had another demonstration of the fact that hypocrisy knows no bounds when it comes from the Labor Party. Double standards—
—That's right. You know about that. Tell us what you are trying to cover up.
—Order!

—Just listen. Practically every allegation the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Faulkner) referred to today occurred under Labor's administration—when Labor held the books, when Labor controlled the purse strings and when the Minister for Administrative Services and the President of the Senate were Labor. What did Labor do about it? The only thing we know on the record is that, when there was one dispute under the then Minister for Administrative Services, the now Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, accepted a repayment and ended the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: So all of this occurred under Labor, and we did not hear a squeak from Labor. Yet Senator Faulkner comes in here today and says, `This is terrible, terrrible, terrible.' What credibility is there in his charges when Labor did nothing about it, year after year? No credibility at all. Labor only showed interest after Senator Colston left their party. Then he had to be punished and driven out of this parliament. Senator Robert Ray came in here and told the truth. He said that Senator Colston was treacherous and he must therefore be punished.
Senator Conroy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator, yes. No one on Labor's side must know that you can get away with leaving the Labor Party. Your past records will be searched and you will be pursued. And allegations in this place will not—

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There will be an opportunity for others to speak. There is no need to shout during Senator Hill's speech. Senator Faulkner was listened to.

—Allegations in this place will not be treated as allegations; they will be treated as proof. We have heard it all again today. Why do you think Senator Faulkner went through that whole range of charges? So that it is all printed in tomorrow morning's papers. So that there is further pressure on Senator Colston. Don't be embarrassed. You are seeking to hound him out of office because he left your party. You admitted it in here the other day, through Senator Robert Ray. He is the only one who has been prepared to be truthful about it.
—You bought him. You paid for him. You wear him.

—The other day you used the estimates committee as a Star Chamber. You made the charges and went through it. You did not seek proof, but just put charge after charge on the record, with the hope that it would stick. And it works. The more times it is said, the more times it is written—
—We want to see the report.
—We want to see the report.
—Senator Conroy and Senator Forshaw, you can have an opportunity to speak later.

—The more it is said, the more it leaves the impression that there must be substance to the charge. But what a wrong way to do business in this cowards' castle. If you were unhappy with Senator Colston's behaviour, you had years and years to do something about it. It is not easy—

BREAK.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! All senators will cease interjecting immediately. Senator Hill has the floor.
—In this business, it is not fair to draw adverse conclusions so automatically from the extent to which a senator travels.
—You are covering for him.
—It is not fair. People who live in Sydney and Melbourne travel to Canberra much more easily in a day than those from further states.
—Put the report on the table.

—Yet you are not worried about fairness in this matter; you are just concerned with persecution and treachery. You wish to hound him out of office. Madam President, I am astounded that this has all flowed today from your simply trying to determine what is fair in relation to Senator Colston answering certain allegations. I heard what you said: you wrote to him yesterday asking for further information. I have not seen either of the studies which are the basis for your letter, but they may be in conflict. Senator Faulkner says, `Why hasn't he answered the first one?' If you receive a request for further information, it is perfectly reasonable that he should be able to assess his position in the light of both reports. Madam President, in any other circumstances but this one, any step taken by you other than that which you have taken would draw howls about lack of natural justice from this opposition
—He is hanging around your neck.
—That is why this is just a horrible exhibition of hypocrisy on the part of the Labor Party.
—You are tainted by him.
—Senator Conroy, you are persistently interjecting.

—What you have done, Madam President, is perfectly sound and reasonable in the circumstances. You have said that justice should prevail. Justice is a two‐way street. If a charge or an allegation is made against somebody, they should have a reasonable opportunity to answer that. You have said that that is all that you have used to influence your position.

BREAK.PARA: You would not believe it. You have said that you require it in only a few days time. Yet, if you listen to the howls of outcry from the other side today, you would think that you have washed your hands of it. All you have said is that there are now two reports on which you require answers and you require them by next week. In all the circumstances that appears to be absolutely reasonable. Any other step would have been a breach of natural justice.

Madam President, although the Leader of the Opposition has sought to take advantage of your statement today to continue this political persecution of Senator Colston, I can tell you, provided you continue to operate fairly as it applies to all senators, you will certainly have our support on this matter or any other matter. I regret that the Labor Party has again stooped to this unprecedented low and that they have abused the privilege of this place again to pursue their internal party affairs. It does no credit to the Labor Party and, unfortunately and what is more important, it then does no credit to the parliamentary system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, by way of speaking to the motion to take note, I ask you whether you are able to give us an explanation of the general nature of the matter or the matters that you have referred to Senator Colston in a further report because I think this reflects on comments Senator Hill made about whether, in the interest of natural justice, Senator Colston was afforded further time because those matters may be linked. I need that clarification before I make further comments.

—There have been two reports prepared by the Department of the Senate, each of them with some cooperation and assistance from the Department of Administrative Services. I have referred them both to Senator Colston—one on 6 March and one yesterday—asking him to let me have comments on any matters in them he wishes to comment on. I have made the reports available to no other person but him. I have now asked that he respond in relation to both of them by next Monday.

—I do not think your remarks make it clear. Senator Hill has claimed that they may be linked and therefore the extension is appropriate. I do not think that helps. I wish to make the following comments. On the matter of the extension of time for response to the first report by Senator Colston, I regret that there will be a perception of political protection offered to Senator Colston so that the government and Senator Colston's vote are seen as being protected until we get to the end of next week and the end of this session. I believe that reflects most unfavourably on the government and the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Unless it can be demonstrated that the matters are linked, I think natural justice has been afforded Senator Colston in terms of the time that he has been given to respond to the first report. On the second matter, obviously you have taken the appropriate action. I regret that, in the absence of further information, such as whether the second report is about travelling allowances or Comcar use or whatever, I think it is impossible for us not to draw a conclusion that there is some kind of protection being offered.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going rise on this, but I want to speak on the motion to take note. I was interested in the comments just made by Senator Kernot. I do not know what Senator Kernot wants or whether she is suggesting that Senator Colston stand down until he—
—I didn't say anything—
—Maybe you did not mean that, but that is how it came across.
—Neville Wran did it.
—What happens if that occurs?
—I am not saying that.

—What happens in respect of a tied vote? If you want me to decide everything in this chamber then that is how you go about it. I would not have thought that that was very appropriate. If allegations have been made and if there are further matters that Senator Colston has been asked to comment upon—and presumably these matters are linked; that is what I get from the remarks by Senator Hill—then I believe it is not for us to act as a Star Chamber. Let the cards fall where they may.
—Stopped defending him now, have you?

—I have always said two things in respect of this matter. First of all, Senator Colston deserves to be judged according to how he performs his functions. I do not think there is any question that he performs his functions as Deputy President and Chairman of Committees in an admirable and an impartial way, which allows free and full debate in this chamber.
—That's not the issue.

—That is one issue. In respect of other matters, I have made no judgment about them at all. I agree with what Senator Hill has said that it is not fair to use a take note motion simply to turn this chamber into a Star Chamber. Let what Madam President has suggested be done.
—We're allowed to disagree with it.

—If you want to disagree with it, Senator Kernot, move an amendment. There is no amendment before the chamber. If you want to disagree with what the President has said, get up and disagree and move a substantive motion. Neither the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) nor you have done that. So what are you on about?
—I asked a question for clarification and I got no clarification.
—And I think you suggested then that you disagreed.
—What I am on about is having the report tabled as the President said she would. That is what I am on about.
—Yes, and I agree. She will do that on Monday, and I think that is an appropriate course to take.

BREAK.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly opposes any attempts by the Australian government to mine uranium at the Jabiluka and Koongara sites in the World Heritage Listed Area of the Kakadu National Park or any other proposed or current operating site.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any intentions by the Australian government to support the nuclear industry via any mining, enrichment and sale of uranium.

PETITION.TITLE: Head of State
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned expresses widespread community support for an Australian as Head of State for Australia.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate note and endorse the wishes expressed in this petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation will be forced to significantly reduce its services in Tasmania in order to meet the Budget cut of $65 million as announced by the Government.
Your Petitioners request the Senate to oppose the funding cuts proposed by the Government and to ensure that:
(a) the ABC can maintain its valuable communication and education services to Tasmania;
(b) ABC Launceston—the ABC's largest regional operation in Australia—can maintain its range of programming;
(c) the Launceston television crew—one of only three in regional Australia—is maintained;
(d) the future of the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra is maintained; and
(e) the Coalition's pre‐election promise of maintaining existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC is upheld.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Crowley, Sen Rosemary; Faulkner, Sen John
PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect, 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This Act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Crowley(from 75 citizens)and Senator Faulkner(from 84 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that only one group have been excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) where such group has performed honourable overseas `active service'. That group being members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 which were excluded under `Operational Service' at Section 6.(1)(e)(ii) of the Act.

The various claims made in Statements to the House and the Senate and the contents of correspondence from various Ministers to maintain the exclusion are answered as follows, the answers are from documents obtained under Freedom of Information Act and from the public record:

(i) `They were never allotted for operational service', (contained in a letter from the Hon. Con Sciacca Minister for Defence Science and Personnel 1995). A letter from the Secretary Department of the Navy to Treasury dated 11 November 1955 stated `the date that the Navy were allotted for operational service was 1 July 1955'.

(ii) `Members of the RAN were only doing the duty for which they had enlisted', (October 1956 The Hon. Dr Cameron representing the Minister for Repatriation). This applies to Service personnel everywhere.

(iii) `They were in no danger', (November 1956 The Hon. Dr Cameron representing the Minister for Repatriation in the Senate). They shared the same danger as all other Australian Service personnel serving in Malaya at the time.

(iv) `They were not on Special Overseas Service', (in a letter from the office of The Hon. Bronwyn Bishop Minister for Defence Industry Science and Personnel to Mrs Williams of Adelaide dated October 1996). Requirements for Special Overseas Service was introduced in 1962 without retrospective conditions, therefore has no relevance to events of 1960.

(v) `They were not on Active Service', (in a letter from the office of The Hon. Bronwyn Bishop Minister for Defence Industry Science and Personnel dated October 1996). It is now, as it was then, that Service Personnel had to comply with one of three requirements for Active Service, this group complied with two, or twice as many as is needed. The one that they did not comply with was, `is in military occupation of a foreign country'.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate should remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act, thereby giving the Australian sailors involved comparative recognition with the Army and RAAF personnel that served at the same time, and all other Australians who have served their Country on active service overseas.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned demand the Australian Government honour its commitment to the Higher Education sector as stated in the Liberal and National Parties' Higher Education Policy.

PETITION.TITLE: Euthanasia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned shows that we believe that the terminally ill should not be denied the right to choose voluntary euthanasia.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:

PARA.TAB: Oppose the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996 introduced by Kevin Andrews MP, which seeks to use constitutional powers to overturn the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995.
We also urge the introduction of legislation to legalise living wills/advance directives, the information to be registered on a national computer database.

PETITION.TITLE: Euthanasia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that euthanasia is the actual intervention by another to end a human life. It is neither curing nor a therapy. It destroys a human life.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to:
(a) recognise that euthanasia is not an issue which can be dealt with adequately by the States or Territories;
(b) listen to the public, doctors, health carers and religious organisations who are against euthanasia;
(c) legislate to prevent euthanasia being carried out in Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

AVIATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1997

The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Airports Act 1996 to provide certainty to new airport operators and existing airport tenants, and to ensure that the Commonwealth can exercise adequate regulatory control over leased airports.
Among other things, the Bill will amend the Airports Act 1996 to clarify some issues which are unclear and to empower required regulations. These include:
statutory requirements for an airport operator to use an airport site as an airport;
variable penalties for breaches of environmental standards;
to provide for new offences for deliberate harm to the environment;
powers to allow pre-existing contamination to be addressed; and
prohibition on sub-leasing to trusts.

Introduction and passage of the Bill in the Autumn sittings is essential to enable the Office of Assets Sales timetable for the leasing of three of Australia's major airports to be met and to maximise the return to the Commonwealth on those leases. Passage is therefore essential for the leasing process to continue as planned. Further, it will enable the finalisation of a comprehensive and appropriate regulatory regime for the airports which will ensure that the public interest is protected.

If the Bill is not dealt with in the Autumn sittings the leasing process for Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth airports will be delayed or the Commonwealth's regulatory regime will be compromised. The regulatory regime for leased airports may not be able to be finalised prior to leasing.

STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1997 AUTUMN SITTINGS
CORPORATIONS LAW AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PARA.EMPHASIS: Purpose

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Corporations Law Amendment Bill 1996 is to amend the Corporations Law in light of a decision of Cohen J of the New South Wales Supreme Court, In the matter of Crawford House and Corporations Law handed down on 13 June 1995 ('the Crawford House decision'). The amendments are intended to ensure that creditors who deal directly with a company trading under a deed of company arrangement will be able to make a claim against the company's assets for outstanding debts and liabilities should the company go into liquidation following termination of the deed

PARA.EMPHASIS: Reasons for Introduction and Passage in Current Autumn Sittings

SPEECH.PARA: The voluntary administration scheme contained in Part 5.3A of the Corporations Law provides for a regime which allows for companies to enter voluntary administration as an alternative to immediate liquidation. Under the regime, a company may cause an administrator to be appointed. The administrator takes control of the company's business and makes an assessment of the company's affairs. Within approximately one month of appointment, the administrator is required to make a recommendation to creditors about the future of the company.

Statistics from the Australian Securities Commission indicate that, on average, more than one hundred companies utilise the voluntary administration procedure every month. In a significant proportion of cases, the creditors resolved that the company should enter into a deed of company arrangement rather than be wound up immediately. The advantage of taking this course from a creditor's perspective is that if the company is allowed to continue operating its business, there is a likelihood that a better return to creditors would be obtained than in an immediate winding up. The mechanism also serves to avoid the costs and delays often associated with liquidations. Indeed, these considerations were behind the voluntary administration scheme being inserted in the Corporations Law in 1993 as recommended by the Australian Law Reform Commission.

In the Crawford House decision it was held that where a deed of company arrangement provides for the directors to be in control of the company, rather than the deed administrator, the debts incurred by the company while trading under a deed of company arrangement do not receive priority payment, nor are they provable in a winding up. The effect of the Crawford House decision is that creditors who deal directly with a company while it is trading under a deed of company arrangement have no claim whatsoever against the company's assets for their debts in the event that the company is would up following termination of the deed. Cohen J remarked that this is not a result that could have been intended by the legislature. His Honour therefore called for urgent legislative amendment.

In the wake of the decision, there were calls for urgent amendment from a number of concerned parties including the Insolvency Practitioners' Association of Australia, the Australian Securities Commission and legal practitioners. Also, the Australian Taxation Office has been significantly adversely affected by the decision. If the law as determined in the Crawford House decision is allowed to stand, the confidence of creditors in deeds of company arrangement is likely to be undermined and the viability of the voluntary administration regime could be jeopardised.

In the period since the Crawford House decision was handed down, liquidators and their advisers have been in an invidious position because, unless they have been able to defer finalisation of the administration pending the commencement of an amendment, they would have been obliged to act in accordance with the law as stated in Crawford House, which is patently unfair to post-deed creditors.

The prospect of an imminent amendment to correct the anomaly was publicised in law journals and other publications following the introduction of a bill addressing the issue in October 1995 and this may have encouraged liquidators to defer finalising administrations. However, unless an appropriate amendment is passed soon, liquidators will be forced to make distributions ignoring the claims of past-deed creditors. This extremely undesirable outcome would be very difficult to correct, even by way of retrospective legislation, since it would be impracticable to provide for the "unwinding" of administrations, perhaps involving very large numbers of creditors, once they have been finalised. Accordingly, it is highly desirable that an amendment addressing the Crawford House decision is proceeded with as soon as possible.

The Law Council of Australia and the Insolvency Practitioners Association of Australia have expressed their support for the approach taken in the Bill and have urged the Government to secure passage as soon as possible.
Circulated by the Authority of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer

EXPORT FINANCE AND INSURANCE CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL
The Export Finance and Insurance Corporation Act 1991 (the Act) was enacted to establish the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC) as a statutory authority.

Under the Act, a function of the Corporation is to manage Development Import Finance Facility (DIFF) monies made available by AusAID to overseas buyers of Australian exports. The liabilities associated with these loans currently reside with EFIC.

As announced in the 1996-97 Budget, the Government has decided to transfer these liabilities from EFIC's Commercial Account to the Government's National Interest Account. As the current National Interest provisions of the Act do not provide for acceptance of these liabilities it is necessary to introduce an amendment to give effect to the Government's decision.

The Government's decision also called for an associated payment by EFIC to the Commonwealth, representing a portion of the capital which EFIC holds against the liabilities for these loans. Again, there is no provision in the Act for such a transfer to take place.
The amendments need to proceed in the Autumn sittings so that this payment may be made in the 1997-98 financial year, as announced in the Budget papers.
This statement is circulated with the authority of the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism

I seek leave to make a short statement about the committee's concerns with this legislation.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee's concerns with these instruments include possible prejudicial retrospectivity, reversal of the usual onus of proof, strict liability offences, removal of rights without explanation, administrative decisions which may not be subject to external review of their merits, lack of a protective safeguard, discretionary and subjective provisions and no indication whether appropriate consultation was undertaken. Madam President, as usual, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short summary of the matters raised by the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The summary read as follows —

PARA.EMPHASIS: Actuarial Standard for Cost of Investment Performance Guarantees
Actuarial Standard for Paid Up Values and Surrender Values
made under s.101 of the Life Insurance Act 1995

SPEECH.PARA: The Standards provide for the calculation of paid up values, minimum surrender values and the cost of investment performance guarantees for the purposes of the enabling Act.

Although the Standards apply in respect of calculations made on or after 31 December 1996, they were not gazetted until 22 January 1997. The committee has written to the minister asking whether the Standards are void because of apparent prejudicially retrospective operation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Childcare Assistant (Fee Relief) Guidelines (Variation) No. CCA/12A/97/1 made under s.12A(1) of the Child Care Act 1972

SPEECH.PARA: The Guidelines limit childcare assistance to 50 hours per week, except in special circumstances relating to work commitments.

Subclause 18(3) sets out several situations under which the 50 hours limit may be exceeded. With one exception, it is not clear who would make a decision on whether circumstances came within the Guidelines or what would happen if there were disputes about the facts. The committee has written to the minister about the right of review of these decisions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Federal Airports (Amendment) By-Laws No 1 of 1997 made under s.72 of the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986

SPEECH.PARA: The By‐laws establish a series of public order offences.

New By‐law 15J.1 provides that a person who, without reasonable excuse, proof of which lies on the person, commits a specified offence at a Federal airport, is guilty of an offence punishable by a fine of up to $500. This is a reversal of the usual onus of proof and the committee has written to the minister asking for reasons for this provision.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Life Insurance Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1996 No 305

SPEECH.PARA: The Regulations provide for the publication of information about unclaimed moneys.

Regulation 10.05B provides that the Commissioner may publish any information relating to unclaimed moneys. The Explanatory Statement advises that in the absence of r.10.05B, disclosure of the information may breach Information Privacy Principle 11 provided for by s.14 of the Privacy Act 1988. The committee has written to the minister seeking advice on whether the Privacy Commissioner was consulted before the Regulations were made.

PARA.EMPHASIS: National Crime Authority Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1996 No 286

SPEECH.PARA: The Regulations provide for new forms of search warrant.

One such warrant authorises the use of only such force as may be reasonably necessary in carrying out the warrant. However, another new warrant does not appear to include this protective safeguard. The committee has written to the minister seeking advice on the reasons for excluding this provision.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Mining Legislation (Amendment) Ordinance 1996
Territory of Christmas Island Ordinance No 10 of 1996
Mining Legislation (Amendment) Ordinance 1996
Territory of Cocos (Keeling) Islands Ordinance No 8 of 1996

SPEECH.PARA: The Ordinances amend the principal mining laws to change the terms of leases and royalties.

The Ordinances replace the right to renew certain mining tenements for a further 21 years with a term of renewal as determined by the minister. The Explanatory Statements also advise that the minister may vary the scheduled rates of royalties. These amendments appear to be a major removal of rights. The committee has written to the minister about reasons for the change and whether there is a right of review of the minister's decisions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) (National Standards) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1996 No 288

SPEECH.PARA: Among other things, the Regulations provide for exemptions from occupational health and safety standards.

The Regulations provide for review of some adverse decisions but not others. They also provide for the minister to take action, which would adversely affect a person, without prior notification or consultation. The committee has written to the minister.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Management of Safety on Offshore Facilities) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1996 No 298

SPEECH.PARA: The Regulations provide for safety on offshore petroleum facilities principally through the operation of a Safety Case regime.

Regulation 38 provides that offences, other than those under one specified Division of the Regulations, are offences of strict liability. Also subregulation 39(1) provides that a person is not liable to be punished more than once for the same act or omission. However, r.39(2) does not prevent a person being punished for two or more offences if the same act or omission is a common element of each offence. The committee has written to the minister seeking an explanation for the need for strict liability offences and of the operation of r.39, which may breach personal rights.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Radiocommunications (Compliance Labelling—Incidental Emissions) Notice Statutory Rules 1996 No 294

SPEECH.PARA: The Notice provides for the fixing of labels to electrical and electronic devices.

Clause 4 provides for the Spectrum Management Authority to appoint bodies which will access whether a device complies with a standard. As these decisions appear to affect a commercially valuable right, the committee has written to the minister asking for advice on review of any adverse decisions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Road Transport Reform (Mass and Loading) Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1996 No 342

SPEECH.PARA: The Regulations require buses to comply with certain specifications in the Australian Design Rules.

Subregulation 13(2) confers a discretion on the vehicle registration authority to declare a bus to be a complying bus, if satisfied that it complies with specified ADRs. As these two discretions appear to be of considerable commercial value, the committee has written to the minister asking whether the discretions will be subject to independent review.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Workplace Relations Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1996 No 328

SPEECH.PARA: The Regulations provide for withdrawal from amalgamated organisations.

Subregulation 98O(2) provides that members of an amalgamated organisation or any other persons authorised by the electoral official may inspect or take copies of the roll of voters. It may be more appropriate, however, for the roll to be open to public inspection.
A number of provisions use the permissive `may' when it may have been intended and appropriate to use the mandatory `must', used in similar provisions.
A number of provisions provide for action to be taken without the usual safeguard, included in similar provisions, that the action be `reasonable'.
The committee has written to the minister for advice.

The statement read as follows—
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1997 AUTUMN SITTINGS

PARA.EMPHASIS: Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 is to make amendments to various Acts that are consequential on the passage of the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency Bill 1996 and the establishment by that bill of the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency.

In particular, the bill is intended to make amendments to the Social Security Act 1991, the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973, the Data Matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990 and other Commonwealth Acts, to reflect the fact that the responsibility of the Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs for delivering various Commonwealth Government programs and services will be taken up by the new Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency, to be created by the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency Bill 1996.

The Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency Bill 1996 was introduced into the House of Representatives on 4 December 1996. It is intended to commence on 1 July 1997. It is therefore essential that the necessary consequential amendments also be made in time to commence on that date. Further, it is both desirable and logical that the consequential amendments to be able to be considered by the Parliament at the same time as the "parent" bill.
This statement is circulated with the Authority of the Minister for Social Security

PARA.EMPHASIS: The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: TABLING STATEMENT
THE HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION AND THE COMMONWEALTH OMBUDSMAN
REPORT ON PUBLIC SEMINARS 20 AND 25 SEPTEMBER 1996

[Madam President] I have pleasure in presenting the report by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on two public seminars held in Canberra last September in relation to the work of the Human Rights and Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (HREOC), and the office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman, which together deal with international and domestic issues relating to human rights. HREOC is a statutory body responsible for ensuring Australia's compliance with, and implementation of, international human rights treaties and conventions. The Commonwealth Ombudsman has a more domestic focus on the everyday human rights of citizens in their dealings with government agencies. The office of the Ombudsman is established within the Prime Minister and Cabinet portfolio.

Through its Human Rights Sub-Committee, the Joint Standing Committee has adopted the practice of meeting on an annual basis with the heads and senior office-holders of both statutory offices. The purpose of conducting the two public seminars was to keep the Committee up to date on current work programs, challenges and future directions being planned for the Commonwealth Ombudsman's office and the Human Rights Commissioner.

The report presented today examines issues of concern to each particular office, as well as a shared concern about racism and the human rights of indigenous Australians. There are five recommendations in the report. Two of them relate to the implementation of the International Convention on the Rights of the Child and HREOC's major concerns for the children of Australia, particularly the welfare, care and protection system, and the treatment of children in the family law and juvenile justice systems. The Committee shares these concerns, and was most disappointed that no specific Act of Parliament has yet been passed to implement the Convention on the Rights of the Child nor, I should add, the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights. Back in 1994, ie Committee's report on the Review of Australia's Efforts to Promote and Protect Human Rights highlighted the plight of abused children both internationally and in Australia. At that time, criticisms of the youth welfare and justice systems in Australia, and youth homelessness were drawn to the attention of the Parliament. Those warnings are even more timely today than they were in 1994.

Accordingly, the Committee recommends that the Australian Government introduce legislation to incorporate the International Convention on the Rights of the Child into domestic law, and recommends also that the Attorney-General investigate the feasibility of establishing a Children's Commissioner within the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

Within the time constraints imposed by only two short meetings, the seminars could not cover in great detail all areas of concern. However, in addition to the issues to which I have already referred, the report mentions several other important areas of concern to the Committee: for example, the rights of refugees in detention, the rights of women in Australia and in the region, and the right of transgender people.

Of the issues specific to the Ombudsman the Committee made particular note of the independent statutory role of the office which reports direct to Parliament, notwithstanding the fact that it is established within the portfolio of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. As highlighted by the Ombudsman in her annual report for l995-96, and reiterated during the seminar, this situation has given rise to funding constraints during budget considerations for the portfolio. One of the proposals put forward to the Government by the Ombudsman was for the status of an Officer of the Parliament to be applied to the Ombudsman, thereby guaranteeing its independent operation in terms of administrative arrangements such as budget allocation.

The Committee believes there is merit in strengthening the office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman, and has recommended that the Government expedite the necessary changes to jurisdiction and funding arrangements proposed in the Ombudsman's annual report. As well, the Committee has recommended that a parliamentary review of the office be conducted in order to examine the resources available to the Ombudsman, the mechanisms for ensuring its independence from any specific portfolio, and the desirability of giving the Ombudsman the status of an independent officer of the Parliament.

A shared concern which the Committee highlighted in the report relates to the problem of racism in Australia and the difficulties faced by indigenous Australians in gaining access to services. Both HREOC and the Ombudsman have to confront racism as a significant issue raised in complaints, and clearly recognise the need for continuing support for indigenous people in the areas of health, employment, housing, education and welfare services in particular.

The Ombudsman emphasised the special needs of indigenous people and the disadvantages which need to be addressed on their behalf. Both HREOC and the Ombudsman were critical of the limited access that indigenous people are able to gain to services provided for all Australians by DSS and DEETYA, for example. These difficulties were the result of the particular needs of indigenous people and the barriers erected by the current administrative arrangements for delivery of services, which can be quite complex. In the Committees view, one solution would be to fund a position within the Ombudsman's office to cater for the special needs of indigenous Australians, and the report recommends that the Government consider that option.

The final observation by the Committee as a result of the seminars was that the role of both EREOC and the Ombudsman is being undermined by budgetary pressures, and the Committee foresees serious consequences if the workloads of each office continue to increase while funding and other support mechanisms are reduced.

Madam President I would like to conclude by thanking all involved in the seminars for their contributions—Sir Ronald Wilson, President of HREOC, Mr Chris Sidoti, Human Rights Commissioner, and the Senior Adviser to the Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Kieren Fitzpatrick, and the Commonwealth Ombudsman, Ms Philippa Smith—who gave their time to attend and to inform the Committee about their work I would also like to thank the members of the Committee who were able to attend the seminars and the staff of the Joint Standing Committee, in particular, Margaret Swie ringa and the staff of the Human Rights Sub-Committee who organised a very successful seminar program and drafted the report.
I commend the report to the Senate.
