DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Cook, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Regulations (Amendment), as contained in statutory rules 1996 No. 277 and made under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, be disallowed.

In speaking to that motion, firstly, I would like to draw the attention of the Senate to the report of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority for 1995-96. In that report the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority noted as its goals and aims, among other things, `to involve the community meaningfully in the care and development of the marine park,' and further down, `to minimise costs of caring for and developing the marine park consistent with meeting the goals and other aims of the authority'. Quite clearly, the extra charge that has been put in place through the regulations is an impost and is totally at odds with those particular goals which I read out, along with the other goals of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority—GBRMPA.

This is quite clearly a broken promise of the Howard government—one more of their broken promises. Of course, it flies in the face of what they told the tourist industry on 13 February 1996 in the lead-up to the election held last year. A document circulated by the Far North Queensland Promotion Bureau of Australia has an extract of that promise which was made by the coalition at that stage. It reads:
The Coalition in Government will honour its long-term promise to this industry of no new taxes and no increases in existing taxes on this industry and its service industries.
So it is quite clear, quite unequivocal, that the promise made to the tourist industry in Cairns was that there would be no new charges, no new taxes. The extract further states:
The Coalition will not be introducing any new taxes or increasing any existing taxes on the tourism industry.
. No New Taxes or Tax Increases.

PARA.TAB: ‐ that is an unequivocal commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: We know how far that commitment went. It did not last very long at all. No sooner were the coalition in government than we in the Queensland tourist industry found ourselves confronted with another tax, a new tax, an increased tax—in this case a fivefold increase in the tax on the tourist industry. This tax was not well received by the tourist industry at all—far from it. There was total revulsion at what the government had done. There had been no consultation. As a consequence, the government found themselves in a sticky situation. They found themselves in a lot of trouble.

Of course, this belies what they had done when the environment management charge was originally introduced back in 1993. It is worth while looking at what was said by some of the speakers from the other side in the speeches in the second reading debates that took place in both the House of Representatives and in this chamber. I refer firstly to what Mr Jull, the member for Fadden, had to say at page 868 of the Hansard on 13 May 1993 about the introduction of the then environment management charge:
We hope that those operators will get a sympathetic hearing from this government—
meaning the then Labor government—
about any future charges. While the principle of user pays is a good one, we must ensure that we do not overcrowd the industry with charges to the extent that we become non-competitive.
In the same debate on the same day at page 869, Mr Miles, the member for Braddon, said:

If we are going to raise moneys to support our world heritage areas in a piecemeal fashion, the administrative costs involved will probably outweigh the benefits. I suggest to both sides of the House that it might be better to raise those moneys through general revenue rather than continuing with the present piecemeal approach, such as we are seeing here, of adding a dollar to fares and so on. I am sure that the administrative costs involved for the operators and the overall administration—the government and departmental structures—far outweigh the benefit of a $1 increase. Furthermore, I do not see it staying at $1.

What prophetic words from a person speaking at the introduction of a $1 charge back in 1993. Whilst opposing that charge he said that he could not see that charge remaining at $1. Of course, the prophecy has been fulfilled. Mr Miles went on to say:
No doubt it will rise, and rise rapidly. That will be just the start of it—the thin edge of the wedge. We need to think more carefully about how we fund our world heritage areas.
When we turn to the second reading debate that took place in this Senate, we get to the real gems. Senator Ian Macdonald, at page 1309 of the Hansard of 26 May 1993 says:
The industry is concerned that it is the thin edge of the wedge: $1 today, $5 tomorrow.

How the coalition must have had a crystal ball in those days to see that they would be in government and that they would be the perpetrators of not raising it from $1 to $5, but raising it to $6. Senator Ian Macdonald went on to say in the second reading debate:
. . . It is something that we will watch very closely, as the tourist operators and many other people, including myself, have very real fears that this will not be so easy.
Further on in the transcript he says:

. . . I will certainly be joining other members of the Liberal and National parties in monitoring the situation and the regulations as they come through. We will do so to ensure that the tax which is being introduced now is not the thin edge of the wedge; that it stops where it says it will; and that it is not used by this Government—
meaning the then Labor government—

as a crutch to enable it to stop funding the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. Rather than the Government using Consolidated Revenue to fund what is a very important research and maintenance agency which protects one of Australia's greatest assets, funding in the future should be by way of an increase in the tax.

I cite those three instances because that is what this debate is about today. When in opposition the now government were vehemently opposed to the imposition of the first $1, which was an environment management charge. I will come to that in a few moments.

Then they went on to say that they thought it was the thin edge of the wedge and that, as the thin edge of the wedge, it was something that should be looked out for and that one should look out for the regulations. So we have the disallowance motion here today seeking the disallowance of the increased charges that have been imposed unfairly on the tourist industry by this government.

One only has to look at how they have hurt the tourist operators in that area. I quote from a letter sent to me by Tusa Dive, one of the operators in the Cairns region, referring to the announcement by the government of the increased tax in the budget last year. It says:

The only alternative presented to us is to absorb the charge into our existing rates, which, as a small operator, with competitive rates based on marginal profitability, may potentially send Tusa Dive Charters to the wall.
It goes on to say:

On the second point of concern over the lack of consultation to arrive at this decision to increase the Reef Tax, we consider this action to be an act of betrayal of trust on the part of the Federal Government. The Prime Minister, John Howard had stated previously this year—
that is, 1996—
that there would be no increases or new charges.

Here we have, quite clearly, not a big operator but a small operator who has suffered at the hands of the government after they clearly spelt out in their election promise that there would be no increase in charges.
Further, I quote from a letter from Mr Blue Bulling, the chair of the Cairns Regional Marine Resources Advisory Committee. He says:

. . . There was disbelief, obvious disgust and distress that a 500% increase could be levied with no regard for the consultative mechanisms which have been painstakingly developed and proven efficient over the past two years. Members are truly terrified of the potential to broaden this precedence and the potential impacts that such political decisions will cause.

This political decision is seriously threatening and has jeopardised an enormous amount of hard won good will and future potential for community/government relations. It is not the act of a responsible political party within a democracy. It is a grave error and must be quickly revisited and dealt with through a process of consultation and resolution within the existing structures if damage is to be mitigated.

Following on from that, the government did set about trying to retrieve the position. They tried to save themselves from a fate worse than death—that is, a complete revolt by the tourist operators in North Queensland. What they came up with in the end was not satisfactory to the needs of the tourist operators.

There is one thing that this government have never understood—that the environment management charge was never meant to be something by which the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority was funded. It was always designed to be something which operated as a research facility for the cooperative research centre of the Great Barrier Reef. Seventy-five per cent of what was collected out of those dollars was to go to research; 25 per cent was always destined to go to GBRMPA as a management charge for their collection of the fee.

The government have now turned that around and are trying to use whatever they can get out of this charge and whatever they can get out of the additional tourist visitor charge. What they are trying to do with that is fund the operations of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, which it was never designed to do under any circumstances.

They have dropped the increase from $1 to $6 back to $1 to $2. They may feel that that is some comfort for the tourist operators, but it is quite the opposite. In its place, whilst they have dropped the environment management charge from $6 now back to $2, they have put a $4 tourist visitor impost on users of commercial facilities and craft in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. Surprise, surprise, the tourist operators are still upset. No wonder, because this impost is something which will affect their livelihood, their ability to operate and their ability to attract people into the tourist area.

On 26 November last year, a motion was passed in this chamber referring the issue of heritage access fees in general to the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee. This is the matter that was referred at that time:

The question of balancing public access with the principle of "user pays" in order to defray the public costs of maintaining natural and cultural heritage assets such as national parks and museums with particular consideration to issues of fairness and equity.

That inquiry is proceeding and has not concluded at this stage, and of course one does not really know what that committee will find. What we are faced with here is a premature action on the part of the government in pursuing the increase in the environmental management charge from $1 up to $2. The tourist operators say that this increased charge will impact on them. This was brought out in recent correspondence that I have from the Tourism Council of Australia. It is interesting to see how they view the charge that has been imposted on the industry by the current government. I will quote in part from that letter:
TCA would like to take this opportunity to outline this policy—a "user pays" approach should be transparent and should only apply where:
‐ all users/beneficiaries can be identified,
‐ the charge can be applied fairly to all users,
‐ revenue collected is entirely hypothecated to the delivery of goods and services,
‐ there is appropriate advance consultation with the businesses affected and there is an appropriate lead time for the introduction of changes to the charge.
The action taken on 20 August—
that is in 1996—
does not meet any of the previously agreed criteria.
Further on they say:

The imposition of an additional cost at such short notice, just 4 months notice, puts operators in a most difficult position. Contracts with wholesalers are quoted and signed quite a long way in advance i.e. around 18 months.
They then go on to cite how far out some of the contracts that they have with travel agents go. The Tourism Council of Australia goes on to say at page 3 of this letter:

This would seem to confirm the industry's worst fears that the Government merely intends to direct the monies into consolidated revenue or at best use the funds as a replacement/substitute for the Government funding the administration of GBRMPA—again the agreement has been dishonoured.
In addition, the EMC will not be per visitor per day as suggested in the Budget papers but in reality is per visitor per activity.

I have pointed that during other debates in this place, and that has just been like water on the duck's back to this government. As this letter rightly points out, the more activities you undertake on the reef, the more charges you will be confronted with. Then the council goes on to say:

The tourism industry has contended for a number of years, that all users of the Park can be readily identified and should be subject to the EMC, however, there has been no attempt to ensure that the Charge is fairly applied to all "users".

That is the very thing that the heritage access inquiry under the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee is trying to establish—the very thing. Yet here we have the government pursuing a charge which the operators on the reef quite clearly do not want any part of because they know it will only serve to damage them.

It is worth while looking at the Hansard of the Queensland parliament of 13 September 1996. At page 2900 Ms Warwick, the member for Barron River—coincidentally, an area that would have close affinity to the tourist industry and the problems suffered by the increases in the reef tax—directed a question to the Minister for Tourism, Small Business and Industry, Mr Davidson. The question basically asked who will be affected by the proposed increase in the environmental management charge. It was interesting that, during the response, the Queensland minister referred to a letter that had been sent to both the Hon. John Moore and Senator Robert Hill which stated:

The planned increase, combined with a 3% per cent reduction in Federal funding to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, seems to suggest the Federal Government is neglecting part of its responsibility and shifting the onus for the management of the Marine Park further towards the tourism operators in Queensland.

That is precisely what the tourism operators are saying. It is the precise reason why this particular increase in charges should be disallowed here in this chamber this afternoon. This is not something put forward by my side of politics but by their own side in the Queensland government. The other matter which concerns me greatly is the impact on jobs in that area. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am presuming the Australian Democrats and the Greens will be supporting us in this motion because they have been demanding an increase in user fees for our natural resources. But it is astonishing what a few feet make. On this side of the chamber the ALP introduced and defended an environmental management charge for the Great Barrier Reef. On the other side they condemn it. They talk about it now—to quote Senator Hogg—as an `impost' at odds with the GBRMPA goals.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not remember hearing any of that in 1993 when the Labor Party believed that it was a fair contribution towards the costs of research and maintenance of the reef. Certainly, 75 per cent of the $1 charge was to go to the CRC for research, but nobody seriously suggested that the other 25 per cent was what it cost to collect the money because in fact the collection is carried out by the commercial users. Therefore, the cost to GBRMPA is very slight indeed.

What happened to the 25 per cent was that it went towards GBRMPA's operating charges. I suggest to the Senate this afternoon that that is totally reasonable because what we are faced with is the challenge of the maintenance of a vitally important environmental resource which is subject to ever growing commercial pressure. The area of greatest growth has been in relation to tourism. The type of growth and therefore the type of inroads into and pressure on the reef is very different from what was once envisaged. Now there are modern vessels and very large numbers of tourists being able to be moved to outer reefs in a short period of time.

The responsibility therefore of the management authority, GBRMPA, has grown enormously. It has a responsibility on behalf of government to ensure that this valid use of the reef for commercial advantage nevertheless remains within an environmentally responsive wavelength; in other words, that whilst tourism grows it operates in a way that does not put undue pressure on a very important natural environment resource.

It does cost a lot of money. GBRMPA costs the taxpayers as a whole about $14.75 million a year and it gets an extra million dollars from industry. So it is nearly up to $16 million a year in its costs. What does this contribution from commercial operators, calculated on the basis of individual usage, contribute? At the moment it is about $1.2 million. This regulation, if it is allowed to stand today, would contribute for this year 1996‐97 a further $750,000 and for 1997‐98 it would contribute an extra $1.5 million. But it remains a very small proportion of the total management cost.

The trend everywhere now is to look for a fairer share of the financial burden of maintaining our natural environmental assets between the taxpayers at large and the particular users—commercial, recreational or whatever they may be. It has not been the case in the past. Australia has been a little different from much of the world in that we have in the past basically accepted that that burden should fall totally upon taxpayers as a whole. It is now recognised that that is not the fairest way to approach these things; that those who gain the pleasure or the commercial advantage, but who as a result put direct extra pressure on those environmental assets, should be prepared to pay a bit as well.

That is all we are seeking from this regulation. What this regulation predominantly does is increase the charge from $1 to $2. I remind you that the vast majority of these visitors are those who take trips to the outer reef from Cairns or Port Douglas and who are paying $120 or $130 for the pleasure of doing so. What the government is saying is that $2 towards the cost of maintaining the reef, which is only a small proportion of the total cost, is more than reasonable.

It is only a party in opposition, I might say, that would have the nerve to come in here and try to argue that that is unreasonable. A fee of $2 compared with what is being charged in other parks protecting natural environmental assets is also particularly low. Those who have the privilege and the pleasure of entering Uluru or Kakadu, for example, pay an entry fee of $15. If you enter the Kosciusko National Park you pay $12. That is per car. If there is more than one person in the car the fee still remains at $12, so if there are two people in the car the cost is $6 a head, three times the fee that we are propos ing in relation to the Great Barrier Reef. One could go on. It is an aim of government to find a fairer mix of meeting this financial responsibility. We strongly argue that $2 is more than reasonable.

As Senator Hogg said, eventually we want a fee of $6 but the balance of $4 will be subject to a separate regulation later this year and I suspect will be subject to a further motion of disallowance. That debate will be had at a later date. But this debate is simply about increasing the fee from $1 to $2. It is predominantly about that; there are some extra fees for other commercial uses which have been doubled as well. But they are a small percentage of the total part of the revenue of $1.5 million in a full year. What has been said in the past about the direction that we are taking? We thought it was interesting to note the advice we have just received from the House of Representatives in its examination of world heritage areas and their maintenance. It said:

A convincing argument can be made for charging those who benefit most from world heritage areas, either financially or as visitors. It is argued that, while Australian taxpayers as a whole contribute through government funding to world heritage management, those who reap special rewards from the areas by earning a living from tourism or through their experiences while visiting the areas should make an additional financial contribution.
That is from page 169 of the report. It went on to say:
The committee considers that where it is feasible to collect fees, they should be more than a token amount.

That is on page 183 of the report. So even the House of Representatives seems to recognise that this is a sensible direction to take. And so have others. It was interesting, when I was thumbing through the records, to note that the Leader of the Opposition in this place, Senator Faulkner, seemed to have had a different view on these things when he was environment minister. Speaking of a user pays fee, as reported in the Australian of 19 May 1994, he said:
I can't shy away from the need to have a look at—
that is, the fee—
. . . the pressures from the number of tourists going to those World Heritage areas is going to be enormous and we have a responsibility to protect their values.
So it is not surprising that he is not participating in the debate.

I have to say in passing that I am a bit disappointed in Senator Cook, too. Having giving this notice, he has decided that it is not worthy of support by leading the debate, but I guess he has other priorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's not a Queenslander.

—But there is a principle that goes beyond Queensland here, I suggest, Senator Hogg. Having quoted one former Labor environment minister, just to make your day more miserable, Senator Hogg, I draw to your attention some comments by Barry Cohen, who was a previous national environment minister—quite a good one, I might say—from 1983 to 1987. As reported in the Australian of 11 September 1996, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Great Barrier Reef is Australia's greatest environmental treasure. The burden for protecting it is borne by all Australian taxpayers. Gradually a larger part of that burden must be shifted to those who most enjoy it—those who visit the reef.

All we are seeking to do today is to move a small portion of the burden across to those who gain particular pleasure or commercial benefit from the reef. I put it to the Senate that that is more than reasonable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —This disallowance motion has been a very difficult one for us to assess because there are many arguments on both sides. Labor are moving to disallow the reef tax regulation. They are seeking to capitalise on very strong industry and North Queensland reaction which apparently is causing considerable disaffection in the ranks of North Queensland backbenchers, particularly those from the National Party.

SPEECH.PARA: These allowances particularly affect the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, but it must be remembered that that is not an authority which is universally loved. It has been attacked by coalition politicians and by sections of the tourism industry.

The allowances affect the environmental management charge, also known as the reef tax. With the original increase, as Senator Hill has said, the amount of revenue raised from the EMC was to go from $1.5 million in 1995‐96 to $8 million in 1996-97. The government's intention was to raise the EMC from $1 to $6 and to reduce the budget of the GBRMPA so that the net budget outcome was nearly even. Under that budget, the authority's appropriation was to be reduced by almost $6 million, from $15 million to $10.6 million. Therefore, the net budget outcome for the authority was to be just $0.28 million net and, according to well placed sources, most of this would go to collection activities.

After strong political and local Queensland reaction, the government decided to introduce a two-part tax. The EMC was to go from $1 to $2 from 1 January 1997 and a $4 tourist visitor charge was to be levied from 1 January 1998. The supplementary budget does have provision to make up for the shortfall in the authority's funding, but the overall decrease will be 3.2 per cent for 1996-97.

The tourism industry appears to accept user pays as a principle. I do not, as a general principle, and I regret that they do. They are strongly opposed to a two-part tax. They are strongly opposed to a significant increase in tax. They are strongly opposed to acting as tax collectors. They are opposed to the retrospective aspects of the tax, since some groups are already booked two years hence. And they are strongly opposed to the cumulative effect of the increased charges on families and regular users of the reef.

The levy on commercial facilities and craft is particularly unpopular, even if Senator Hill chooses to say it is a minor part of the appropriation. It is a minor but very hurtful part. These charges as a disallowable instrument cannot be amended. They can only be thrown out. That is the problem facing us and that is why I suspect both the opposition and ourselves have had particular difficulty with the package that is before us.

The two most recent thorough reviews have together recommended an increase of some $3.5 million per year for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to allow it to fulfil its responsibilities. The government policy would result in a classic situation of conflict of interest. We in Western Australia are particularly familiar with that. Our own department of CALM—which I refer to as `Genghis Calm'—is both an exploiter, or a beneficiary of exploitation, and the regulator manager. That is what the authority is being pushed towards—a CALM type arrangement. It is clear that governments in this country, and it seems in many countries, are trying to divert management and management authorities away from protection and towards exploitation, and towards being dependent upon the very exploitations that they are there to regulate and correct.

The Australian Democrats have the following feelings about these charges. We condemn the government for reducing the core budget funding to the authority. We actually think the authority needs more funding, not less, to do a very substantial job in a very important area. We would like to push not just for the maintenance of existing budget but for an increase in line with the review recommendations which, as I mentioned earlier, amount to at least $3.5 million more being needed. We condemn the government for attempting to increasingly link the authority's financial and operational viability to tourist income. Any user charge should supplement the authority and not affect its core appropriations and operations.

We support the Labor Party's disallowance motion on the basis that the move to a reliance on a user‐pays charge is bad policy for this particular national and world facility. You cannot just accept user pays as a principle which applies in every case. Sometimes certainly it is appropriate, and the Democrats would accept that in certain parts and certain instances, but not in this instance. That great world marine park facility needs a fearlessly independent, well-funded Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. That means government funding, not funding by tourists.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens will not be supporting the disallowance motion. From consultation with conservation groups in Queensland, we believe on balance that it is in the interests of the Great Barrier Reef to support the in creased charge for the environmental management by commercial tourist operators on the reef from $1, which was struck by the Labor government four years ago, to $2.

SPEECH.PARA: We reserve our judgment on the further $4 so-called tourist visitor charge, or tax. The Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) is going to have to provide a good explanation as to how that is going to be hypothecated to the protection and management of the reef and not be a substitute for a diminution in government funding for those functions before he gets our support on this.

The Greens do not support the principle that user pays should be the only means or the principal means by which to fund our great heritage assets in this country. We do not support the idea that commercial operators who are profiting from those assets, which are the property of the people of Australia as a whole, not make a specific contribution to the upkeep. After all, they form part of the management and protection of the reef.

I suggest to the government that it look at the way in which this tax is levied. The tax does not discriminate between the small operator, the low fee collector, and the big wealthy operator who is charging big fees to richer clientele. It needs to be tailored to that direction. Those people who are profiting most, who have the clientele who use the reef in a way the average person would not, ought to be paying proportionately. That is, this tax ought to relate to the amount of money that the commercial operators are charging the clientele for using the reef.

I reiterate that the Greens support this levy increase because we are concerned about the Barrier Reef. But, if the government wants support for the further tax, it does not have it as I stand here. It is going to have to show that the tax is not a substitute for a withdrawal of public funding.

I have been unable to get the exact figures on reduction in public funding through government revenues for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. The government will not get further support unless it can do better so far as we Greens are concerned. Our basic line in all such difficult matters is this: what is good for heritage itself; what is good for the Barrier Reef?

We are not going to allow ourselves to be drawn into a process of saying that it does not matter who the operator is or how rich it is or how much Keith Williams is going to make from his damaging and destructive operation in the Hinchinbrook Channel with the 200‐plus high‐speed motor boats operating there which threaten the dugongs and the rest of the environment of that place, and that we will not collect any revenue from him and his operations.

That obnoxious development ought not to be proceeding. But, seeing as the government has given it the go‐ahead, against the interests of both the wet tropics world heritage area and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park world heritage area, there ought to be money coming from that wealthy businessman, who is profiting improperly and unnecessarily from these magnificent world heritage areas, to put towards assuaging some of the damage which he and his supporters are going to wreak upon these fragile and magnificent wild places.

It is important that we ensure the public has access to these places without being put under an undue impost. Also, it is important that the heritage areas are adequately funded. I put a challenge to the minister that, if he expects further support, he come up with a better explanation than he has given so far for the flagged $4 tax to the tourist industry in Queensland and that he come up with a better way of imposing such a tax—

TALK.START.PARA: —Surcharge.

—`Tax' is the word—to ensure that the likes of Keith Williams and co pay a fair share for their damage and contribute to the environmental welfare of assets like the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. At the moment the minister does not have our support.

That the motion (Senator Cook's ) be agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE:
COMMONWEALTH SERVICES DELIVERY AGENCY BILL 1996 REFORM OF EMPLOYMENT SERVICES BILL 1996
REFORM OF EMPLOYMENT SERVICES (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1996

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Community Affairs Legislation Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make some remarks in relation to business of the Senate order of the day No. 1, the Community Affairs Legislation Committee report, which was dealt with out of order.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee considered the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency Bill and the Reform of Employment Services Bill and, in addition, consequential amendment bills to both. I believe the submissions received by the committee were, considering the impact of the proposed legislation, of a very high standard. I want to congratulate, in particular, those who made submissions on behalf of ACOSS, ACROD, the Welfare Rights Centre, the Brotherhood of St Laurence, the Community and Public Sector Union and, of course, the submissions put to the committee by the various departments to make clear the impact of the legislation. Because there was a limited reporting time due to the government's desire to have this legislation dealt with in the current session before Easter, there was a great deal of work involved, especially in the preparation of the minority report of which I am a signatory. In particular I wanted to thank staffers Christina Valentine, Andrew Scott and Catherine Wildermuth for their assistance in the preparation of that report.

SPEECH.PARA: The bills in question, as I said earlier, are extremely important in terms of their impact on the legislative framework that affects the unemployed and many social security beneficiaries in this country. Firstly, the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency Bill has the effect of creating a one‐stop shop or agency where beneficiary recipients can conduct their business. I understand that it will not necessarily be single premises or a building in each case; it might be that closely located buildings provide that service. The opposition has no in principle opposition to the creation of such an agency, subject to comments which I will be making and which the minority report makes in relation to the Reform of Employment Services Bill. It seems that those bills go hand in hand in terms of the operation of the new agency and the new regime in so far as the unemployed are concerned.

With regard to the service delivery matter, there was a concern expressed that there needed to be a transparency of ministerial control of the agency. In that regard, the minority report deals with certain necessary amendments to the bill to ensure that any government directions to the agency and the board of the agency in relation to the administration of government policy be reported in the annual report of the board of the agency to the parliament so that there can be proper scrutiny of the operations of the agency.

Secondly, because of the operation of the agency as both a purchaser of services and a provider of services, there was also concern expressed in the minority report that those roles needed to be separated and that some of those roles would be more appropriately provided by the department rather than the agency and that appropriate amendments to the bill would be moved.

As I said, there is no in principle opposition to the bill. In relation to the Reform of Employment Services Bill, however, there is a great deal of concern. This is a piece of legislation which will repeal the Employment Services Act. It is a bill which contains most of the labour market programs which arose under the previous government, particularly under the Working Nation program. It also leads to the disappearance of a universally available labour exchange service for all Australians. It replaces a service that was not restricted with a set of services which are restricted in their application to Australians. That can be borne out by looking at simple statistics. Over the last year, the CES assisted over 500,000 Australians with gaining work but the funding provided for the new agency will make provision to assist only 300,000. The reason for that is that the universality of the service will disappear with the CES's disappearance under this legislation.

This bill also effectively provides for the privatisation of employment services and for the creation of employment placement enterprises. Be they community based or for‐profit organisations, they will operate pursuant to the legislation—on a fee for result basis—and that creates a problem in itself. Originally, the government announced that a public employment placement enterprise would be created and would be part of this legislation. Late last year, the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) retracted that announcement and stated that the public employment placement enterprise, the name of which would be decided subsequently, would, in fact, be established as a commercial corporation under the Corporations Law. That decision creates some concerns for the opposition.

One particular concern is that the very existence of the public employment placement enterprise will be beyond the control of the parliament and can, therefore, disappear at the whim of the government without this parliament having any say in the matter. That is a matter which has been addressed closely in the minority report and will receive further attention in the debate on this legislation. So the government has backtracked on its original position and there is a need for that matter to be closely addressed when this bill comes before the Senate.

There are also major concerns expressed in the report about the equitable delivery of employment services to the unemployed, particularly revolving around the fact that payment for the employment placement enterprises is outcomes based, and a fear that there would be, effectively, creaming of the unemployed by these placement enterprises, that is, placing those who are easiest to place because it is an easier fee to get and concentrating less on the more difficult to place.

In the latest unemployment figures released, I think today, we see that the long‐term unemployed figures have risen by 14,000 in the month of February. That is of great concern. It will be an even greater concern to the opposition if we lose the ability to guarantee that there will be special attention paid to the long‐term unemployed, as has been paid under the Working Nation program, where, whilst there is a higher fee for placing long‐term unemployed, there is a greater cost in providing the services necessary to make the long‐term unemployed job ready and, therefore, in our opinion, disincentive for the employment placement enterprises to do the job for the long‐term unemployed.

In addition, of course, the legislation—the downgrading of the CES, the disappearance of the universal labour exchange—will see 3,000 to 6,000 jobs go in the public sector and, at a time when unemployment is rising, that is not a good figure for the Australian community.

In summary, the opposition and the Democrats have many concerns about the bill which will come before the parliament in this session. It is a bill which puts into place a risky strategy. The question which this chamber must ultimately answer is whether we are prepared to take the risks which the minister advocates on behalf of Australian unemployed because the price of failure is greater misery for the unemployed and the consequential social dislocation that that will create.

TELECOMMUNICATIONS BILL 1996

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 3, page 3 (after line 3), after paragraph (a), insert:

PARA.TAB: (aa) to provide a framework under which a carriage service that provides digital data capability comparable to an ISDN channel is to become reasonably accessible to all people in Australia as soon as practicable;

SPEECH.PARA: (28) Page 71 (after line 7), after clause 65, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 65A Conditions about Telstra's ISDN obligations

PARA.TAB: (1) The Minister must ensure that Telstra's carrier licence is subject to one or more conditions directed towards achieving:

TAB.TAB: (a) the result that, by 1 July 1997, Telstra is in a position to make available, to at least 93.4% of the Australian population, a carriage service that provides a digital data capability broadly comparable to that provided by a data channel with a data transmission speed of 64 kilobits per second supplied to end‐users as part of the designated basic rate ISDN service; and

(b) the result that, by 1 January 2000, Telstra is in a position to make available, to at least 96% of the Australian population, a carriage service that provides a digital data capability broadly comparable to that provided by a data channel with a data transmission speed of 64 kilobits per second supplied to end‐users as part of the designated basic rate ISDN service.

PARA.TAB: (2) For the purposes of this section, if:

TAB.TAB: (a) immediately before 1 July 1997, Telstra supplied a basic rate Integrated Services Digital Network (ISDN) service; and
(b) the service complied with any of the standards for ISDN services made by the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI);

SPEECH.PARA: the service is a designated basic rate ISDN service .

PARA.TAB: (3) For the purposes of this section, the determination of the comparability of the digital data capability of a carriage service is to be based solely on a comparison of the data transmission speed available to an end-user of the service.
(4) This section does not, by implication, limit the application of section 63 to Telstra.

SPEECH.PARA: (41) Clause 104, page 100 (after line 23), after subclause (4), insert:

PARA.TAB: (4A) The ACA must monitor, and report each financial year to the Minister on, the progress made by carriers and carriage service providers towards making a carriage service that provides digital data capability comparable to an ISDN channel reasonably accessible to all people in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: (42) Clause 104, page 100 (line 24), omit "or (4)", substitute ", (4) or (4A)".
(43) Clause 104, page 100 (lines 27 and 28), omit "or (4)", substitute ", (4) or (4A)".
(62) Clause 137, page 125 (after line 22), at the end of the clause, add:

PARA.TAB: (2) Before 1 January 2000, the Minister must cause to be conducted a review to determine whether a carriage service that provides a digital data capability broadly comparable to that provided by a data channel with a data transmission speed of 64 kilobits per second supplied to end‐users as part of the designated basic rate ISDN service should be specified in regulations made for the purposes of subsection (1).

(3) For the purposes of this section, the determination of the comparability of the digital data capability of a carriage service is to be based solely on a comparison of the data transmission speed available to an end-user of the service.
(4) The Minister must cause to be prepared a report of the review.
(5) The Minister must cause copies of the report to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the completion of the preparation of the report.
(6) In this section:

SPEECH.PARA: designated basic rate ISDN service has the same meaning as in section 65A.

These amendments make it an object of the new legislation to provide a framework under which a carriage service that provides digital data capability comparable to an ISDN channel is to become reasonably accessible to all people in Australia as soon as practicable and to provide for monitoring and annual reporting by the ACA on progress towards achieving that objective. This gives effect to recommendation 10 of the opposition senators' report—in other words, the report by Senator Schacht and Senator Lundy—on the Senate inquiry. It will also require the minister to impose a licence condition on Telstra directed towards achieving the result that Telstra is in a position to make available to at least 93.4 per cent of the Australian population by 1 July 1997 and at least 96 per cent population of the Australian population by 1 January 2000 ISDN comparable digital data capability. That gives effect to recommendation 9(3) of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I think from reading through your amendment and the revised running sheet—we now have amendment No. 62 which was not on the earlier running sheet—I can sum up the difference between the government's position and the opposition's position, and you may correct me if I am wrong on this because there has been shifting sand with things being rewritten. Our recommendation was that we wanted it guaranteed by the year 2000 that all Australian telephone subscribers would have access to digital data capability or 64 kilobits per second. I think your amendment and comments indicate that by 1998 some 94 per cent of the population would have that capacity but by 2000 it would still not be guaranteed that the last two or three per cent would be achieved. I think what you are offering is a review of the progress being made by the carriers to get that figure to see what would be achieved by 2000.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition believes, without being too prescriptive, that it is not unreasonable to guarantee people in regional and rural Australia that they should have access to digital data capability. Our amendment makes it clear that we do not believe with the last few per cent that you have to roll the fibre cable out and put satellites up with empty capacity just in case. What you have to do is put it there so that if someone wants it they can reasonably be connected.

As I understand it, that is the difference between our positions. Some people might ask why we are arguing about six per cent of subscribers. I think it is reasonable. Generally, people in the bush feel put upon about this. Have I described the differences between your position and my position correctly? I accept the fact that there has been some shifting around with drafting and so on even in the last day or so and I may now not understand the difference.

TALK.START.PARA: —When Senator Alston is responding to Senator Schacht, could he advise the committee where this six per cent would be? In what geographical locations are they likely to be in? That might shed a bit of light on the subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer, as far as Senator Schacht question is concerned, I think is that the recommendation from the committee was that it should be an objective—
—This is the majority committee?

—No. Opposition recommendation No. 10 stated that the bill should include an objects clause stating that it is an objective of the proposed act that digital data capability be available to all Australians by the year 2000. The requirement contained in our amendments is that 1 July 1997 be the date for Telstra to provide ISDN capability or its equivalent, which is really what we are talking about here, to 93.4 per cent of the population—people who live within five kilometres of a local exchange. To get to 96 per cent by the year 2000, which is the difference between 96 per cent and 93.4 per cent, which is 2.6 per cent, involves people who live beyond that area but not in the remotest parts of the country.

SPEECH.PARA: The last four per cent, to take it to 100, are those people who currently rely on digital remote concentrator systems and are therefore simply beyond the reach of ISDN for practical purposes. Those people will need to rely on new technologies or an upgrade of DRCS. I think all the signs are encouraging in terms of satellites. That is the harder part of the equation. Telstra is committed to ongoing research to ensure that they are brought within the ambit of what the other 96 per cent will have by the year 2000. It is really people within five kilometres of the local exchange who are the 93.4 per cent. It is those beyond that, but not in the remotest parts of the community, who are the next 2.4 per cent. The last four per cent are those who are in the outer reaches.

We recognise that it is a desirable objective to aspire to having national coverage, but the concern we have is that, if you effectively mandate that for the year 2000, you are locking the carrier, or carriers, into technol ogy that may not be appropriate and that may indeed change very dramatically over the next few years. That is why our amendment No. 62 would require the minister of the day to conduct a review before the year 2000 to determine whether a requirement to make ISDN available should be included in the USO. In other words, we do not have any quarrel about that aspiration; it is simply a matter of remaining flexible in the means of achieving it. We certainly do not want to see the last four per cent left behind anymore than you do.

The view we take is that it would be irresponsible to simply lock in existing ISDN technology, for example, when there may be plenty of other ways of achieving it or when, indeed, it might already have been delivered quite voluntarily. So rather than having the straitjacket of a total requirement—and bearing in mind what came out of the standard telephone service review—if you go down the path you are proposing, you are effectively wanting a blank cheque.

We do not know whether it might cost one or more billion dollars, but certainly the only evidence that came out of that report was that there was a very big question mark over the cost and that the responsible way of proceeding was, therefore, to have your review in due course and try to get a handle on the costs and then you may be able to go that extra step, if it is affordable. We would be confident that there would be other means of getting there in any event but, if there are not, you will have this review to look at whether they ought to be included in the USO.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, in terms of what you have just stated about the government's desirable objective to achieve that ISDN service, and not wanting to be put in a straitjacket, if you like, in terms of defining the type of technology, can you comment on the fact that the opposition's amendment actually specifies that we should ensure that a carriage service that provides a digital data capability comparable to an ISDN channel becomes available to all people? So the nature of our amendment is not technol ogy specific; it in fact allows for the precise flexibility that you are arguing is required.

SPEECH.PARA: So I put to you, Minister, that, with respect to that, our amendment provides for all of that flexibility you were looking for in that we are not seeking a technology specific outcome with respect to this. We are stating a desired aim and, as you said, a desired objective, but in fact the wording of our amendment provides for a `digital data capability comparable to an ISDN channel to become available by 1 January 2000'.

In this way, the two per cent at issue and the four per cent in the remote areas can in fact be included in this clause because we are not arguing for a technology specific outcome and the flexibility does exist. So I put to you that it is within your position to support the opposition amendment on this particular issue of a standard telephone service by 1 January 2000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lundy has very eloquently made the point that we have not made it ISDN specific. We have made it comparable to ISDN so that we have a measure, so that we are not trying to write into legislation specific technology. There is advice around, and some comments may or may not be correct, that ISDN may be overtaken by new developments, and we have all conceded that. So that is why we have made it comparable.

SPEECH.PARA: The further point I want to make is about why we believe it ought to be the objective of 100 per cent by the year 2000. Some people in the cities might say, `The last two or three per cent, what do they matter?' Apart from the issue of a telecommunication system serving all Australians equally and efficiently, there is also the issue that having access to decent on‐line services in many of these remote areas will be, in my view, a major advantage in the growth of the pastoral industry and the tourist industry in particular. For example, someone in a remote area of Australia running a high quality tourist resort, say, in the Kimberleys, may see real advantages in marketing their tourist resort directly around the world on the Internet or through similar on-line services. They will get a real marketing advantage. They will be directly in control of their own bookings. They will be directly in control of putting information out. They will not be relying on agencies in between who take 10 per cent or 15 per cent, which may well be their profit margin.

So it is not just the fact that it is only three per cent or four per cent—and I acknowledge that the minister probably wants to get it connected as much as we do. If Telstra in particular is the dominant carrier and has an investment program running at $4 billion or $5 million a year, and over the next four years that is going to be about a $20 billion investment program, irrespective of privatisation or not—the third privatisation—we think it is not unreasonable in the national interest that it has this objective put on it so it cannot get out of it. As we in this chamber all know, sooner or later someone will complain that there is discrimination, and with the new technologies we ought to make sure no Australian is discriminated against. We believe that what we are offering is reasonable.

I also want to point out to the minister that, in our amendment—amendment No. 5 on document 412, which has been circulated—we say the ACA must monitor and report each financial year to the minister of the progress made by carriers and carriage service providers towards the attainment of the objective referred to in paragraph (32)(aa), which is the objective of 100 per cent. Minister, I note your new clause 62, which has been circulated today, says that, before 1 January 2000, the minister must cause to be conducted a review to determine whether a carriage service that provides a digital data capability is broadly comparable. You are offering an unspecified time. The review may be as late as some time in the latter half of 1999.

We also believe that there is an advantage in saying to Telstra and the carriers that ACA is conducting a review every year on progress—to keep them up to the mark, so that in late 1999 they do not say, `This is impossible to achieve now: you have got to give us another couple of years.' If they are having problems on delivery, every year between now and 2000 the ACA ought to be asking them to provide information on how they are progressing towards attainment.

If our amendment to this legislation—that it has got to be provided for 100 per cent by the year 2000—is accepted and is not achievable technically, and they then come to us in 1999 saying, `We cannot achieve it, but you have been getting reports from us every year through this period through the ACA, which we have seen as a transparent process about it,' those are reasonable processes to put into place to achieve the objective. As far as the objective is concerned, I concede the government's and our own position—we would all love to have 100 per cent by the year 2000. The process is the matter here. But a firm objective will put an extra bit of sting on the carriers, to make sure they get there and have the ACA reviewing their progress each year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to indicate that the Democrats will support the ALP amendments to this legislation and to remind the government that services for rural people were part of the coalition's pre‐election promises and should therefore be supported.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator ALSTON (Victoria—Minister for Communications and the Arts) (5.54 p.m.) We do not need any cheap and superficial reminders of our commitments to rural Australia. We negotiated the commitment from Telstra to have the 93.4 per cent by 1 July this year. I will make a couple of points. Firstly, the information I have now is that the 2.4 per cent difference between the 93.6 per cent and the 96 per cent relates to DRCS customers. The last four per cent are the ones in between—in other words beyond—

TALK.START.PARA: —The DRCS are the two per cent?
—They are the 2.4 per cent.
—The 2.4 per cent to get it in 1996?
—Yes. We would get those two groups done by 1996. The central issue is—
—Who are the remaining four per cent?
—They are people who are in between the remote areas and more than five kilometres from a local exchange. So they are the people in between, if you like.
—Are they in such areas as rural midwest New South Wales or Queensland or rural South Australia?

—You could say that the 93.4 per cent are those people who live in the metropolitan areas and within reasonable reach of regional centres. Then you have the people in the most remote parts, and then this four per cent—the in‐betweens who are more than five kilometres from a local exchange but not so far out that they are on DRCS.

SPEECH.PARA: I will explain the logic of this—to get to 96 per cent, you are not mandating it so that it is effectively provided to every household. It is a digital data capability. Therefore, it will be provided essentially on a commercial basis to those 96 per cent of people. The really hard issue is the four per cent remainder. On a foreseeable basis, that will be non‐commercial, although you cannot tell quite what new technology is around the corner. But, assuming that it is non‐commercial, it makes sense to do that as part of a USO review. In other words, the way the system works is that, if it is commercial, the carriers deliver it and they do not need much incentive to do it; you might have a mandated requirement that they have timetables. But it is the non‐commercial stuff that will never otherwise be delivered, and that is why you have a universal service obligation. That is why our amendment says you ought to be looking at whether you need to extend the USO to cover that last four per cent.

I have no objection to bringing that forward. Responding to your point that you do not do anything until the year 2000, we could commence that review during 1998 so that you have plenty of time to do what is affordable. But what we are trying to avoid is a situation where you are requiring ISDN or ISDN comparable technology when, on the current state of information, you have only got ISDN—and we know that it is going to be prohibitively expensive for the last four per cent. That is what comes out of the standard telephone service report.

BREAK.PARA: The majority report simply says that the cost of universal coverage should not be unreasonable. We do not know what the cost is—they do not assist us in that regard. The report contains very little quantitative information to support its recommendation regarding a digital data capability. You are therefore left with saying, `What do you want—a blank cheque?' because you only know whether it is affordable when you have had your review, based on the state of current technology. By 1998, it may be that there will be brand‐new, very cheap technology that will enable you to say, `We can impose this requirement; it is not a problem.'

On the other hand, if you are technologically no further advanced than now, you might say, `That last four per cent could cost a couple of billion dollars.' Senator Schacht, I know your view is, `What is a couple of billion dollars when you have got a cap of four or five billion?' The fact is that that is already in the system, committed to important upgrades—whether of the can or of roll‐outs or whatever else. You cannot say, `Because you have got a track record of spending some billions of dollars, an extra one or two in the lead‐up to 2000 does not matter.'

TALK.START.PARA: —But that figure of one or two billion is as much a guess as my $100 million.

—But that is precisely why I say you ought to have your review to determine whether it is affordable in the scheme of things. But your requirement would say, `By hook or by crook—irrespective of cost—you have got to get there by 2000.' What I am saying to you is that, once they get beyond 1996, they have got to provide the last four per cent irrespective of cost. If the cost is some billions of dollars, it is no use shrugging your hands and saying, `Too bad. You have got to wear it.' We are saying, `Do the responsible thing. Do it in stages.' In principle, we do not have any objection to it being done but, if it did turn out to cost two or three billion, the most sensible thing to do would be to look at the best way of getting there in the most appropriate time.

BREAK.PARA: You may say, `Well, maybe we would need to go a bit beyond 2000 because there is new technology just around the corner' or `There may be some cheaper way of delivering it that is not quite ISDN standard. Maybe if somebody can deliver 52 kilobits per second by a much cheaper method, then you might accept that.' All we are saying is, `Do it in stages so that at each step along the way you know pretty much what the cost is going to be.'

But there is a fundamental difference between 96 and 100 because 96 per cent is commercial. The last 4,000 is uncommercial, and it therefore ought to be included in the USO. The only way you will ever get a handle on that is to do a review. The USO, as we know, only cost $230 million, so if you were to suddenly include this and it cost $1 billion you would be quadrupling the current USO and you would be fundamentally changing the whole concept. So we say that the sensible way of doing it is to go in stages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —Further on that point, Minister, you talk about the unknown costs being the reason why this aim cannot be specified but at the same time we are debating this in the context of moving towards a deregulated telecommunications market. Our amendment seeks to provide an incentive for the carriers to actually invest in perhaps some research and development to move in the direction of being able to provide these capabilities to some of our more remote geographical locations.

SPEECH.PARA: Stating this as an aim really highlights one of the great strengths of the Australian telecommunications industry and what has driven Telstra previously to the point of being a world leader in delivering very high standard and high speed telecommunications to remote areas. So by virtue of the fact that we have had a USO in place that has been required to deliver a high standard of service to all Australians, that incentive has fed research and development to the point where Australia can stand up and show that we are a leader.

By removing that incentive of forcing carriers to actually address what is a very difficult exercise—and, I am sure, as you have said, an exercise that will involve some expense—you are effectively cancelling out or unarming what has been in the past a great strength of the Australian telecommunications industry on the R&D side. So can you explain why the government is so keen to isolate, if you like, the last four per cent—or, in your case, the last 6.6 per cent—of people, where in fact that has been a great strength, and removing that incentive will only serve to drain further funds and further investment by the major carriers into providing services to the furthest reaches of Australian settlement and to people in those remote areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said earlier, our bona fides in this matter ought to be beyond dispute because we did actually spend a lot of time negotiating with Telstra to put that requirement for 93.4 per cent by 1 July in place, and we are going further in this legislation and getting to 96 per cent by the year 2000. It seems to me that you have gone a fair way down the track in doing that.

SPEECH.PARA: What it boils down to is that in a sense you are saying that this is so important you want to do it irrespective of cost and we are saying, `No, the sensible way of doing it is step by step.' I do not want to remove incentives and it may well be that there will be a lot of commercial incentives there for people. You may not accept that, but I am saying that that is what incentives are all about. If people see a commercial opportunity, they will do it. You might have thought—

TALK.START.PARA: —Without social obligations.

—But the social obligations should only come into place by default. That is the whole purpose of a CSO. Because you know that the true cost of providing a connection to an outback homestead is many thousands of dollars you cross‐subsidise that under the universal service obligation because you know that commercially no‐one is going to put that in place because the user of that telephone line will never be able to afford to pay the true cost. So you subsidise that under a CSO arrangement.

SPEECH.PARA: But it is not all clear that you will not get commercial opportunities arising in this area, just as in Ballarat recently we had Northgate announcing that they would provide free local telephone calls between their own customers in the Ballarat area.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was in a bundled package. You had to take the television as well, didn't you?
—I am not sure whether you have to subscribe to the package or not, but you would not have to use it.
—It wasn't a free‐standing one‐off telephony. It was a bundled arrangement.

—Well, at the end of the day, if it is affordable for them to do it someone else could come in and offer single services. It does not have to be a bundled arrangement. But what it demonstrates is that those who thought that country areas were not going to get telephony except on an interconnection arrangement suddenly see the opportunity for brand‐new services—
—You may well be arguing for our position—that it is going to be easier for it to occur.

—No, but what your argument does is say, `Let's just take a big punt on this. Let's say that new technology will emerge within the time frame that we are setting so that magically by the year 2000 it will all be affordable.' And I am saying that that is not necessarily a responsible position to take. We all have the same objective. We do not want these people left behind. We have made it clear that we want to bring them up to date. That is why we had the standard telephone service review.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite frankly, I was hoping that from that I would get a steer on the true cost. If they had said to me, `Our best guess is that it will cost you a couple of hundred million dollars', you probably would have said, `Well, that is affordable in the scheme of things. Let's build it in.' But we did not get that. All that we got was advice that we should not impose unreasonable costs.

You then ask what it is really going to cost, and no‐one has any true idea—simply because, I suppose, the research has not been done. I do not have any problem about people doing the research and I do not want to remove any incentives from the carriers. I think it is perfectly respectable for us to conduct that review, despite what the carriers' inclinations might be, so we get an independent assessment of what is affordable and what is not. That way you then make a judgment about whether and how you get to the last four per cent. So it seems to me that that is the difference between us: you are saying `Hang the expense', and we are saying `No, let's do it in stages and see whether it is affordable at that point.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think we are saying hang the expense—
—You are saying they can wear it.

—But we are also saying in our amendment that the ACA shall report each year on the progress being made. If we have the objective there and the ACA reports after each year and it is said that the carriers have made it quite clear that the technology to do this is going to cost us—as minister has just said—$2 billion, then the parliament can have a look at that in 1998 or 1999 and make a subsequent change to the act. But I think that we ought to put it around the other way. The objective is there. We want the carriers to meet that objective, and they have to prove to us through these reviews by the ACA, which are covered by our amendment, that they cannot do it. Then the parliament can make an adjustment to the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have here is a situation which is the other way around. You want to drop back from the objective, to have a review some time before 2000 to see how they are going and if they cannot do it, as the objective is not there, I think they will be less dynamic in trying to get an outcome. But it is really a matter of which way you put the carrot or the stick. You might say that you are offering a bit more carrot, that they ought to achieve it. We are saying that the stick is there, and you have got to get there. But we are saying that the ACA will review this each year to report on progress. If the parliament gets reports from the ACA review, under our amendment, that this is technically not going to be achievable, the parliament will have to make a judgment in 1999 that it is either going to have to find $2 billion through the USO to do it, as you say; or, extend the period. But we will have that debate closer to 2,000. I think that is not unreasonable.

Four per cent on the number of subscribers—I thank your advisers for helping me on this calculation—is about 400,000, I suppose, on 10 million subscribers. Four hundred thousand subscribers who are in this 4 per cent is not an inconsiderable number; it is equivalent to the population of Tasmania. Senator Denman from Tasmania, who is behind me, nods her head. I am not in any way implying that all of Tasmania will be out of it, but across Australia the number of subscribers affected is equivalent to the population of Tasmania. So it is not a small number, even though 4 per cent does sound small.

From the discussion we have had so far, I am yet to be convinced to drop off our amendment, because I do not think it is horrific, as you say. Minister, through this process, if you have got a suggested adjustment and amendment whereby you can take our position somewhat—if some of your advisers have got another way of putting it together—I am not averse to having a compromise in a lot of areas, because I am after an outcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I respond by saying that I think part of the problem that we would have with your approach is that you say, `Let's require them to get to 100 per cent by the year 2000.' Then, in the same breath, you say, `If they are having troubles, they will report back to us.' In other words, if at some stage you were satisfied that it was a serious problem you would have to come back and amend the legislation. In the meantime your amendment requires the minister, in exercising the powers conferred under section 63—which is to ensure that there is a licence condition requiring the carrier to provide this digital data capability to all people by the year 2000—to take all reasonable steps to ensure that that object is attained. If it is not, the ACA can cancel the carrier licence. That is a pretty horrific last step. But the point is that that approach is fundamentally in conflict.

SPEECH.PARA: On the one hand, you are saying, `We are going to require you to do it and if you are having trouble, let us know and we will have a rethink.' On the other hand, the minister is saying, `By God, if you slow down at all, the ACA could take away your licence.' That is where the problem lies: you have got this inherent conflict of approach.

In terms of a compromise solution, we would certainly be more than happy to bring forward the review, and I am amenable to any reasonable time frame for that. In other words, if you have got to 93.4 per cent by 1 July this year, there is no reason why we cannot be conducting this review over the next couple of years. But you do not want to do it immediately, because you will not learn any more than you know now. So you need a bit of a time period to elapse.

That is why I say that if we commenced the review or even concluded it by the end of 1998, you would be well placed to make a judgment about the most appropriate means of delivering services to the last 4 per cent. It may be that you can contract it out. It may be that you build it into the USO. It just seems to me that that is a more responsible approach to take than having the inherent tension between you saying, on the one hand, `I am imposing the obligation come what may, but if you have got problems come back and see us' and, on the other hand, the minister saying, `Just get on it with it; unless you do, you could lose your licence.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, on that point, what you were saying just then and certainly comments you made previously about commercial incentives indicates to me that the clause that we are proposing to insert regarding an outcome of 100 per cent on 1 January 2000 is not entirely incompatible with your position, because it does state an outcome. What you have just articulated is in fact the appropriate checks and balances that we have also contained, albeit in a slightly different form, in terms of your amendment. So I put to you that in fact we are not so far apart, that we are dealing with an issue of semantics. We all agree that this is the direction in which the industry should be heading and it is the outcome that is desirable. It seems to me that by virtue of that, by stating the objective unequivocally and providing the processes along the way to review progress, we are not so far apart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I take note of the suggestion about putting a time scale on when the review would take place. We are interested in that. I think the other amendment that we want to look at is your amendment No. 1, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 3 (after line 3), after paragraph (a), insert:

PARA.TAB: (aa) to provide a framework under which a carriage service that provides digital data capability comparable to an ISDN channel is to become reasonably accessible to all people in Australia as soon as practicable;

SPEECH.PARA: If we can look at a form of words to amend that phrase, `reasonable accessible to all people in Australia', then I think we have a chance of a compromise. We know there will be a review. If the review is transparent and, in your own amendment, it comes to parliament to be debated, and that review says it is going to cost, in your terms, $2 billion to do this, that it is going to blow the USO calculations right through the roof, or you are going to have to find $2 billion somewhere else, or we are going to put up charges or whatever to pay for it—if all of those options are before the parliament then we have to make a choice about it. That means you make a choice in public process and you live or die by it, in a sense.

`Reasonably accessible' is just too broad for us regarding the last four per cent—400,00. If you and your advisers can look at it, I would like some firmer definition to indicate that we are moving closer to get the 100 per cent. But, because we have the review process, if that is not working then parliament can reconsider it in 1998‐99 and make an amendment and we can have a transparent debate at that time. I think that is a reasonable outcome for both sides here that could be achieved.

BREAK.PARA: I know that writing amendments and making adjustments on the run sends advisers out the window, back to front and upside down, but I am offering this, Minister, on behalf of the opposition. I cannot speak for the Democrats. If you can change that phrase from `reasonably accessible' to a more definite statement, then I think we have a chance of getting a compromise that we certainly would be willing to vote for. I cannot speak for the Democrats, Senator Harradine or other Independents or Greens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps, in the circumstances, Mr Deputy Chairman, it may be worthwhile to defer further consideration, but can I suggest that there may be a word that is tougher than `reasonably accessible', something like `available'.

SPEECH.PARA: Can I just respond to what Senator Lundy said. It is not a semantic argument because we are really talking about whether or not it will become commercially available within that time frame. You may hope it will, and so do I, but there is no guarantee of that. On the basis of current knowledge, the last four per cent would not be commercially available, so it would have to become part of the universal service obligation and that is where you have this black hole—you do not have any idea of the cost of it.

I do not mind an aspiration that is tighter, but what we want to avoid is what is contained in your amendments which effectively requires the minister to keep the whip on them to get there, irrespective of cost. I think we can address your concern that they will go to sleep if there are no incentives, by having an independent assessment and making sure, well in advance of 2000, that we have a sensible handle on costs. I suppose if we had given the STS review team a longer time frame or more resources then they may have been able to do that job for us in sufficient time to be—

TALK.START.PARA: —We didn't have Henry on the team.
—Look, to be quite frank, what Henry was doing was drawing attention to the fact that you cannot just commit yourself to something irrespective of cost.
—The carriers were on that review panel in the majority. They were the ones I was surprised about, but if they can live with it.

—I think some of them were not happy to see it implemented irrespective of cost. In the game that they play between themselves it is a bit hard to follow the logic sometimes, but from a government point of view, I do not think it is sensible for us simply to blind ourselves to that. So I am happy to defer further consideration.

—This is a variation: in that paragraph where it says `to become reasonably accessible', I put it to you I could obviously live with `to become accessible to all people in Australia by the year 2000.' Is that too tough for you? Knowing that you have the review and everything, I wondered whether other senators might wish to comment.
