I am putting forward as a suggestion to just say, `to become accessible to all people in Australia by 1 January 2000'. `Accessible' is a word that has enough marginal flexibility for the minister, in my view, but not too much that it can be walked away from. We know the transparent review will take place and will report back to parliament, so if it is all going haywire the parliament will have to make another decision.

—Before you ask that these amendments be adjourned, may I ask the minister to clarify one particular figure that he gave. As I heard him, and I may have misheard him, I think he said that there will be achieved, by 1 July 1997, a 93 per cent customer penetration for ISDN.

—Yes, 93.4. That is interesting. I think my own state has been neglected in this particular area over a period of time. As I understand it, there will only be a 70 per cent customer penetration by June 1997 in the state of Tasmania and a 90 per cent penetration by December 1997. I am, of course, considering that particular matter in the context of the current discussions and I would hope that the minister might also consider that matter. Mr Temporary Chairman, I am happy to do what you are about to propose to do.

—Senator Allison, I did not give you the call just now. I was just going to suggest that if this is going to be deferred it might be better to defer it now, do the negotiating at a later stage and come back, to save discussion backwards and forwards and doing it on the run.

—Since Senator Harradine raises the point about Tasmania, it would be useful for us to know what the distribution is of those people who do not have access to ISDN. Perhaps that would assist us with further discussions. I was rising a moment ago to suggest that I would support the wording proposed by Senator Schacht.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I indicate in response to Senator Harradine that I think there is the germ of a good idea there which would involve putting a minimum coverage requirement so that you would not have 93.4 per cent achieved by 100 per cent in some places and 50 per cent in another. We have a minimum level of coverage around Australia. That will be one of the things we will explore.
—It being the wish of the committee to defer these amendments, I move to the next group of amendments, which are Democrat amendments Nos 1 and 7 to 12 on sheet 404.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 3, volume 1, page 3 (line 28), at the end of subclause (2), add:
and
(g) to promote the relocation of existing overhead cables, and the location of future cables, underground, wherever possible.
(7) Volume 1, page 71 (after line 2), after clause 64, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 64A Conditions about underground cables

SPEECH.PARA: In exercising the powers conferred on the Minister by section 63, the Minister must take all reasonable steps to ensure that the object referred to in paragraph 3(2)(g) is attained.
(8) Clause 71, volume 1, page 75 (after line 1), after subclause (5), insert:

EMPHASIS.TAB: Contravening licence conditions relating to underground cables

SPEECH.PARA: (5A) If:

PARA.TAB: (a) a carrier licence is subject to a condition declared under section 63; and
(b) the declaration of this condition was in fulfilment of the Minister's obligations under section 64A; and
(c) the holder of the licence contravenes the condition;

SPEECH.PARA: the ACA may cancel the licence.
(9) Clause 71, volume 1, page 75 (line 4), omit "(3) or (4)", substitute "(3), (4) or (5A)".
(10) Clause 104, volume 1, page 100 (after line 23), after subclause (4), insert:

(4A) The ACA must monitor, and report each financial year to the Minister on, the progress made by carriers and carriage service providers towards the attainment of the object referred to in paragraph 3(2)(g).
(11) Clause 104, volume 1, page 100 (line 24), omit "or (4)", substitute ", (4) or (4A)".
(12) Clause 104, volume 1, page 100 (lines 27 and 28), omit "or (4)", substitute ", (4) or (4A)".

The purpose of these amendments is to provide a legislative basis for a major national effort to improve the urban environment by ensuring that further telecommunications cabling is located underground wherever possible and that existing overhead telecommunications cables are progressively undergrounded, along with other aerial cables.

As the Senate will be aware, over the last two years there has been widespread community outrage at the wasteful duplication of cable roll‐out here in Australia involving extensive aerial cabling. It is now being widely acknowledged that so-called facilities based competition has simply produced a blight on our urban landscapes and wasted millions of dollars. It seems inevitable that the carriers will shortly be forced by economic necessity to stop this nonsense and will, in fact, create a shared telecommunications infrastructure. However, our aim now should be to ensure that in future cabling is carried out in an environmentally responsible way.

Amendments Nos 1 and 7 to 12 will require the minister to take all reasonable steps by means of carrier licence conditions to promote the relocation of existing overhead cables and the location of future cables underground wherever possible. These amendments will create a new subclause 3(2) to be inserted in schedule 3 of the bill so that carriers shall relocate underground any designated overhead line installed or maintained by a carrier in an area where the majority of cabling in an area is relocated underground. Government amendments Nos 250 and 251 do not actually do any more than require the minister to hold a review and to report back to the parliament, and then only once.

Australian Democrats amendment No. 10 requires regular monitoring by the ACA and a report each year to the minister on progress towards undergrounding. In addition, the amendments I have just moved to insert a new subclause 3(2) will ensure real action on this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I could indicate the government's attitude to those amendments. The real vice in that, and it is again part of this problem of doing things in the dark, is that it would require the minister to take all reasonable steps to ensure the undergrounding of existing and new cables takes place. In other words, again, irrespective of cost, you would have to have progressive retrospective undergrounding of all that is overhead in Australia at this time, but not power cables, which are just as, presumably, aesthetically offensive as telecommunications cables.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to us that that is entirely the wrong way to proceed. On any estimate you are talking about billions of dollars. In terms of priorities, it is still a very moot point whether the community at large would want to see billions of dollars spent on progressive undergrounding of cables rather than on new schools, hospitals and other community services.

I am by no means persuaded that there is universal outrage around Australia on this issue. Indeed, the objection seems to have been loudest in some fairly concentrated areas. In my own area, for example, of Boroondara, where we were told that people were going to die in a ditch on the issue, the council has reached agreement with the carriers. In Ballarat, for example, an agreement was reached without a requirement for any moneys to be paid to the council. In other words, the council itself was very keen to have those services, and the ratepayers, presumably, are also just as keen, because there have been no objections that I am aware of. That tells you that it is, in many respects, a matter of varying judgments in different areas.

There may be leafy parts of the North Shore where this is a burning issue and where they may well be prepared to pay for the undergrounding of cables in their streets. But to require the minister to make it a licence condition that the carriers ensure the progressive retrospective undergrounding, irrespective of costs, seems to us to be very irresponsible.

Our approach is rather to have a full assessment of the options and to get an independent assessment of the true cost of undergrounding all cables. We have already announced that we are establishing a working group to examine the issues involved in putting all cables underground. I have written to my other ministerial colleagues suggesting a structure. There will be something like 20 people on that underground working group.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bigger than the Collingwood football side.

—They will probably play a bit better. I should not say that because they did do better the other night, thank heavens. The working group will be a very representative one: each of the states and territories will be represented on it, as will be the Australian Local Government Association. It seems to us that that is the way to progress this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not want to run away from the fact that it would be desirable in principle but, once again, you simply cannot ignore the true cost of such an activity. It is critically important to know who should be paying that cost. We have already got a commitment from Telstra to put $1 million on the table and $½ million from Optus. We therefore have the capacity to conduct some high-level independent research to determine what the true cost would be. I think everyone on the working group would be very interested in exploring the possibilities of undergrounding power and telecommunications cables.

Then you have to look at what I think is just as difficult an issue, and that is in what proportions you would expect the various stakeholders to contribute to such an exercise. It is very difficult to say that, just because you live on the North Shore, you should be subsidised by everyone else in the country; it is equally difficult to confine the true cost of undergrounding to residents in those areas.

Our approach is not to ignore the issue at all but to address it in a systematic fashion, to establish a working group, to acknowledge that it is going to take time to come to grips with what are very vexed economic issues in terms of cost and sharing of cost and then to report back so that the parliament is made fully aware of all of the implications. The parliament can then proceed to look at the best way of addressing the issue.

The Democrat series of amendments would simply say that this is going to happen irrespective. You are going to commit the same offence, in our judgment, as you would have wanted to commit probably 12 months ago and that was to effectively impose very substantial burdens on carriers who have built business cases against the background of a legislative regime that allowed them to roll that out and did not impose any obligation to then bear the cost of progressive undergrounding. You are proposing now that that additional burden should be imposed on presumably all carriers. That would fundamentally affect the economics of the roll-out to the point where you might make it totally uneconomic for any of the carriers to remain in the business, and I do not think any of us would want to see that.

I make it abundantly clear that this would be a disastrous outcome not only for carriers and potential users of their services but ultimately, I would have thought, for the Australian community in terms of priorities. The more appropriate way of proceeding is as I have indicated and as will be addressed in government amendments Nos 250, 251 and 252. They require cabling to be removed when all other aerial cabling has already been removed unless otherwise agreed with the relevant local government authority; they require a review to be undertaken of the options; and they require the ACA to monitor progress in placing cabling underground. The report of the working group will be provided to the parliament by 1 July 1998.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, the Democrats have moved amendment No. 1 and then Nos 7 to 12. As I understand it, Democrat amendment No. 1 is adding to the list of objectives on pages 2 and 3 of the Telecommunications Bill. I think the amendment should actually be (h) rather than (g) because (g) is already there. I do not think you are asking (g) to be deleted. Nevertheless, whatever the correct alphabet number is, the amendment says:

SPEECH.PARA: to promote the relocation of existing overhead cables, and the location of future cables, underground wherever possible.

I presume that, when they talk about `cables', they are talking about telecommunications cables. When you look at the list of other objects in clause (3) of the bill, you have a whole list of things which start with `to promote'. For example:
(b) to promote the supply of diverse and innovative carriage services and content services;
(c) to promote the development of an Australian telecommunications industry that is efficient, competitive and responsive to the needs of the Australian community . . .

Also (d) starts off `to promote'; (e) is `to promote'; (f) is `to promote'; and the existing (g) is `to promote'. These are not binding formulas to say you have to spend X amount of money that goes on each of these things. This is the objective of the bill. I believe it is not unreasonable to include Democrat amendment No. 1 in the list which says:
to promote the relocation of existing overhead cables, and the location of future cables, underground wherever possible.
I think that is a reasonable thing to promote. That is separate from the arguments you may have about Democrat amendments Nos 7 to 12.

The opposition can live with an additional clause in the objectives starting off `to promote' because it does give a guidance, an impetus, an indication to the community that this is what we should all be about. I do not think anybody has any objection to putting these goddamned cables underground over a longer period of time. If we can do it at the same time as convincing electricity authorities to do it, the urban landscape of Australia and so on that we all know will be immeasurably improved. I ask you: what is wrong with Democrat amendment No. 1 itself being added into the objectives?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The principal problem is that you send all of the wrong signals. You cannot just pretend they are words that do not really matter. If the words are in there as objects, then you presumably want people to adhere to them and you expect governments to take actions consistent with enforcing them progressively. You say there can be no argument that everyone would like to see cables underground. I do not know that that is an endgame objective or something that is beyond refuting. It may well, for example—are you rolling your eyes or are you just tired?
—I know there may be someone in 18 million people who thinks they are beautiful or attractive.

—That is not what I meant. What I meant was that with the pace of new technology, with low earth orbiting satellites and various other direct to home satellite services that are now being developed—and you would be aware what Murdoch is doing with Echo Star; all of a sudden you have a couple of hundred spot beams delivering services on a digitally compressed basis that people a couple of years ago said could not be done—you may well find in the not too distant future that this technology becomes obsolete and if it is obsolete you would want to tear it down and throw it away. So why would you be wanting to commit yourself to putting it underground? That is just one example.
—Obviously they are going to tear it down because it is obsolete.
—Exactly, but you are wanting us to promote the relocation underground wherever possible, where there is existing cabling.
—Where existing cables are being used. It is the words `to promote'. I cannot see—

—That may not be a desirable end objective. That is what I am saying to you. If you just take those words at face value I think you are quite correct in saying that it is not confined to telecommunications cables. There is no definition there. It could well be all forms of cable and, particularly, it could be telecommunications cables which people in rural areas are perfectly happy to see above ground. In many instances the complaint you get when you talk about mobile telephony is quite the opposite of what Senator Allison would find on the leafy shores of south Melbourne. They are saying, `By hook or by crook we want an overhead tower so we can get a decent digital service out in the bush.' In the same way they would regard it as being very low on their priorities to suddenly find cables throughout the country on highways and byways being put underground.

BREAK.PARA: So you are not doing justice to words if you say that you can have some sort of harmless objects clause that promotes undergrounding wherever possible and not acknowledge that that would then obligate people to implement it wherever possible—and that is irrespective of cost. Saying `wherever possible' is not saying `as long as it is not unaffordable'; it is saying it has to be done wherever possible. We know it is possible, technically speaking, to do it now. The sticking point is cost.

You might like to start again and say, `Wouldn't it be wonderful if everything had gone underground in the first instance.' I could not disagree with that if that had been the way it had happened. If you had not got Kim Beazley to change the Telecommunications Act in 1991 to allow powers and immunities to continue over a period of years we may have had a very different configuration in this country. But we haven't; we have what is there and we have to address the true cost and desirability of changing that, and particularly undergrounding it which is clearly going to be a multibillion dollar exercise. I think it would be quite irresponsible to say, `Let's have it as an objective to underground that,' knowing it is going to cost billions of dollars, and not at the same time expect people to be doing something about it.

You cannot have an objects clause that is not requiring anyone to implement it. If you are going to have an objects clause then, consistent with the logic, you have got to have an act that delivers the goods. That is certainly not the way to go. It is much more sensible to take first things first: find out what the true cost is, have a sensible political debate about whether that is affordable and whether it should be done in certain areas—whether the people on the North Shore of Sydney and in a few other places who are particularly keen on it might not like to have arrangements that enabled that to occur—or whether it is a national objective.

I keep saying that I would have thought that in the scheme of things there are many more important ways in which you could spend scarce taxpayers' money than spending many billions of dollars undergrounding cable. Let us at least get an idea of what it costs and an idea of how cost sharing ought to be arranged; and then look at where we go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is interesting that the minister talks about the need for us to know what the cost is when this working group that was first mooted six months ago has still to be set up. I think this is why the Australian Democrats are driven to move these amendments. It is because there has been such inadequate progress on the part of the government in responding to enormous concern out there in the community—and also a concern in local government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a fact that the Australian Local Government Association has encouraged us so strongly to move these amendments because they see a complete lack of any sort of commitment by the government on this issue. We can take the case of Telstra. Where it has had the capacity to take its cables underground— which certainly would not cost billions of dollars, may take a little longer and may be slightly more expensive—Telstra has not done that. The minister stood by and allowed that to happen. So what we are asking for is an indication from the minister that the government will promote the relocation of existing overhead cables and the location of future cables underground where possible.

We were hoping that this would set a direction for the government to respond to the huge numbers of people who have written to my office and spoken with me directly—and no doubt have done this to most other senators in this place. Unless we have a referendum on this subject I do not believe, Minister, that you can stand up and say that there is not a wish for the government to have a greater commitment to promoting the undergrounding of both TV cabling and other sorts of cabling. As Senator Schacht points out, these amendments are not binding; they are not requiring that billions of dollars be spent on this. They are simply asking for a stronger commitment on the part of the government to see that it happens, not immediately but wherever and whenever possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just respond to that so we do not proceed on a false basis. I think it is quite disingenuous to suggest that the Democrats are now driven to require undergrounding wherever possible because of the delay in the establishment of the working group. The fact is the Democrats have been determined to veto the existing roll-out for at least the last couple of years. They have never shown the slightest interest in compromising. Their attitude from day one has been that the roll-out should stop immediately and everything should go underground.

SPEECH.PARA: Just to be clear on this, Senator Allison said she thought people would wish to see the government provide greater commitment to undergrounding. That is precisely why we are establishing the working group to explore what the implications of it would be. She says that it might take a little longer and it might have been slightly more expensive. I am sure she knows, because there have been Austel reports on the subject, that the very reason that both companies wanted to go overhead—Optus much more than Telstra, but Telstra by way of catch‐up—was that it was something like three of four times cheaper and two or three times faster. It makes a huge difference, and they were allowed to do that by the 1991 act. They have already spent billions of dollars acting in good faith in accordance with the legislative framework that was enacted. You have always taken the view that that did not matter, that you ought to be able to stop it cold.

The problem once again with saying, `Why don't we just have an objects clause,' is that you also have an amendment that would require the minister, in exercising powers conferred under the act, to take all reasonable steps to ensure that your objects were attained. In other words, once you start putting an objects clause in that promotes the relocation of existing overhead cables and future cables underground wherever possible, then you are also putting an obligation on the minister, or the government, to ensure that it happens, once again, irrespective of cost and irrespective of the consequences for the carriers. That is precisely why we say that that would be quite irresponsible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —For a start, the Democrats have never said that we would veto TV cabling. It is quite wrong of the minister to say that. We have never said that we would stop it cold. Our position has always been that the matter of TV cabling and mobile phone towers ought to be something that local government could put through normal planning processes, and that is still our position. We have never, at any stage, talked in terms of vetoing anything. I take exception to the fact that the minister continues to say that when that has not been our position at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I would ask the minister why it is that this working group has taken so long. We had this commitment from Telstra and Optus some months ago. It is very difficult for us to believe that there is any sort of commitment on the part of the government when it has taken all this time and we still do not have this working group working.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the answer to that is that it is important that it be part of the legislative program. We wanted to have that obligation inserted in the act. We have already done a lot of the preparatory work. It has been necessary to have extensive discussions with the states to determine whether they want to be simply represented as a group or as individual states and territories. We have needed to ensure that this process is fully thought through before it is put into place. After all, no-one pretends that you will be able to achieve this over a short time frame of a couple of years. It has to be an ongoing strategy. There are states which are already going down this path by entering into arrangements with local government authorities, but still setting a 10- to 15-year timetable.

SPEECH.PARA: In the scheme of things, I would have thought that it was perfectly sensible to have tried to get the process right. After all, we made it clear by an announcement some months ago that there would be no more overhead cabling beyond 1 July, subject to the transitional arrangements, unless it was with the approval of local governments. So it is not as if it is simply rolling on. We were never prepared to bring that date forward, for obvious reasons. So nothing is happening that would have been affected by the working group being established even six months ago. It will be a long-term process, it will be a very difficult and expensive exercise and we wanted to get it right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the Democrats' amendments. I just very quickly suggest that we know that corporate law indicates that if it is not written into legislation, if profits are not there, it will not happen. The minister clearly said that taxpayers' money is involved. If the minister does not trust the community to work out what is in their best interest, I am wondering who he is representing. The reality is that the community are clearly saying that they want codes and legislative controls in these issues. The minister is not hearing that. I am wondering exactly who he is listening to.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 March 1997, on motion by Senator Herron:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak on the Euthanasia Laws Bill to oppose it and to support voluntary euthanasia and, in particular, the rights of the people of the Northern Territory who have shown their support for their legislators, who have three times voted for the bill which gives to the world—not just themselves—breakthrough pioneering legislation. It extends to their citizens the right to opt for voluntary euthanasia. I speak on this issue with as much commitment as I have ever spoken on any matter before.

SPEECH.PARA: As a doctor, as a relative, as a friend, I have on a number of occasions sat with people who have suffered the long, undignified, unedifying and sometimes very painful end to a useful, wonderful and productive career as a citizen that accompanies the extenuated dying process which comes from our ability to live longer as a result of modern technology. I have seen them suffer. I have heard their calls for help in ending their indignity and their suffering. That appeal comes with me into this chamber and into this debate.

Let me tell you, through the words of one of the great majority of Australians who support the Northern Territory laws and oppose the Andrews bill, what it means to be denied the option of voluntary euthanasia. Ms Annette Mallinson, of Broadbeach Waters, in a recent letter to her newspaper, wrote:
It is almost a month now since my father-in-law, known to the family as Pa, died.
Most people would accept that at almost 78 he had a `fair innings', although by nature we tend to hope for longer with loved ones and life is never long enough.
I can cope with Pa's death.
I cannot accept how he died.

Pa had prostate cancer, but instead of moving to a major organ and killing this kind and courageous gentleman, the cancer worked its way through his bones, causing pain and suffering beyond what I thought the human body could bear.
Despite the best in palliative care and a sympathetic caring doctor, the suffering became progressively worse until Pa's death almost three years after the onset of the cancer.
The final six months were under the most traumatic circumstances.
I have read about suffering caused by cancer but no amount of reading could prepare me for what I was to experience.
As the disease progressed Pa reached the stage where he could wear no clothes and his limbs felt as if they would fall apart at the joints.
He became incontinent and trying to clean him without causing excruciating pain and bruising was impossible.
Eating and drinking resulted in vomiting and in the end all sustenance was refused.
Still his heart beat on.

Morphine doses were increased to help quell the pain but these also brought drawbacks. The pain eased but the morphine took away Pa's speech. His eyes would roll in anguish as he tried to say our names.
He could no longer tell us where he hurt or what his needs were.
But his heart beat on.
Pa's last coherent words were `Why am I still alive? Get a gun—shoot me or get me to the Northern Territory'.
The morphine dose was doubled. Pa was still aware of us but could not speak.
Who knows what his bright, intelligent mind was thinking?
Luckily, we had been able to fulfil his wish to die at home thanks to enormous support medically and from family and friends.
People would do the humane thing and shoot an animal in such condition, but this fine man who had survived the torture of world war was now being tortured by those who loved him most.
When Pa took his last breath he was surrounded by his loving family, the eerie midnight silence broken only by the music of his favourite cassette tape.
I am a caring, responsible person.
I wonder whether anti‐euthanasia advocate Kevin Andrews has known anyone or had a loved one who suffered as Pa did.
I believe no one could possibly oppose euthanasia if they had experienced Pa's death.
Ironically, I read in the paper the day after Pa's death that a convicted rapist and murderer had been put to death by lethal injection in America.
A violent criminal had been afforded a dignified death while this fine law abiding gentleman was stripped of all dignity.
I pray Pa has forgiven us for our ignorance.
I ask honourable members and senators to compare that with the farewell note of Mrs Janet Mills, who died with the assistance of the voluntary euthanasia laws of the Northern Territory. It read:

I believe that euthanasia is the greatest thing for people who are sick with no chance of getting better. It's a wonderful idea and it stops people from suffering when they don't need to. No one wants to do if they don't have to, but I know I have no hesitation in asking for this. No one should have to suffer when they don't have to.
She had been through such suffering. She continued:

I am pleased that the Northern Territory has such a law, even though it was so difficult for me to use, as at least now I can legally and honestly end my life. I hope this law survives and is able to help others like me, who have found the suffering has become too great. It should not be overturned by the politicians in Canberra, but given a chance to be made to work in the way it was intended. I want people to see just how important this law was to me now that I'm at the end of my life.

The central question here is choice, option and the right of all citizens to make their own deliberation in the matter of dying when they are terminally ill. For that small number of the dying in our society who find themselves suffering without relief, in pain without cure and suffering indignity without alleviation, the central question I ask of senators is this: how can you take away their right to opt for voluntary euthanasia when, as intelligent citizens, their hands reach out to ask for assistance of other mature citizens? What right have we to deny them that choice?

A recent article in the Medical Journal of Australia which contains the first survey of doctors involved in dying has been much disputed. But one of the things it rings with is the reality that each year thousands of Australians die earlier because their physicians have determined that they will help them to do so. The figures from that medical journal study indicate that in Australia some 4,400 people per annum die with their doctors actively assisting their death. But the problem is that it is without consultation with those people because our law as it stands inherently forbids it. That is the interpretation of it.

In this debate the choice for those who support the bill is not whether you can stop euthanasia: it is whether you keep it covert, with citizens denied the determination; and whether you are going to leave it with their medical attendants, their doctors, who are themselves inhibited from discussing the matter with the patients because inherently the law could catch up with them and have them charged with murder or worse, if they were to say exactly what they were contemplating.

I submit, as many legal authorities do, that we as a mature society can do better than that. In this, the people and the legislature of the Northern Territory have shown the way. Let me quote from Dr Margaret Otlowski, senior lecturer in law at the University of Tasmania. She says:

The current legal situation is totally unsatisfactory in that it creates very real dangers for both doctors and patients: doctors are at risk of criminal liability for murder (or assisting suicide) if their conduct is exposed; the rights and interests of patients are vulnerable, particularly in the light of recent evidence indicating a relative high incidence in Australia (in comparison with the Netherlands) of killings of patients occurring other than at the patient's request. It is my submission that the most effective way to protect the rights and interests of both doctors and patients is by acknowledging the existence of the practice of euthanasia and seeking to regulate it in carefully controlled circumstances. The legislation in the Northern Territory represents a very cautious attempt to legalise active assistance in dying, subject to stringent safeguards. The legal framework it establishes is sound and provides ample protection for doctors and patients.
Add to that the words of David Kelly, former chairman of the Law Reform Commission of Victoria. He says:
Although the common law focuses on the care of the living patient—
that is the law as we have it now—

it in fact permits a doctor to assist a patient to die in most of the cases covered by the Northern Territory Act. It also permits a doctor to assist a terminally ill patient to die in a number of circumstances not covered by that Act. It offers much less protection against abuse that the Act does.

So, in effect, by supporting the Andrews' bill we are moving, according to that legal authority, to a situation in which the person is less protected than under the Northern Territory law which at least codifies the process of voluntary euthanasia and brings it into a set of rules which are understood by all, and which offer protection to both doctors and their patients.

It is because of the debate about this matter that public opinion has moved in Australia. Let us not deny this in the Senate: the majority of Australians in every poll since the 1960s have supported voluntary euthanasia as the right of citizens, as an option that citizens should have. One only has to see both the repeated opinion poll figures and the way in which they have strengthened over those two or three decades to recognise that this is a constant as far as the Australian people are concerned.

A Morgan poll back in 1962 showed that 47 per cent of people supported voluntary euthanasia which a patient had asked for, compared to 39 per cent who opposed it. Within 33 years—in 1995—the same question put to the Australian people showed that the support had grown to 78 per cent and the opposition had fallen to 14 per cent. So in circumstances where a person asks to die and doctor is able to respond with a lethal injection, 78 per cent of people—

TALK.START.PARA: —What were the questions asked?

—Senator Herron asked `What were the questions?' Last night he indicated, as did other speakers, that these questions did not talk about the specifics of euthanasia as in the Northern Territory. These polls asked about a doctor injecting `with a lethal dose' at the request of a person. Australians say yes to that—78 per cent to 14 per cent. A recent Newspoll showed a 63 to 28 majority on the same question. That is why I believe Australians have a right to express themselves on this matter. It should not just be left to parliamentarians. I therefore foreshadow an amendment I wish to move to the motion before the Senate. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit all the words after `That', substitute:

`the bill be withdrawn until such time as a referendum has been held on the issue of whether the Australian people support the option of voluntary euthanasia as provided by the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995'.

I do so because I believe the people have a right to have a say in the matter. I do so because I believe that the House of Representatives did not reflect the feeling of the people of Australia. I do so because I believe every Australian has a right to have a say in this matter.

If it is a matter of conscience—as we repeatedly hear in this place—let it be on the conscience of the Australian people. Let them express their feelings in the matter. Let them say how they feel in this matter which is pertinent to every one of us 18 million Australians because all of us recognise that sooner or later death will come our way as part of the relay of life, as we hand on to others the great gift of life that we have ourselves.

On the matter of religion I want to say this: I believe in a universal life force which gives us that relay of life, passing on from generation to generation, an essential factor being death. It also gives us intelligence, sensitivity, rights and responsibilities. That is my God. And so it is for me to choose about voluntary euthanasia when I am dying and life has been overtaken by the matter of how to die. My God says that is my choice. Others in this place may have a God who does not give them that choice. Well and good. Abide by your God, but do not force your God on me and I will not force my God on you.

In this great debate we are challenged to back the people of the Northern Territory; we are challenged to back the breakthrough for the whole world which their courage in this legislation, brought forward by Marshall Perron, has given to the world. We are inveighed to back the vote that was carried three times in the Northern Territory Assembly, and which has shown clearly that assembly's commitment to this legislation, backed by the majority of Northern Territorians.

I cannot pass without saying that I see the parallels here with the controversial legislation of the New Zealand and South Australian parliaments 100 years ago when they gave the vote to women; or with the even earlier legislation in the British Parliament, controversial, howled down by many people in society, which gave children the right to education instead of being placed in workhouses and in mines. Also, there is a parallel with the legislation which led to a civil war in the United States which, nevertheless, at the end of that controversy, gave freedom to people who before faced nothing but slavery.

It is about human rights; it is about individual rights and we are challenged in this Senate, as a house of review, and a house of the states, to look differently at what I believe was an aberrant vote and a non‐reflective vote, as far as the Australian people were concerned, for the Andrews' bill. We should overturn it.
Finally, I can do little better than quote from Wes Lanhupuy, the Northern Territorian who had the casting vote with the original legislation back in 1995. This former member for Arnhem said:

After all the debate and controversy, I said to people that I hoped that they would be able to give me the right to exercise my right as an individual. It is not hard to ask for a person's rights as an individual. A man lives his life, whether for or against the law, and irrespective of whether he has received the rights that he has demanded or has had a cheerful life or otherwise. When he is about to make his last request, should we be in a position to deny him that last right which he wants? That is the question which I believe honourable members of this House will have to come to grips with by themselves. . .

With no less charge, we in this Senate are challenged to give people that right, and not to deny it to them. We are charged to have the courage of the Northern Territory legislators. We are charged to respond to the undeniable force of public opinion in this country, and I charge all senators who have not yet made up their minds in this matter to think carefully about that preponderant public opinion—to give the people a say if you cannot make a decision against overriding this legislation, which will set the clock back decades in what is an inexorable move in the global community as well as here in Australia towards granting everybody the right to opt for voluntary euthanasia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Euthanasia Laws Bill, the purpose of which is to stop the killing of Australians in territory hospitals. Euthanasia is the premeditated act of delivering or facilitating a lethal injection with the purpose of ending life. Neither this bill nor the Northern Territory bill is concerned with the withdrawal of life support systems.

SPEECH.PARA: Under euthanasia, a person does not die naturally. Without this bill before the Senate, already passed by a large majority in the House of Representatives, Australians will continue to be put to death and the value of life will incrementally diminish for all of us. Without this bill, the Northern Territory Attorney‐General will table a euthanasia report at the end of each financial year, tabulating in some form the deaths by lethal injection. As the report is handed down, will anyone be heard to cry, `Hear, hear!'

In this parliament we have many reports tabled every sitting day. The time to discuss them is small. Some are weighty and others insignificant in the affairs of the state. But should we allow euthanasia to continue by defeating the bill before us then this Senate will have effectively signed and postdated every euthanasia report to be tabled in the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory as surely as if we were party to the killings detailed therein.

The debate we are having here today is of the greatest consequence for our society and those societies which take their lead from us. It is of the greatest consequence because it is about the value we attach to life, not just as fathers and mothers, husbands and wives, but as elected leaders with national and international responsibilities. It is of the greatest consequence, because the state has revisited its power to kill. By enacting a law which permits the killing of a person or by refusing to enact a law which prohibits it, the state is responsible for that death. The buck stops with us here today. It used to be a state's right to kill, but over the years the ability of nation states to exercise that right has gradually been removed—most notably in resiling from capital punishment. If the state revisits its power to kill, the danger is that the state assumes once more the right to kill.

In the second half of this century, the Australian state has been about increasing the value attached to the lives of its citizens. Overall, great and largely successful efforts have been put into increasing our quality and standard of living, not least by advances in medical research. We value life very highly in Australia, as attested to by the French yachtsman Thierry Dubois, on his amazing rescue from the Southern Ocean earlier this year. He marvelled that we could go to such lengths to save one life—and that life not even one of our own citizens. Did we marvel so much? No. Proud? Yes. But were we surprised at the efforts put in by the armed services? No, because it is an ingrained trait for Australians to go to the last lengths to face any adversity to preserve a life.

Think only of the generosity we show to poorer countries with insufficient food and racked by disease. Think of the rush to aid those affected by international disasters and the courage and sacrifice made by our citizens overseas to assist. Think of the risks taken by our peacekeepers in lands where blood flows freely. Think of the great mountains of wheat grown on our plains—wheat that has been transported to starving mouths across the world. We are a country dedicated to life like no other.

At the penultimate moment of being swallowed by the seas, Thierry Dubois was given his first taste of a universal, life‐affirming mateship. Today, we are considering whether euthanasia fits into the continuity of that Australian spirit. They say that the numbers are close, that this bill to defeat euthanasia will be decided by a handful of votes. This means that each senator's vote now carries greater significance and, as the count draws ever faster towards its decisive conclusion, that the burden on each conscience is heavier. In whose hands will the responsibility rest for tipping the scales one way or the other? It will not lie in the hands of the devout Christians, nor in the hands of the committed euthanasia supporter. Those votes are already in. We may never know the identity of those who will come to assume the role of Solomon on the fate of this bill before us.

But I would like to think—and I am sure the country would like to think—that they will have some of the following characteristics: the quality of mateship, prepared to forsake selfish interests to right a wrong or rescue a life; a prejudice, like Mary MacKillop, in favour of the poor and disadvantaged—who the Senate committee has heard would be most at risk under a euthanasia regime; and, like Mary MacKillop, a persistence to overcome tyrannical rules which stand in the way.

We would hope this group of senators might have the figurative hands of Weary Dunlop, dedicated to healing and encouraging; and the approach to life in adversity as passed down to us from our folk heroes and best summarised as `fight and never surrender'. We would admire them if they applauded the primacy of the urge to work to save mankind from terrible diseases, as exemplified by our Nobel Prize winners for medicine—Eccles, Florey and Doherty. How many Australians are alive today because of their motivation to use all their talents to improve life?

We know they would salute the selflessness of our humble priests and missionaries who found their vocation in neighbouring islands, embracing the life that was in incurable leprosy victims rather than embracing a means to their death.

We know from the House of Lords committee that involuntary euthanasia cannot be ruled out, that lives will be taken without the required permission, that there is no absolute safeguard that every person who dies of lethal injection voluntarily does so without pressure or without feeling the compulsion to self‐sacrifice to ease their family's burdens.

Therefore, will the senators who decide the outcome of this debate have the same determination to save innocent, vulnerable victims from an undeserved and unwanted fate, as the saviours of Lindy Chamberlain had to free her?

I am sure that we all believe that Australia, despite our shortcomings, is at the forefront of the whole world in the equitable treatment of our people, no matter what their colour, gender, creed, age, health or wealth.

How will these special senators, carrying the power of life and death in their hands, assess the compatibility of euthanasia with the need to set an international example of how we treat our vulnerable, indigenous, sick and elderly?For a society such as ours to consider euthanasia, invites the world's scrutiny.

If we take the next step and defeat this bill, we not only stamp the visa for euthanasia to enter mainstream Australian life, but we also invite the rest of the world to reciprocate. If we say to China and Burma on the one hand that they must copy us on human rights, will we also be so proud of our record on euthanasia that we ask them to copy that as well? If we cannot be proud of something, if we cannot boast to the world of the decisions we make in this parliament, then we should decide the other way.

You see, I think the Northern Territory made an error of fact in their decision on euthanasia. They forgot what a beacon we are to the world on the value of life. They did not see our greatness. They were too humble in reflecting on the impact of their little bill and too introspective to see what other, less democratic and less respectful‐of‐life countries might make of it.

Why should history change? Tyrannical regimes are ever anxious for weaker sanctions on the taking of life, ever anxious for tools of fear to oppress minorities and political opponents. If the country that goes around preaching human rights to them says euthanasia's okay, then who is to say it is not? The world will have lost a leader on the side of the angels, which it can ill‐afford to lose.

Euthanasia could be the answer to many questions in the developing world. It will take on an appearance different to its sanitised, sophisticated, computer‐mechanised delivery in the developed western world. Its face would not be recognisable as that which is happening right now in the Northern Territory, but they would share a common ancestry. Is this Senate prepared to be mother and father to even the slightest weakening of the globe's sanctions against intentional killing? What message do we send if we, the self‐styled leaders of justice and tolerance and democracy, take specific action to devalue that high standard of life?

We have a responsibility not just to our state or our country but to the world. It is time to stop being coy about our national identity, and say without hesitation that we are for life, in all its richness, pain, mystery, confusion and diversity. That small group of senators who decide the fate of the Euthanasia Laws Bill before us can look to many precepts in history to guide them. They might remember the motivation of Egypt's Anwar El‐Sadat in his courageous visit to the Israeli parliament because he wanted to further the `sublime position of mankind.' How does euthanasia rate by this yardstick?

The issue of a right to autonomy is frequently raised by those in favour of euthanasia, but perhaps the senators with the casting votes might question the real nature of liberty, as did the influential American jurist, Judge Learned Hand, in the following terms:

And what is this liberty which must lie in the hearts of men and women? It is not the ruthless, the unbridled will; it is not the freedom to do as one likes. That is the denial of liberty and leads straight to its overthrow. A society in which men recognise no check upon their freedom soon becomes a society where freedom is the possession of only a savage few—as we have learnt to our sorrow.

Will these senators think along Winston Churchill lines that our primary objective is to stand up for the `survival for the urge, the impulse of the ages, that mankind shall move forward towards his goal'? Will they decide that euthanasia moves us on towards that goal? Is it not true, as US Defence Lawyer Clarence Darrow argues in his opposition to capital punishment, that `The greater the sanctity that the state pays to life, the greater the feeling of sanctity the individual has for life'?
Euthanasia has been described by Australian palliative care experts as a `violent solution'. Louis Pasteur could have been speaking of euthanasia when he described the two contrary laws which:

. . . seem to be wrestling with each other nowadays . . . the one, a law of blood and death . . . the other a law of peace, work and health, ever involving new means of delivering man from the scourges which beset him. The one seeks violent conquests; the other, the relief of humanity. The latter places one human life above any victory; while the former would sacrifice hundreds and thousands of lives to the ambition of one.
Which of these contrary laws will prevail in the vote on the bill before us tonight? The so‐called freedom to end one's life prematurely is merely the freedom to end your freedom.

In the celebration of the race which is life, renowned US Supreme Court Judge, Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes, on his ninetieth birthday dwelled on what it is like to come towards the end of one's life.

The riders in a race do not stop short when they reach the goal. There is a little finishing canter before coming to a standstill. There is time to hear the kind voices of friends and to say to oneself, "The work is done." But just as one says that, the answer comes: "The race is over, but the work never is done while the power to work remains." The canter that brings you to a standstill need not be only coming to rest. It cannot be, while you still live. For to live is to function. That is all there is to living.
The March edition of the Australian magazine Quadrant contained an article by Denis Grundy, himself in remission for a terminal illness. In it he reasons:

I could not agree that the dying be given the legal right to end their life based on the meaning of life as advanced by the advocates of voluntary euthanasia, because I have found that meaning to be narrowing and inadequate to the goodness of life . . .
We would sacrifice our unconditional obligation to human life to a dubiously rational right to end it.

Then we have the euthanasia participant, Philip Nitschke, a man for whom I fear greatly, who told a conference last week that he was under terrible strain because he gets to know the patients and to like them, and then comes the appointed day when he has to go in and kill them. He is taking on an impossible burden but one created by the state. It is the state that must shoulder the responsibility, not Nitschke. It is the state which has allowed doctors of medicine to get to know and like patients and then follow through with the killing. It is the state which must answer.

BREAK.PARA: As Australians, we have proven ourselves first and foremost `obliged to human life', as Grundy puts it. We have often not acted rationally in our attempts to fulfil that obligation. We have fought against the odds, strived to do the impossible and often succeeded. Our national character is such that we have often gone against orders and rules and the establishment to affirm the value of life and the equal rights of all to that life.

Hence, when all is said and done in this debate, my only wish is that the Senate act in character and view the bill before us with the perspective offered by the first world citizen, John F. Kennedy, in his inaugural presidential address.

With a good conscience our only sure reward, with history the final judge of our deeds, let us go forth to lead the land we love, asking his blessing and his help, but knowing that here on earth, God's work must truly be our own.
Motion (by Senator Brown)—by leave—proposed:
Omit all words after "That", substitute:

"the bill be withdrawn until such time as a referendum has been held on the issue of whether the Australian people support the option of voluntary euthanasia as provided by the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset of my contribution, let me say that I had a very large number of representations on the issue of euthanasia. I have received over 1,300 letters representing the full range of opinion on the bill, although I do think it is proper for me to make it clear to the Senate that the vast majority of those correspondents have supported passage of the Euthanasia Laws Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: While I have responded to each of these letters, I do want to take this opportunity to again thank those who have written for taking the time and the trouble to put their views in writing to me. The correspondence that I have received on this issue has given me a much better understanding of community views on this matter and has certainly assisted me in refining my own views.

Mr Acting Deputy President, all of the representations that I have received have strengthened my conviction that, because views about euthanasia vary so much and are so deeply held, decisions on this matter made by parliament should be made on the basis of individual conscience rather than of party affiliation. I have been a strong proponent of this approach within the Australian Labor Party where I have argued that a conscience vote should apply both on the procedural handling of this bill and in speaking and voting on the bill itself.

If enacted, the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996 will remove the legislative power of the Australian Capital Territory, Norfolk Island and the Northern Territory to enact laws that permit voluntary or involuntary euthanasia. In particular, the bill will override the Northern Territory's Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995 which, under certain conditions, permits physician assisted suicide and active voluntary euthanasia.

This debate, as I see it, is fundamentally about an individual's right to choose. This is not to say that there are not many other issues involved, nor does it deny the importance of those issues. I appreciate, for example, the strength of the religious convictions that many people hold about the sanctity of life. I acknowledge the concerns about the potential erosion of medical ethics. I accept that there are legal uncertainties. And, of course, there is an issue of territory rights.

But for me the overriding principle is that of individual freedom of choice. I believe that we should not deny that freedom to those who are suffering from a terminal illness and may choose death as an alternative to insufferable pain. I feel strong sympathy with the aim of the Northern Territory's Rights of the Terminally Ill Act which this legislation before us seeks to overturn. That aim, in Marshall Perron's words, is to give:

Those who suffer the right to choose a death with dignity, to bring an end to the torture many endure on their death bed, and for that to be done legally, without fear of prosecution for those doctors or nurses who may assist a patient in this desire.

Mr Acting Deputy President, in addition to recognising this right, it also provides individuals with choice, with the option of awaiting an inevitable death in pain or of choosing euthanasia as a means to ending their suffering. The provisions of the act ensure that the choice is exercised exclusively by the patient and there is nothing in the act that obliges anyone to take up the option of euthanasia.

The Rights of the Terminally Ill Act is clearly, in my view, within the competence of the Northern Territory legislature and does not infringe on the Northern Territory (Self‐Government) Act. I do not believe that we should legislate to overturn it and accordingly I will be voting against this bill.

Mr Acting Deputy President, it is a reality that euthanasia in various forms happens now. It is a reality that we neither can nor should ignore. The evidence before the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee's inquiry into this bill was conclusive in this regard. As indicated in the committee's report, a survey of New South Wales and ACT doctors conducted in 1994 by Professor Peter Baume and Emma O'Malley found that 47 per cent of doctors had been asked by a patient to hasten his or her death and 28 per cent had taken active steps to bring about the death of a patient who had asked them to do so. Of these, 81 per cent had done so more than once, 93 per cent still thought that they had done the right thing, 58 per cent thought that the law should be changed to permit active voluntary euthanasia and 46 per cent thought that the law should be changed to permit physician assisted suicide. I am aware that other surveys have yielded similar results.

I do not argue that we should legislate to legalise an activity just because it is prevalent, but when that activity is benign, even in this case when it is merciful and purely a matter of personal choice, I think the fact of its prevalence does become an argument in favour of legislation. The people of the Northern Territory, through their elected representatives, have taken the decision to legalise euthanasia. I believe that decision is reasonable, is justified and I certainly do not see any justification for this parliament to impose a contrary view.

I am also persuaded by the argument that the continued prohibition of voluntary euthanasia, coupled with its prevalence, does not permit proper control and scrutiny. Again, I agree with Marshall Perron, whom the committee report quotes as saying:

It is surely preferable to have voluntary euthanasia tolerated in particular circumstances, with stringent safeguards and a degree of transparency, than to continue to prohibit it officially while allowing it to be carried out in secret without any controls.

There is also the important issue of consent. Evidence given to the Senate committee reveals quite clearly that many end of life decisions, such as those to withdraw or withhold life sustaining treatment, or to administer life shortening pain and symptom control, are currently taken without the consent of the patient. I strongly believe it is preferable that those who find themselves in this situation have the option to make their own end of life decisions. This argument was put persuasively by a Northern Territory nurse, who is quoted in the additional comments made by my colleagues Senator McKiernan and Senator Bolkus in the Senate report. She said this:

My name is Sue Carter. I am a registered nurse. I am speaking tonight on a couple of points that come from my experience in nursing. The first point I want to make is that people make the comment that palliative care works and that doctors and nurses sort things out for patients.

The problem with that is that no‐one consults the patient in the ward about what is about to happen. What happens is that there is a discussion between nurses and doctors generally and a decision is made to "up the morphine", as the comment is. No‐one actually goes to the patient and says, "Look, Mr Jones, you're really suffering here; we are going to up this morphine. The end result of that will be that you will lapse into unconsciousness, we cannot say when, and eventually you will die." Nobody tells them that. So they are not giving their consent to the sort of activity that occurs at the moment, whereas voluntary euthanasia enables the patient to have control, enables them to talk to their families and to make an exit at a time that suits them. For that reason, I support it.
I will be listening to this debate to hear a convincing rebuttal of the argument that Ms Sue Carter puts.

I think it is appropriate that we as parliamentarians take account of community views, particularly when we are dealing with important social issues. It would be foolish of any legislature to seek to impose a social measure or standard of behaviour which was supported by only a small minority of voters, a small minority of the community. The majority would certainly make their views clear at the next election.

On the issue of euthanasia, it appears that the Northern Territory parliament, in legislating to allow it, was reflecting a very substantial majority of the electorate. It also appears that if we were to support the Euthanasia Laws Bill and override the decision of the Northern Territory legislature, we would be taking action that was supported by only a minority of the community. To cite just a few examples of public opinion polling on this subject which were highlighted in the Senate committee's report: a Morgan poll found in June 1995 that 78 per cent of respondents were in favour of voluntary euthanasia; a Newspoll found in July 1996 that 75 per cent were in favour of the practice. Since 1962, when the first Morgan poll on euthanasia was conducted, there has been a consistent and growing majority in favour.

Any discussion of euthanasia brings with it the need to address the issue of palliative care. It is something that has been raised in submissions and evidence before the Senate committee time and time again. Palliative care is critical in the treatment of people suffering terminal illness and, regardless of whether or not they support euthanasia as an option, palliative care must be available to them. I do not believe that any of us would try to stand up here and say that there is sufficient funding for palliative care in Australia today, either for research, training or the provision of care. I hope that the review which is currently being conducted by the Department of Health and Family Services will facilitate some positive change in this area, along with adequate funding.

The previous Labor government recognised the need to provide support for palliative care by providing funding in the 1993‐94 budget to the states and territories for a four‐year program to the value of $55 million. Funds were also allocated under schedule G of the Medicare agreements and through the HACC program. I regret that the current government has cut this funding but I do hope that this debate will facilitate a bipartisan commitment to funding palliative care in this country.

In conclusion, I come back to the fact that what we are debating here is the right of the individual facing pain—extreme pain—and certain death to determine the time and the manner of their own death. I recognise that right and I remind those who do not of the words of Mr Bob Dent, the first person to utilise the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act. In his letter published in the Sydney Morning Herald shortly after his death, he said this:
If you disagree with voluntary euthanasia, then don't use it, but don't deny me the right to use it if and when I want to.

The Northern Territory parliament has recognised this right. In doing so, I think it has responded to community views and the widespread prevalence of the practice of euthanasia, often in ways that currently deny choice to the patient. I believe it would be wrong of us to override the decision of the Northern Territory legislators on this issue and wrong of us to deny those who may wish to make use of the legislation the choice as to how and when they end their own lives. Accordingly, Mr Acting Deputy President, I will be voting against the Euthanasia Laws Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, I am proud to be the only leader of a parliamentary party who is opposing this bill. For the record, six of my colleagues will also vote against Mr Andrews' bill, and Senator John Woodley will support it. Like coalition and Labor senators, our seven Democrat senators have a conscience vote on this bill and, like so many of you, we too have had to agree to disagree as we have struggled to come to terms with what is a difficult and complex issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe very strongly that voluntary euthanasia is a matter in which there is no clear right or wrong, and no clear black or white. Instead I think there are shades of grey and degrees of personal belief and personal experience and most of us can only do our best to come to terms with those. That is why I do not think there is anything to be gained from playing politics with this issue, and there is nothing to be gained from any of the opponents or the supporters of Mr Andrews' bill trying to stake out the moral high ground in this debate.

But it is because I regard voluntary euthanasia as such a deeply personal and individual matter that I feel intensely uncomfortable about being a part of a group of politicians, a small and not particularly representative group of Australians at that, making a decision with such potentially dramatic personal implications. It seems to me to be a very fundamental infringement upon the beliefs, both religious and personal, of others to have a handful of people denying fellow Australians, particularly those who are dying and wish to avail themselves of this opportunity, such an opportunity to choose a swift and dignified death if they so wish.

I do not believe that there is inherent nobility in pain and suffering. I believe we each have our own thresholds, our own limits, our own fears and our own terrors. At the heart of my opposition to this bill lies my belief that I cannot and should not sit in judgment on the limits, fears and beliefs of others.

Now, I am a Christian, although whether I leave this place with any faith after some of the budgets and legislation that we debate in this place is a matter of some concern to me, but as a Christian I acknowledge the difference of opinion about life and death both within the Christian tradition and within other religions. Some people believe life itself is sacred and should be preserved at any cost; others place quality of life ahead of life itself. But holding a particular set of beliefs does not entitle me to impose those beliefs upon others. It does not entitle me to presume that others share my beliefs. Perhaps, most importantly in the context of this debate, I should not delude myself that people's religious or moral beliefs will be changed by legislation.

I do not believe the introduction of a bill which removes the power of the Northern Territory, the Australian Capital Territory and Norfolk Island to make laws permitting euthanasia will stop euthanasia from taking place. It will not stop euthanasia—either active or passive—from taking place for one very simple reason: most Australians believe the right to decide how and when to die is an integral part of their freedom, their dignity and their autonomy as an individual.

When it comes to the crunch, most people want to be able to exercise that right and many will—when their personal limits are reached and even if the very best palliative care is available to them—ask someone. They will ask a relative, a friend or their medical practitioner to help them die. Unless we are asking governments to use this bill to go storm‐trooping through the hospitals, the hospices and people's homes, arresting doctors and their patients, then the only value this bill has is that it forces doctors and their patients back over that border between legal and illegal behaviour and back into a world of secret actions, lies and deceit.

Maybe some senators do want governments to intervene more actively to stop all forms of euthanasia, but I do not believe such a level of interference in these sorts of personal and private decisions is something the vast majority of Australians would support. I think we have to recognise that active voluntary euthanasia is already practised in Australia and that current legal prohibitions do not, and will not, stop some patients asking for help and some doctors from giving that help. It is surely better to have the practice of active voluntary euthanasia out in the open, properly regulated and scrutinised—instead of the secretive and clandestine manner in which it is currently approached.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have to be joking.
—You do not have a monopoly on wisdom in this area, Senator.
—I know I haven't. But you don't know what occurs in real life and real death.
—Well, simply because you are a physician does not make you the expert either.
—No, I am saying you don't know what occurs. You're saying it does.
—Order! Senator Herron.

—We will see. In my view, openness and accountability are the best ways to protect patients from abuse. I also think it is important to note that the Northern Territory legislation is not a carte blanche for euthanasia. It does not compel you to take the opportunity. It is strictly limited to providing a framework for active voluntary euthanasia and it does not extend—despite all the emotive words that are used about doctors of death and lethal injections—to actions taken without a patient's consent.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the legal clarity of the Northern Territory legislation stands in marked contrast to the imprecision and uncertainty of Mr Andrews' bill. There is no consensus on what exactly the Andrews' bill does or does not do in relation to its attempt to take away the Northern Territory's power to make certain laws. There also have been doubts expressed about whether the bill will not also effectively restrict the territory's power to enact laws covering the right to refuse treatment, guardianship, medical powers of attorney and certain passive euthanasia practices. In short, I think you can argue that the supporters of Mr Andrews' bill are replacing a clear and limited piece of legislation with an unclear one—one which will create even more uncertainty in an already uncertain area while still failing to prevent the practices it purports to prohibit.

A lot of people are using the states rights argument. I am not a strong defender of states rights; I believe people have rights, not states. The Democrats have always held the view that the national parliament should not be coy about overriding the states and territories in matters of national interest. Many is the time when we have asked for that to happen on environmental issues, for example.

For that reason, while I have concerns about the appropriateness of the use of a private member's bill in this manner, I do not agree with the view that a state or territory should be able to do anything they like and `damn the national consequences'. I do understand how Northern Territorians feel, but I cannot be a hypocrite by saying that this is the reason I am voting against this bill.

BREAK.PARA: I do find it extraordinary to hear the views of some members of the Liberal and National parties on this particular aspect. It seems to be a case of when you agree with what a state is doing, then you scream or you champion states rights; but when you do not like what they are up to, then you find a nice, expedient reason to back legislation overriding that state or territory's rights. All I can say is that, after this debate is over, we should never ever have to listen to another lecture on the topic of states rights from those coalition members who use this particular reason to justify their position on the Andrews' bill.

I have great difficulty understanding how members of the Liberal Party who champion freedom of the individual and for whom the rhetoric of choice underpins just about all of the legislation we have seen introduced since this government came to power last year, can deny those very things to individuals on this matter. It seems to me to be extremely hypocritical to say, `These are the things I believe in but not on this matter.'

At the end of the day, I can only say that my personal beliefs coincide with the underlying premise of the Northern Territory legislation: that a competent adult suffering from a terminal illness may request his or her medical practitioner to assist in terminating his or her life. I do not believe that anyone—or any parliament—should deny that right to a terminally ill person. I know that many Australians also agree with that premise. It was interesting to see in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday the report of a Morgan poll showing that 77.3 per cent of voters in Mr Andrews' own electorate disapproved of his bill. This is a really interesting test case for representative democracy as well.

I know from the letters I have received that many Australians are unhappy with the idea that this decision is being taken by parliamentarians, rather than by a referendum. I will be supporting Senator Brown's amendment calling for a referendum on this matter. The sad fact is that it is a destined to be a largely token gesture because it is ultimately up to the government of the day to decide which matters they will take to a referendum. I do not think the government would be honest enough to take this one to the people of Australia. I would hope that those senators who are supporting Mr Andrews' bill will at least agree on the appropriateness of putting to a referendum a matter of such importance to the individual rights, lives and autonomy of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Sandy

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I would like to say I feel very privileged to be part of this ongoing debate on voluntary euthanasia. There is much public confusion as to what is meant by euthanasia. This was shown by the previous two speakers when they both cited the apparent high level of community support for euthanasia. Senator Faulkner talked about 78 per cent support in a Morgan poll and 75 per cent in Newspoll. I think there is a big difference between the withdrawal of forms of medical life support and medically assisted suicide.

SPEECH.PARA: The World Medical Association declaration, adopted in October 1987, describes euthanasia as:

Euthanasia, that is the act of deliberately ending the life of a patient, even at the patient's own request or at the request of close relatives, is unethical. This does not prevent the physician from respecting the desire of a patient to allow the natural process of death to follow its course in the terminal phase of sickness.
This was adopted by the 39th World Medical Assembly in 1987.

With this in mind, the scene has been set by the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act, which has focused the media on a few individuals who have been terminally ill and have chosen to end their lives. This has created a diversion from other important issues which now surround the insecure situation of many frail aged, terminally ill and other disabled and seriously disadvantaged members of our community.

This is a conscience vote and, if you cannot bare your soul in this debate, you never will. I think it has stirred the emotions of all of us in the federal parliament; certainly, it has for many thousands of other Australians. After all, there were a record 12,500 submissions to the Senate inquiry and it has generated more letters to my office—mostly handwritten— than any other issue in my 3½ years in the Senate.
