This is a debate not simply about personal experiences we might have had with people close to us dying with a terminal illness, our particular religious beliefs or our views of the sanctity of life. It primarily concerns our making a decision about any government's capacity to play a role in assisting suicide, and I do not believe a government should have that capacity—nor, if it did, could I be sure that it would be able to exercise it safely.

Secondly, I am disappointed that the issue has been forced to the Senate in a way where it can be confused with legitimate constitutional arguments about the rights and powers exercised by the Australian states and territories. Particularly in this case it is the Northern Territory legislation that has brought us to this debate tonight, and I acknowledge Kevin Andrews for being the catalyst—an unpleasant but necessary role.

The states rights argument is simply facile, and I say that having the highest respect for the Northern Territory—their growth, their development, their commitment to building a thoroughly modern Australian society and their commitment to racial equality. All those things are to be commended but, on this issue, they have got it wrong.

To walk away from such a fundamental issue as voluntary euthanasia by saying, `Whilst the Commonwealth has the legal power to override it, we don't have the moral power,' is just not a valid argument. To do so when we have the power under section 122 of the constitution is akin, I believe, to a legal conviction not taking place because of a technicality. When this happens, it brings the law into disrepute.

If we hide behind states rights, we will be bringing the federal parliament—and in fact Australia—into disrepute. I would be a lot happier if I heard those who champion states rights talk a little more about a state's or territory's responsibilities, because I cannot agree that such a fundamental decision as the Northern Territory legislation being passed with a bare majority in a very small legislature is a responsible act. I apologise for that if it is necessary, but it will be difficult to persuade me that the Northern Territory has got it right when others in the world have looked at voluntary euthanasia—full as it always is with subjective checks and balances—and said, `We don't want to go down that track.' It seems untenable to me that not only do we have a law that controls life and death; we have a law that makes behaviour legal in Darwin that is illegal in Adelaide; legal in Alice Springs that is illegal in Albury.
Let us be honest. Vote for euthanasia if you wish, but don't try to obfuscate. You are not making your decision on such a fundamental issue because of your belief in the importance of states rights.

The supporters of euthanasia emphasise that a dying person must have the freedom of choice and the right to get another person to kill them or to facilitate their suicide. Where there is extreme pain and suffering, it is difficult to argue this is morally wrong because euthanasia is not about discontinuing treatment, turning off machines or providing pain relief which hastens death. The less difficult moral question is whether the state can safely legalise such actions and practices, and I believe it cannot.
The AMA, the premier health lobby group, in their position statement on euthanasia in May 1996 opened with the sentence:
The AMA believes that doctors should not be involved in interventions that have, as their primary goal, the ending of a person's life.

I believe the AMA's position is mirrored by the great majority of health workers across the nation. The adopted AMA position endorses the right of patients to refuse treatment and the right of a severely or terminally ill patient to have relief of pain and suffering even when that therapy may shorten their life. Again, I have no problem with that.

The AMA makes special note of the importance of palliative care. I acknowledge the great advances that have been made in this area and, if something good can come out of this wide‐ranging debate, it will be if pain relief and palliative assistance to terminally ill patients is improved.

The AMA suggests this would include the provision that every major metropolitan and regional health care facility have a designated palliate care service for its catchment area, that the teaching of palliative medicine be further developed as an important component of undergraduate and postgraduate training programs and that doctors with an interest in palliative medicine be able to undertake further specialist training. Clearly, the importance of home care for terminally ill people and the importance of helping those who care for those people at home should be acknowledged and supported.

In politics we argue a lot about what we—mostly as political parties, but also as politicians—see as the rights and wrongs in what are essentially grey issues. In other words, the real black and white issues are mostly agreed on, although the general community would not necessarily be generous enough to give us that credit. All politicians argue as if they believe the angels are on their side, but this issue is fundamentally a question about how you see your role of governing in the best interests of the community.

I cannot see that legislating for voluntary euthanasia improves the prospects of the people, and that is the test I try to apply. In fact, I believe it does the opposite. Frankly, my conscience tells me that life is given by a force greater than human kind and it is not for humans to take it away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston, Sen Malcolm

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996, a private member's bill brought before the parliament by Mr Kevin Andrews, the member for Menzies in the House of Representatives. He, like any member of either house, has every right to propose a bill for the parliament's consideration. While not a great number of private members bills are passed into law—13 in the Commonwealth parliament since federation—this bill has been passed by the House of Representatives and now awaits the judgment of the Senate. The purpose of the Euthanasia Laws Bill is to prevent the legislatures of the Northern Territory, the Australian Capital Territory and Territory of Norfolk Island from passing certain laws permitting euthanasia. In the case of the Northern Territory, the bill prospectively invalidates the Northern Territory's Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: In debating the principles of the bill, it is pertinent to outline what is meant by the term `euthanasia'. The word derives from the Greek `eu' meaning `good or well' and `thanatos' meaning `death'. The word, thus, has a literal meaning of `gentle or easy death'. In contemporary debates, however, the word is used with a variety of meanings. Many people use a definition of euthanasia which accords to their particular stance on the issue of euthanasia itself. There is not necessarily anything wrong with that but, in debating the question of euthanasia, it is pertinent to accept that there are various definitions which are used.

There are, however, certain distinctions which are generally accepted, irrespective of how narrowly or broadly the word euthanasia is defined. One such distinction is between active and passive euthanasia. The latter term refers to an action or actions which merely refrain from keeping a patient alive. Active euthanasia involves taking some positive action to end a patient's life, the type of approach used in the Northern Territory's Rights of the Terminally Ill Act.

A further distinction may be made between voluntary and involuntary euthanasia. Involuntary euthanasia involves the taking of someone's life, supposedly in that person's own interests, but in disregard of that person's views. Although most cases of involuntary euthanasia remain undetected, there is little doubt that these cases occur. This type of euthanasia is nothing other than plain murder.

Euthanasia can also be classified as active voluntary euthanasia. In this case, deliberate action is taken to end life where a patient has requested that his or her life be terminated. There is a slight difference between active voluntary euthanasia and what may be termed `physician assisted suicide'. In both cases, the patient has expressed a desire for life to end, but with physician assisted suicide the health professional makes a lethal substance available and the patient dies at his or her own hand. Whichever basic definition for euthanasia is accepted, there is little doubt that the Northern Territory legislation relates to active voluntary euthanasia and, so far, deaths which have occurred under this legislation have resulted from physician assisted suicide.

An important question which must be addressed in relation to the Euthanasia Laws Bill is whether the federal parliament should be legislating to override a law passed by the Northern Territory parliament. Successful passage of this bill would also prevent the parliaments of the Australian Capital Territory and Norfolk Island from passing into law their own legislation similar to the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act. The consequences for the Australian Capital Territory and for Norfolk Island are slightly different from those for the Northern Territory. Neither the Australian Capital Territory nor Norfolk Island has passed legislation similar to that of the Northern Territory, but both hold that they should not be fettered in doing so, if that were their desire.

Each of the three territories has a compelling argument: that if the federal parliament has delegated certain powers to a democratically elected territory parliament, there is a basic contradiction in later limiting that power by preventing that territory's parliament from making laws on a particular issue of public policy.

Due to the time which I have at my disposal, I will not canvass the Euthanasia Laws Bill as it relates to the Australian Capital Territory and the Norfolk Island territory, although many of my remarks will still be pertinent to those two territories. Australians have long accepted that our system of local government is established under state legislation and, from time to time, state governments take actions which affect local governments, in some cases suspending their operation. In a similar way, the territories' powers to legislate lie in the provisions of section 122 of the Australian constitution. In effect, section 122 states, inter alia, that the federal parliament may make laws for the government of any territory.

Under this constitutional provision, the Northern Territory has progressively been given the right to conduct its own affairs. In 1947, a legislative council was established with a minority of elected members. This changed over time and by 1968 there was a majority of elected members.

In 1974 the Commonwealth parliament enacted the Northern Territory (Administration) Act 1974, establishing a fully elected legislative assembly of 19 members. Finally, in 1978, the Northern Territory (Administration) Act was repealed and replaced by the Northern Territory (Self‐Government) Act 1978. The Northern Territory parliament therefore now operates much like Australian state parliaments and the next logical step in the process is for the Northern Territory to be granted statehood.

The Northern Territory (Self‐Government) Act provides in section 9 that the Governor‐General—in practice, the Commonwealth government—may disallow a law passed by the Northern Territory parliament within six months of the Northern Territory Administrator's assent to the law. Whether this provision should still exist at this stage of the territory's development is a matter for debate, but it does prevail and could have been used to disallow the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act.

The fact is that the Commonwealth government of the day was asked to use this provision to disallow the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act. The government declined to use those powers, a senior adviser to the Prime Minister noting in a letter to a Northern Territory resident:

The Commonwealth government believes that the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995 is a valid law of the Northern Territory and it is up to the people of the Northern Territory to express their views on that legislation rather than the Commonwealth.

The Euthanasia Laws Bill, if enacted, would amend not the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act but the actual Northern Territory (Self‐Government) Act 1978. The wording of that amendment would, however, prospectively invalidate the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act.

There is a powerful argument that the Commonwealth should not override an act of the Northern Territory even if the subject matter of that act is controversial. If the Commonwealth parliament does override the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act, what would be next? A precedent would have been established to encourage any elected member of the federal parliament to move that the Northern Territory (Self‐Government) Act 1978 be amended once again.

It is a function of our democracy that the people are able to make a choice as to who should represent them in parliament, and if they discover that their choice was a wrong one then that choice can be changed at subsequent elections. For democracy to function we must accept that the people's collective choice may on occasions be flawed. So too can parliaments make mistakes, but what moral right does that give the Commonwealth parliament to override a majority decision of the Northern Territory parliament, whether that decision is regarded as right or wrong?

It is interesting, however, that in the Northern Territory there are opposing views on whether or not the Commonwealth should intervene. At a forum held in Darwin on 24 January 1997, at which I was present, Mr MacMichael, who introduced himself as chairman of the Darwin branch of the Northern Territory Country Liberal Party, strongly argued against Commonwealth intervention. Among other things, he said:

. . . the Northern Territory is politically mature and it is our Rights of the Terminally Ill Act . . . If we have got it wrong, we should be the ones to correct it . . . I do not believe that in their sincerity of purpose, the people here this evening will want to see the Andrews' Bill carried.
On the other hand, Mr Terry Secker, a resident of the Northern Territory, at the same forum indicated that he had no problem with Commonwealth intervention. Among other things Mr Secker said:
. . . we have degenerated this into a Northern Territory statehood debate . . . We are not a state. We will not become a state while we have got such laws—
that is, the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act—
on the statute books.
It is against this vexed question of whether or not the Commonwealth should intervene that the actual subject matter of the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act must be examined.

In the debate on the legalisation of euthanasia, voluntary or otherwise, many factors are intertwined with the importance our society places on the sanctity of human life. Legal questions, evolving social issues, the role of modern medicine, our personal experiences and moral considerations thread through this highly emotional issue. To me the basic question is whether the state should permit one person to take another's life or assist in the process of suicide. Even if the action is taken with the consent of the person who wishes to die, I cannot accept that as a civilised society we should have so little regard for human life that we could morally support such an action.

Unfortunately, suicides occur daily, and many of us have been touched personally by having a loved one or a close personal acquaintance take his or her own life. But what do we do when we have the opportunity to try to prevent a suicide from occurring? Do we let a person jump without trying to talk that person into reconsidering his or her actions? Do we leave the motor running when we find someone overcome by carbon monoxide poisoning? Most of us would not. If we can prevent the loss of life we do so. This being the case, why are we willing to allow medical practitioners to assist in ending the life of those who want to suicide? Those who advocate that this should be allowed to occur speak of the pain and suffering of the patient, that palliative care is unavailable or is not providing relief and that there is no hope of recovery.

Surely a significant factor in our health system should be the adequate provision of palliative care. And why should we not question whether a life may be taken when a misdiagnosis has occurred and recovery would have been possible? Why are we prepared to delegate the act of taking life or the assisting in the death of a patient to the medical profession, to which most of us entrust our health for the greater part of our lifetime?

Indeed, suggestions that medical practitioners be permitted to take life lawfully could have disastrous consequences for the practice of medicine. Traditionally patients and their families believe that an important factor in any recovery process is the certainty that medical practitioners will do everything in their power to help patients regain their health. If euthanasia remains lawful in the Northern Territory and, indeed, spreads throughout the Commonwealth then the familiar bond between patients and their doctor could be undermined, leading to a loss of confidence in the medical profession.

I accept that some in our community have no problems with questions surrounding physician assisted suicide. On the other hand, I do. Life is too precious to allow it to be taken away deliberately by human intervention. Unlike some less civilised countries, Australia no longer has the death penalty for serious offences against society. We certainly do not condone horrific crimes, but we no longer believe that the state should take the life of those who transgress against its laws. And in doing so we no longer risk taking the lives of those who are completely innocent of any crime, something that has tragically occurred in the past.

No comment on this bill would be complete without expressing fears that the failure of the Australian Senate to pass the Euthanasia Laws Bill could place the Australian people at the potential risk of becoming victims of what may be termed the `slippery slope' or `wedge' arguments in future law‐making in any of the states or territories. These arguments assert that if the taking of human life is allowed even under the guise of a merciful end to life, a dangerous wedge would be introduced which places all human life deemed to be `unworthy' or `undesirable' in a precarious condition.

What rights to life would be available to the severely disabled, the disfigured or the intellectually handicapped? The list could go on with other categories being regarded as under threat. While some may contend that this is fanciful and even alarmist, it is a possibility which must be addressed. No-one knows for certain whether such unpalatable consequences may flow from the legalisation of euthanasia, but I do have deep reservations that it is possible.

In coming to a decision on this matter I must do so against my deep respect for human life. I cannot accept that it is morally correct to legislate that the life of fellow human beings may be taken by legal means. I accept that if physician assisted suicide is not available, suicide will, regrettably, still occur. Yet where we can prevent people from taking their own lives most of us would do so.

So that leaves me with a dilemma. I cannot accept the legalisation of euthanasia, voluntary or otherwise, nor do I find it easy to accept that this parliament should override an act which was passed by the Northern Territory parliament. I have three options in relation to the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996. I can abstain, I can vote against this bill to maintain the status quo in the Northern Territory or I can vote for the bill in the knowledge that my vote could be crucial in casting aside the Northern Territory's Rights of the Terminally Ill Act.

I accept the fact that some members of the House of Representatives abstained when this bill was voted on in their chamber. Similarly, I accept that there could be some in the Senate who may do likewise. I respect their decision, but I do not believe on this issue that abstention is an option about which I would feel comfortable. I believe that I must make a decision either to support or oppose the bill. Despite my grave concerns about this parliament's interference with legislation that has been duly passed by the Northern Territory parliament, I will vote in favour of the Euthanasia Laws Bill. To do otherwise would be for me to reject the lifelong belief that I have held that we must resist all attempts to devalue the preciousness of human life.

In conclusion, I would like to mention that, as I am sure has been the case for many senators, I have received a veritable avalanche of mail and personal representations on the Euthanasia Laws Bill. A great many proposed that I should vote for the bill. Others argued otherwise. I am sorry that the resources of my office were not sufficiently adequate to respond to all those representations. Nevertheless, I accepted without reservation the sincerity of those representations either for or against. I trust that those who asked me to vote against this bill will similarly accept that I did respect their views, but that my vote will be one which sincerely reflects my views on the sanctity of life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the Northern Territory legislation was actually introduced into the Northern Territory parliament in February 1995 and was assented to in June 1995. It is now 1997. I do not say that delay rules out intervention by this parliament, but I do say that this was an issue in 1995. It could have been an issue at the election in March 1996. It was not taken up then. It may have been preferable, if this parliament wanted to exercise the courage of its convictions, if it did so at the time knowing an election was around the corner. There is nothing that focuses the mind of parliamentarians and politicians and brings them closer to the face of public opinion than an election. That did not happen, but that does interfere with the Senate's right to do as it chooses on this bill. It does give some indication of not so much bona fides but the will behind those who now move this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I took the opportunity recently to read a particularly interesting book prior to this debate. It is called the Godless Constitution and is subtitled `The case against religious correctness'. It is about the constitution of the United States and what is described as a crucial intellectual connection between what is a Godless constitution—that is, the constitution of the United States—and a God fearing people.

It highlights deTocqueville's belief that religion is essential to the health of republican liberty and his concern that religion should not be too close to political institutions and to topical political controversy. Its place was in directing the customs of the community and in regulating domestic life. The risk for religion, it is argued by the authors and deTocqueville, is that once it gets enmeshed in the ever changing world of politics it will be degraded and cannot possibly hope to take hold. Public and political opinion is not stable but volatile. Political argument can be rough and tough and that is not a bad thing, but religion deserves a safer, stronger and more respectful place. That clearly is in the hearts and minds of citizens and not in legislation.

I have always believed, to speak in a colloquial way, that any God is looking for converts not conscripts. Equally, I have always been taken with the response in A Man for All Seasons of Sir Thomas More to the exclamations of his daughter and son‐in‐law. It states:
Margaret: Father, that man's bad.
More: There is no law against that.
Roper: There is! God's law.
More: Then God can arrest him.

The question for me is: should voluntary euthanasia be legal under Australian law? I think it should be. Your life is not mine to take, but what I do with mine should be between me and my God and no-one else.

The book outlines, among other things, the path of one Roger Williams, whom I had not heard of until reading this book, who is described as an `ardent Puritan' and a `godly minister' who was banished from the Massachusetts Bay Colony in 1631. He went off and set up a new colony on Rhode Island. He was banished because he was determined to separate church and state as we have done. His view is described as being that `religion might influence how people behaved in all areas of their lives, but what they did in the name of God had no claims upon their neighbour's conscience'.

Perhaps the risk—and it is a risk—of ever claiming that God's work is being done through legislation is highlighted most aptly by the remarks with respect to Lincoln and the Civil War. I, again, quote from the book:

During the bloodbath that was America's Civil War, Lincoln puzzled over the fact that both sides prayed to the same God, read the same Bible, and claimed to do His will. Lincoln suspected that if God wanted anything it was that the leaders who were entrusted to manage a fragile, precious experiment in democratic government remember that what is most assured about humankind is its collective and individual moral imperfection.

Protecting the separation of church and state often earns rebuke. Thomas Jefferson—it was a surprise to me to discover—who regularly went to church and contributed money to churches, was labelled by many clergy as an infidel, an atheist, a deist or a devil. He apparently kept his own bible with Greek, Latin, French and English translations and added in his own views. He rejected, nonetheless, a call to publish the bible and beat the `infidel' tag, saying:
I have ever thought religion a concern purely between our God and our consciences, for which we were accountable to Him, and not the priests.
The book concludes that the framers of the American constitution recognised:

. . . that social peace and personal happiness are better served by separating religious correctness from public policy. The success of what they proposed should still fill us with amazement and gratitude.

Having read the book, I ask the question: by what right then can anyone claim that, because they believe it is wrong to take your own life, you may not do so with any dignity? I cannot find one. I could not look a terminally ill person in the eye and say that, if they wanted to end the gift of life—and it is that—they would have to throw themselves in front of a train, jump off a building or fumble around and find the right mix of legally available drugs. The decision whether to take your life or not is surely the most personal you can make.

Palliative care for many, mercifully, is a viable alternative, but it does not always relieve the pain. When it does, it can bring other negatives in its place—incoherence, unconsciousness, incontinence, and the list could go on. It seems odd to me that we can agree that a life support can be turned off, bringing an end to life, but we cannot bring ourselves to let someone bring an end to their own life. Many claim that those who are terminally ill are assisted now by the medical profession, and I believe that. I simply believe that the patients ought to be empowered to make that final decision themselves.

I do not always agree with Jeff Kennett, the Premier of Victoria, and least of all his numerous missives from the luxury of a government with the control of both houses, but I do agree that voluntary euthanasia is all about choice, and perhaps Mr Kennett will introduce in Victoria similar legislation to the Northern Territory model. Were that to happen, we would have the same situation that we have now—that is, people can go to one state and follow their choice and go to others and not have it.

So no-one need vote for this legislation thinking that they will necessarily guarantee a harmony of laws around Australia on this issue, because they will not. Mr Kennett's view has been made very clear, and one would assume that, on the basis of that view being clear, it might not be long before Victoria or another state chooses to follow suit. You choose if you want to end your life. The Northern Territory legislation allows you to get assistance—proper, expert, up-to-date medical and technological assistance—in doing that yourself, not for someone else to kill you.

I will not take up the time of the Senate with the details of the published letters from two of the four people who have chosen to use the Northern Territory legislation; excerpts from two will suffice. This is a much publicised quote from Mr Bob Dent:
If I were to keep a pet animal in the same condition as I am in, I would be prosecuted.
And no doubt he would be. I quote Janet Mills from my state:
At least now I can legally and honestly end my life. I hope this law survives and is able to help others like me who have found the suffering has become too great.

I know that I would not be able to look Mrs Mills in the eye and say that I thought the Commonwealth should act to stop her exercising the choice the Northern Territory law gave her. I could not say, `If you want to end your life, you'll have to do it the hard way,' and I could not say that I would support a law that would force her to continue to endure her suffering. Others may be comfortable with that outcome, but I am not.

A society that forces terminally ill people to live without dignity is not a humane or compassionate society. We have the means to let people, if they choose, go gracefully. We ought not deny them that dignity or that choice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to share with the Senate what has been a long and very hard journey in the back of my brain. I do not appreciate Mr Andrews provoking me to take this journey, but I have to say that I am not unhappy with what I have learnt on the way.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to share with you some of the ideas and issues that I have deliberated about, some of the steps on that journey. There are three main areas that I want to talk about: informed consent, private versus public ethic, and then I will turn to the legislation.

Before I turn to those points, there are a couple of other things I would like to make clear. First of all, I must declare a conflict of interest here—not that I am alive and will one day die, though I suppose that is true for us all, but that I am a member of the medical profession, and as a member of that medical profession my first‐up response was to be annoyed, irritated and even angry that the medical profession had been drawn into this debate. If people wanted to suicide, why did they not do it, why did they not just get on with it? They do not need prescriptions for fatal drugs, medications—why involve the medical profession?

As I thought along this line, I realised that in some ways the medical profession had actually asked for it. Over the last 10 to 20 years doctors have very often used high‐tech medicine, surgical procedures, on very old or frail or terminally ill patients to the point where the communities cried in a very clear voice, `Stop. Leave my relative, leave my child, leave my mother, leave my father, alone. Let them be. Let them die in peace. Let us give people pain‐killers, palliative care. Let them be comfortable.'

Indeed, I can share with the Senate a patient I had once in St Vincent's Hospital in Melbourne who was dying of a very serious liver disease. He was admitted to the hospital and put into intensive care. Some time later, at his insistent request, he was removed from intensive care to a ward where he came under my care, where I got to meet and talk with him.

He actually had some great lines. He said that being in intensive care with tubes in every orifice was not exactly a comfortable way to live and, besides, the other patients were not very talkative. It was very interest ing to meet the sense of humour in such a patient. He also said that the other people in the intensive care unit kept dying, which was not very encouraging either; he felt it was setting an example for him and that he preferred, please, to be taken away from all that high‐tech paraphernalia and to be admitted to a general ward to let things take their course so that he could at least live out the rest of his life in some sort of dignity. He felt that being hooked up to everything that worked in intensive care was anything but dignified. I might tell you, although you must have gathered, that this patient was of course acutely conscious. He was one of the many that gave me some pause about what the medical profession was doing in a lot of that intervention.

I believe that as a result of the community crying `Stop' on behalf of their family and relatives we have seen what are called something like the `natural death acts' in various parts of this country that have given people legislative authority to choose their treatment and management as they died of terminal illness—and the right sometimes to say they wanted no extraordinary treatment, to have machines turned off and so on.

I realise that although I might have at first been a bit annoyed about the involvement of the medical profession they had indeed asked for it, that is, for their participation in this area. And I also believe it is entirely proper for the medical profession to be involved. They do have special knowledge and a special responsibility. They do not have—as one of my colleagues was arguing last night—any claim to extra wisdom. In passing, I say that I think it is much harder for the nursing profession, who are very often much closer to the person dying and their family and yet have much less say in the management of that situation.

Next I want to turn to a point of considerable concern. I have received, as everybody else has, hundreds, if not thousands, of letters about this issue. One argument put by a number of writers was that a conscience vote for a Labor Party person was not a real conscience vote at all; it was merely a release from being bound to Labor Party policy and we could make up our own mind. I was bemused by the desperate logic of this argument—used, I might say, by both sides of the debate—and somewhat saddened at the presumption that I or any of us would not be making an informed choice or that indeed if we voted along party political lines that was not an informed choice either.

However, it did challenge me to then do some thinking about what an informed choice is and how we make one. It requires, I think, that we seek a broad range of relevant information and in the light of that information make our decision. We seek the information from facts, opinions from people whose judgment we value, wise folk, parents, church, culture, social mores, historical example, community values and of course much more.

It is the weighing up of the facts and the arguments that is the harder part. Assembling the facts is not much of a problem, but weighing them is very hard. How do I rank and order them? How do I decide what matters most? In this case, is my decision only a matter for me or do I need to include what matters also, very importantly, for others? As a politician can I make a decision that takes no regard of the impact of my decision on the rest of the community? To what extent are the consequences of any decision of mine, as well as I can assess them, part of that information that I need to take into account in making an informed choice?

For example, if I conclude that the euthanasia question overrides the territory rights question and I therefore disregard the territory, what does that mean for future territorial legislation and what does that mean for me next time such a question is debated in this place? On the other hand, if I decide that the question of territory rights is the critical issue, am I effectively excluding myself from an informed choice on the question of euthanasia? I believe in fact that that conundrum is the worst feature of this bill—a choice between two very significant areas of principle.

I heard a number of senators argue that they believe in state and territory rights but not now or not in this instance. I do not find that a persuasive point of view. To me, the spuri ous argument that Northern Territory law is for all Australians and therefore the Northern Territory has stepped outside its jurisdiction is not a sufficient argument.

I am sure that somebody will point out the incorrectness of my next comments, but I did think, in deliberating about this, that when Queensland abolished death duties and the rest of Australia rushed to Queensland to die we did not argue that away on the basis of state rights. Thank you. At least Senator Tambling smiles.

The better argument in this case is to say that the protection of life and the protection of territory rights are two very important principles. How are people going to rank them? People should simply say, `I believe the question of the right to life outranks state rights', or `I believe vice versa.' I believe the Commonwealth has the power to intervene in these laws in the Northern Territory, but we should ask why it needs to and whether this is a proper use of Commonwealth powers. The fact that you can do it does not mean that it is necessarily proper or appropriate to do it.

The last part of my deliberations was about comparing the public and the private ethic. There are people and politicians who cannot allow any difference between their private ethic and their public stance on issues. They are not persuaded that a public ethic takes into account a different range of issues, or that, for example, they might properly consider the differing beliefs of people in a pluralist society or the common good—as apart from that of an individual—in making a decision of informed conscience. Others believe that it is proper and reasonable to vote for a decision in the public realm, even if it does conflict with individual beliefs and behaviours. There are many examples: one I came up with was the question of contraception. Many people would decide that that was not appropriate for them to use but, equally, they might be able to vote that other people should have the opportunity to use it.

Let me now turn to the main points about the legislation. The debate has been very widespread in the community and very wide ranging in its arguments. To my mind, much of the debate has been misinformed, mislead ing and very illogical. First of all, there is the argument of the slippery slope—that, if we start here and oppose Mr Andrews's bill, we will continue on and on and the next thing we will see will be widespread involuntary euthanasia: the killing of the elderly, the disabled, the unwanted and the weak.

This bill has absolutely nothing to do with involuntary euthanasia. It has absolutely nothing to do with killing people without their consent. It has absolutely nothing to do with killing people by doing deals between relatives and doctors. There is absolutely no reason why you could conclude that this legislation would lead to any of those steps. This legislation is focused around the right of the patient to choose. In all of those examples—the killing of those who are disabled or defective in some way—no argument has ever been led that they are based on or around patient choice. The slippery slope line is a completely contrary argument and, therefore, completely spurious.

I find it breathtaking that people who would argue the slippery slope line would then say, by way of defence, `We don't need to worry anyhow—lots of people are finding an easy way to death through palliative care.' At the moment, the practice is that many people receive lethal injections of pain‐killers. But that is not the intention. The intention is to relieve pain, not to kill people, but it is widely accepted that those injections do—as Senator Vanstone spelt out—lead to the death of the patient. So we are saying, on the one hand, that we oppose a clear law that allows patient choice but, on the other, that we support a current practice that is not patient centred but doctor centred.

The palliative care argument is about a doctor choice, not a patient choice and if people are serious about the content of, the quality of and the right to life, they should be very shocked about the number of people who are being killed in the name of palliative care. I am told the difference is in intent: the intention is to relieve pain and not to kill the patient and, therefore, there is no need for this legislation, because this practice is within the current law. If that is the case, it is not going to be affected by the Northern Territory legislation. The current practice will be able to continue.

So where is the rub? The rub is that this Northern Territory legislation brings into the open the truth of the situation and the truth of the choice the patient is making. The Northern Territory legislation is up‐front and honest. It is very restrictive in its application and has many safeguards built into it. It provides legal authority for the dying patient to determine the time of their death. It is not about relatives or the doctor making that decision.

So far in the Northern Territory it has not been about the doctor killing anyone either: all the deaths have been suicides provided by the patient themselves. It is true that they have been assisted, but the actual ending of life has been an act of the patient themself. If it were possible, I would prefer to see the Northern Territory legislation amended to allow only for patient‐driven suicide, but I understand that sometimes—due to frailty or other impediments—the capacity to terminate life is beyond a patient.

The more I have heard the arguments and thought about the issue—and I have thought about it at great length—the more it has become clear that the Northern Territory legislation is enabling and not prescriptive. No one is compelled to use it, but, should they so choose, they have the weight and the dignity of the law to support that decision.

I note with some interest that the House of Representatives vote was 88 to 35 in favour of the Andrews bill. That is very interesting because it is so different from the community view expressed in polls, letters from constituents and so on. As is often the case, the community is way ahead of the legislators—even the Northern Territory legislators. I have heard it argued in this place that the people in the community, when they participate in the polls, do not quite know what they are voting for or expressing an opinion on. That is particularly offensive to the community.

The people in the community are very clear—certainly the people that I understand and have spoken to on this. They believe that they support the right of people to decide on their treatment and pain management, on the right to refuse special interventions or high‐tech medicine. They support the right of people to choose the time of their death if they are dying from a terminal illness and are in intolerable pain and discomfort. They are also very clear that they do not support relatives or doctors making that decision without the patient's involvement and consent. The community, it seems to me, is very clear about where the line is drawn. The Northern Territory legislation, which I believe gives a fair effect to that community decision, allows public scrutiny of such decisions. As I have said, it sets very restrictive criteria of how it should be effected and it does depend on the patient making that decision.

To die with dignity surrounded by friends and family—that is what most terminally ill people want. Most will and do choose palliative care. A small number will exercise their option under the Northern Territory legislation. But in the end, what is the difference here? Is it better that people die as a result of large doses of drugs administered by their doctor to alleviate pain rather than as a result of a large dose of drugs designed to alleviate pain administered by themselves? I have come to the conclusion that, in this legislation, it is proper to support the right of patients to choose.

One thing that I was very struck by in reading the many, many things that I did read in deliberating on this issue is an article called `The continuing Northern Territory euthanasia debate' by Richard Ottley and Jackie Dempsey in the journal of the Medical Defence Union of January 1997. It describes the state of play and what has happened to this point, including the court challenge to the Northern Territory Supreme Court. It quotes a comment of Justice Angel who, as a dissenting judge, found in favour of the plaintiffs in that Supreme Court decision that the Northern Territory act was valid. His quote reads:

In my view, the heads of power in regulation 4 of the Self‐Government Regulations, whether read liberally or restrictively, give no warrant to the legislative establishment of institutional termination of life other than as a punishment.

The rest of it does not matter to me. We have a history that says we could establish an institutional termination of life for punishment, yet tonight we are deliberating on whether or not we can a have an institutional termination of life not as punishment but as part of peace and palliation. I find the choice very compelling, that we have moved on from institutional legislation of the termination of life as punishment to allowing the prospect of terminally ill patients to determine the time of their own dying.

Finally, I think it is important for us to acknowledge that none of us can know the intent of that person. None of us can know what is between that person and his or her conscience, that person and his or her God. If intention says that it is alright in palliation to assist a person with relief of pain that might indeed cause death—often does—and that intention is the thing, then I do believe we should allow the dying person the same dignity and the same respect of their intention without our judgment. I will be voting against the Andrews bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —That was an interesting contribution. It puts me in mind of the observation by the 17th century French philosopher Blaise Pascal in Pensees when he said that there is sufficient light for those who desire and seek the light and sufficient darkness for those who are of a contrary disposition. I do not propose to speak for very long. I do not suppose that I could throw much more light on the subject than has been thrown on it in discussions on this matter over the years. But I do recommend to those who have not read the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee's report on the Euthanasia Laws Amendment Bill that they do so, because there is a great deal of information in that report which would throw light on the subject and which in fact go to the points that have been raised by Senator Crowley—if she would only read it.

SPEECH.PARA: At 10.05 p.m. on 25 May 1995, 13 of the 25 members of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly voted to support a euthanasia bill which was strangely entitled the Rights of the Terminally Ill Bill. For the first time in the world, the deliberate and intentional killing of one innocent adult human being by another was legalised by an act of parliament—for the first time in the world.

Stripped of all its euphemism, euthanasia occurs when the doctor, not the illness, kills the patient. In fact, the Northern Territory law recognises this. The Northern Territory law does not change the law for the patient; it actually changes the law for the doctor, enabling him to kill. At a time when civilised countries throughout the world are abolishing the death penalties, politicians in the Northern Territory, by one vote, have instituted a licence for the doctor to kill. At a time when political, medical and community concern about suicide abounds, those Northern Territory parliamentarians, through their legislature, have legalised assisted suicide and promoted a culture of death.

True compassion means caring for and suffering with another person, not putting that person to death. In this utilitarian, excessively individualistic and hedonistic society, the value of suffering for personal growth and for the opportunity to love and to serve is ignored. The experience of having one's wife die of cancer in one's arms and of one's mother, a long‐time Alzheimer's patient, also die in one's arms confirms the knowledge that life is for more than this earth. The person with whom life and love had been intimately shared does not cease to exist.

We all need to understand the difference between euthanasia and the undoubted right of a terminally ill patient to refuse overburdensome and disproportionate medical treatment. That is dealt with in the report. Euthanasia should also not be confused with measures to relieve pain, such as the responsible use of analgesics. Unfortunately, if euthanasia becomes accepted and becomes law, as it is in the Northern Territory, the demand for resources needed for good palliative care will be stifled.

Just a few weeks ago one of my sons, who works in a nearby aged care centre, told me that even now some of the residents ask him if they are really being a burden. Some of them do feel that they are a burden, particularly on their relatives. How much worse will they feel if euthanasia legislation is enacted? Many of them will feel pressured to make a deadly choice. The question will be raised in their minds. Yes, you might say this is voluntary euthanasia, but the question will be raised in their minds, and will inevitably be raised in their minds, as to whether they should do something about unburdening people, particularly their relatives. That is a question that should indeed be out of the question for those people and for all others.

The former South Australian Governor Sir Mark Oliphant told the ABC AM program last year that `. . . there are too many people who are now no longer part of humanity, as it were, still being kept alive in homes and even in their own homes by their relatives'. He told of a scientist friend who `should be dead and he's not. He just loves to be alive and to be a damned nuisance to all his friends and relatives . . . I think he's cluttering up the world at a time when he should not'. All I can say about that is: will it become a crime to love life and not want to be forced to leave it?

We have had evidence given to the committee relating to the slippery slope—very telling evidence indeed. We have been given evidence by, for example, Disabled Peoples International who are very concerned about this piece of legislation as to what it might do ultimately to persons with disabilities. I do not need to go into all of that material because it is in the report.

We should ask ourselves this question: who will be affected most by the decisions of those 13 Northern Territory politicians? I believe it will be the marginalised, the sick, the frail aged and those who lack self-esteem, and not just in the Northern Territory. The push for euthanasia through all the states has been buoyed by that decision.

As I said, that decision of an elected parliament was the first of its kind in the world. It has been suggested that we should not attempt to override the Northern Territory legislature, even though that particular piece of legislation will potentially affect all Australians and certainly affect those people who choose to go to the Northern Territory. So it does affect other Australians besides those in the North ern Territory. The key issue is whether we in this parliament have a very valid reason to, in effect, overturn the Northern Territory legislation.

I want to say to the Senate that I am wearing the badge of the Northern Territory. I am quite honoured to wear the badge of the Northern Territory. I was born in the northern part of South Australia. My grandfather happened to be the boiler attendant for the old steam train in the Finke, which, as you know, is near the border of the Northern Territory and South Australia.

I might say that there are quite a few Harradines around the place and most of them are Aboriginals, which is something that has not been brought up in this particular debate. I noticed Senator Kernot wondered why I voted a certain way in respect of the Hindmarsh Bridge; she presumably did not know what I just mentioned.

But what I want to say about the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory is that all of the Aboriginal evidence that was given to the committee was against euthanasia. One of the most telling pieces of evidence came from the person who was appointed by the Northern Territory government to go around the Northern Territory Aboriginal communities to teach them about the fact that the Northern Territory rights of the terminally ill legislation was voluntary. He came to our committee and asked our committee to overturn the Northern Territory legislation.

He, himself, actually had no problems with the rights of the terminally ill legislation, but he came before us and asked us to overturn it because, he said, the very existence of the Northern Territory legislation presented a danger to the health and wellbeing of the Aboriginals of the Northern Territory, because they were likely to become afraid of presenting themselves to medical doctors, clinics and the like. Now that is all in this report. I do not think it has been adverted to yet; it may well have been. I think it was adverted to last night, but I have not heard it tonight. It is a very important question when we are considering this legislation because the Commonwealth parliament, under the constitution, has a specific and special duty in relation to Aboriginal people by virtue of the referendum that took place on that matter.

The Northern Territory legislation threatens to undermine the cornerstone of society, which depends on the inalienable nature of the right to life of every individual human being. This inalienable right was enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights agreed to by the international community following the Nazi horrors. That is another reason why I believe that we should pass the Euthanasia Laws Bill, which would overturn the Northern Territory legislation—because I approach this matter from a human rights perspective.
The preamble to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights says:
Whereas recognition of the inherent dignity and of the equal and inalienable rights of all members of the human family is the foundation of freedom, justice and peace in the world.

Then the first two rights are: everyone has the right to life and everyone has the right to liberty. And they are inalienable rights. Let us take the right to liberty. No legislature can legislate to approve of a person selling themself into slavery. And the right to life is inalienable. No legislature can approve of a person requiring another person to take that person's life. But that is exactly what the Northern Territory legislation has done.

People have said, `It is a democracy. It is a democratically elected place, the Northern Territory legislature—they have their rights.' Other people, and Senator Brown, have said, `Let's have a referendum about it.' What I say about that is this: you have to deal with these matters on the question of principle. Either the right to life is inalienable or it is not; either it is equal and inalienable or it is not. In my view, and, in fact, in the view of the international community, it is inalienable; otherwise the very foundations of civilised society begin to crumble.

As to referenda: if you had had a referendum in Tasmania on capital punishment after Port Arthur, you would have had an overwhelming vote for capital punishment. If I had been in the state parliament, do you think I should have gone ahead and tried to move for a return to capital punishment? Certainly not. As a longstanding opponent of capital punishment, certainly not. I take the same view here because I believe that it is barbaric and it is barbaric for a legislature to legalise one person taking the life of another innocent human being.

So a referendum is not the answer. Similarly, the polls are not the answer. I repeat: the Northern Territory legislation threatens to undermine the cornerstone of society which depends on the inalienable nature of the right to life of every individual human being. That inalienable right, as I mentioned before, is enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. On that inalienability rests the edifice of laws which seek to protect the lives of human beings. From that inalienability flows the human solidarity needed to achieve justice for all—the reverse of legislation whereby the value of life is eclipsed and a culture of death is inculcated.

In the higher name of human rights, which transcends state and territory rights, the Commonwealth parliament has a duty to render the legislation of the Northern Territory inoperable by passing the Euthanasia Laws Bill which is currently before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the legalisation of assisted suicide, which is what the Northern Territory act is all about. I note that, at times in this debate, the supporters of that legislation have tried to characterise this debate as being a battle between conservative Christians who are seeking to impose morals on the rest of the community versus progressive upholders of human rights and individual freedom. I reject that. I certainly make no apology for the fact that I am a Christian, but I believe that putting the debate in that context is not only flawed but also simplistic in the extreme.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that honourable senators are well aware of my background of service in the Uniting Church, but my position on this bill is based on a broad commitment to human rights and social justice, which is one of the core principles of the Australian Democrats and the reason why I am proud to belong to that party. As a member of the Democrats, I am committed to defending and supporting those who are most vulnerable and to doing what I can to prevent our society moving further down the road where rampant individualism and survival of the fittest becomes the dominant ideology.

Let us not forget that those who oppose the Northern Territory act are not just a bunch of extreme Christian conservatives. I received a letter today from Gallarrwuy Yunupingu of the Northern Land Council emphasising the strong opposition of the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory to the euthanasia law. He states quite unequivocally—and the same evidence was given to the committee—that that law has already affected the standard of health care to indigenous people of the territory. The vast majority of groups who work with disabled people and the aged have also expressed opposition, as do many in the psychiatric and palliative care professions.

On the other hand, I understand the compassion which drives many supporters of euthanasia, but I believe their compassion is misplaced. In effect, the philosophy which underpins the support of legalised euthanasia is the philosophical and ethical equivalent of economic rationalism.

Many years ago, I spent some time at the Aboriginal community of Millingimbi, an island off the coast of Arnhem Land. Whilst I was there, I observed the community as it surrounded with love and support one of its old men who was dying—a very significant man. It was an inspiring experience to watch the care with which his people prepared both him and themselves for his departure. He died a few days after I left. His was truly a good death.

I contrast this experience with my time as a chaplain at a number of aged care institutions. For example, I remember well visiting an old woman at Pleasantville, a Uniting Church aged care complex in Brisbane. I visited her regularly for one reason, because the nursing staff were unable to get her family to come and see her. Even as she was dying, repeated phone calls were ignored by her family. In the end, she died alone.

Our western culture has great problems with death. It deals with death often by denial or by trying to pretend that death is not a natural part of the process of living. In some ways this debate is a symptom of the same problem. In my example, the Aboriginal people viewed life, dying and death as different parts of the same process which needs to be celebrated in the presence of friends, family and community.

Yet one of the most common arguments used in the debate about death and dying is to infer that the process of dying is wholly negative. Clearly, there are some forms of death which are negative—the example I gave about the elderly woman at Pleasantville underlines this. However, even in the face of these negative experiences, we need to examine the source of that negativity. Is it inherent in the process of dying or has it more to do with our culture's attitude to death and the refusal to take seriously our responsibility to care and support those who are dying?
In an article in the Brisbane Courier‐Mail newspaper on 23 June 1995, quoted by Dr Preston in his book Understanding Ethics, Elizabeth Hepburn wrote about the process of dying. She says:

A philosophy which sees suffering as absurd will lead us to seek relief in the form of euthanasia. We must decide whether we will interpret the dispossession we experience in the face of suffering as absurdity or mystery. If we opt for mystery we will be committed to living life to the full in both ecstasy and sorrow.

I believe Elizabeth Hepburn puts her finger on the problem. The devaluation of human life, indeed of animal life and the natural environment, which is so much part of western culture can lead to the conclusion that life has no meaning and death is an absurdity. I do not accept this view of life, just as I do not accept the extreme form of individualism which also pervades western culture and which devalues any sense of community and mutual responsibility.

This individualism is also the foundation of economic rationalism which plagues our living and so devalues humanity that at its end we may be regarded as nothing more than unproductive burdens. The phrase `unproductive burdens' sounds like something the government might use to justify restricting welfare benefits to unemployed youth. In fact, it was used by the former Governor‐General in a speech about death and dying to the Royal Australian College of Physicians in 1995. Mr Hayden, speaking of his apprehension about the nature of his own death, referred to society's need to divest itself of those older people who no longer fulfilled any useful purpose by their living. He said:
there is a point where succeeding generations deserve to be disencumbered . . . of some unproductive burdens.

I am sure the Governor‐General believed he was proposing a positive obligation of the elderly to society; that is, not to live beyond the point at which they cease to contribute anything to society. I note what Mr Hayden was saying. I am sure he spoke sincerely but I reject completely his philosophy, just as I reject the notion of assisted suicide as contained in the Northern Territory bills.

In some ways, the word euthanasia is a misnomer when it is used for voluntary assisted suicide. I repeat what Senator Colston said earlier that `euthanasia' comes from two Greek words, `eu' meaning good, whole and well‐being, and `thanatos' meaning death. I believe that the death of the old man at Millingimbi was truly a good death. The kind of euthanasia proposed by Bill Hayden is anything but a good death.

This leads me to a consideration of individual rights. In this debate there has been a lot of talk about the right of each individual to choose the time of their own death. This reminds me of the economic rationalist credo that each individual should have the right to earn as much money as they wish. Both approaches remove the link of the individual with the wider community and society. If one is to accept the economic rationalist approach of total individual freedom which underlines the idea that each person has the sole right to choose to die, when and how they wish, why should this right be limited to the terminally ill? What about those with permanent, but non‐life threatening illnesses or disabilities? Should they be able to demand the right to be assisted to die? What about the depressed teenager who cannot find a job or who feels that life has no meaning? Should they have the right to demand to be assisted to die?

Surely it is discriminatory in the extreme to allow only those people with terminal illness es the legal right to be assisted to die and refuse this so‐called right to others who also may wish to die. It is no secret that many young people feel disconnected from society and have trouble seeing a meaning or purpose in life. Indeed, this applies not just to young people. I believe this is clearly linked to the onset of consumerism and individualism. At a time when so many are expressing concern about the increase in youth suicide, what sort of message are we sending by continually asserting that it is some fundamental right to kill yourself whenever you feel like it?

Let me address the issue of the right to choose. The argument for choice is based usually on arguments about the loss of quality of life, especially for older people. Again, Bill Hayden clearly described this position in his speech. He said:

I view the prospect of the closing days of my old age with apprehension. I have visited too many nursing homes, seen too many vegetating old people who were once vigorous, vivacious personalities now dependent on their middle‐aged children . . . This loss of personal control, of autonomy, of human personality for me would destroy my sense of human dignity.

We can empathise with his feelings. Again, I disagree with the position, while empathising with the feelings that Mr Hayden had. His position is the same as that taken by Dr Peter Singer in his book Rethinking Life & Death . Singer argues that medical practice and the law have moved away from an absolute position which proposed to treat all human beings as of equal worth to a new ethic which proposes to recognise that the worth of human life varies. I recommend that people read Professor Singer's book closely. It is mostly well argued, given the limitations of its utilitarian framework. Professor Singer is one of the most prominent and most enthusiastic advocates of euthanasia.

I heard what Senator Crowley said but there is a slippery slope and it is very clearly set out in the evidence given to the committee. Part of that slippery slope, although it may be a well‐worn one, I would like to underline in Professor Singer's book where he clearly advocates that babies born with severe disabilities should be considered less important. He also proposes an arbitrary line of one month of age as a time when they become of equal value to other humans. This is the problem with the quality of life argument; that is, who decides where you draw the line and how you define quality of life?

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of us wouldn't go down too well.

—That is true. On the other hand, I would like to put to you some of the points of view put by Dr Noel Preston in his book Understanding Ethics . Noel Preston is a long time colleague and friend of mine. He argues that while contemporary bioethical practice involves quality of life judgments, it is critical that this approach be situated within the wider framework of reverence for life. Dr Preston warns that without this wider framework, choices made exclusively on the basis of whether or not life is worth living may lead to horrific consequences for individuals and a breakdown in the sense of community solidarity. He writes:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no reason why these bioethical dilemmas cannot be judged within a dialectic between sanctity and quality of life considerations, which results in respect for life. Indeed, the failure to do this may invite grave social errors, such as a careless depersonalising of the elderly, the deformed or the disabled which will, in turn, erode the bonds of covenantal integrity upon which the moral community depends.

Further, Preston argues that quality of life judgments fit within contemporary social attitudes which elevate individual rights over the obligation to extend a duty of care to all members of society. In particular, the need to care for those who are most vulnerable in society is discounted within a society where physical prowess or economic productivity is the measure of individual worth.

Let me address the issue of the conscience vote. Much has been made of this bill being a conscience vote. This has given us all the freedom and also the responsibility to think through the issues involved more deeply than sometimes may be the case. The Australian Democrats provide their parliamentarians with a conscience vote on all matters. However, it is important to note that Democrat policy is silent on the issue of legalising assisted suicide. The policy of the Democrats supports the right to die with dignity, and I believe the position I have taken is totally consistent with this policy.

I note that my time is rapidly running out, so I might just address a couple of other issues. The issue of states rights has, I think, been canvassed fairly widely, but let me add my concern about those who have all of a sudden discovered states rights in terms of this bill and some of those who would perhaps say states rights do not count in this particular instance. I have been perfectly consistent since I have been in this place. I have always maintained that human rights are far more fundamental in every case than states rights.

Senator Brown voices his outrage that this bill overrides the rights of people of the territory to determine their own affairs and some members of the coalition are happy to override that principle on this occasion. I wonder whether their consistency needs to be challenged at this point. I hope that those members of the coalition might be willing to consider the national interest and human rights ahead of states rights in future cases.

I also believe, as a number of speakers have mentioned, that we really do need to address the issue of euthanasia laws in other states because I am sure there will be a push, if the Andrews' bill is carried, for other states to an enact legislation in the future. I believe that whether it is by referendum—although, I am not in favour of that—or by legislation in this place, we really ought to address the issue at a national level so that it is clear in terms of all the states and territories rather than simply, as we have done, singling out the laws of one territory in this debate.

Finally, let me address the issue of legislating for euthanasia. There are many other issues, but others will canvass those. Even if one believes in voluntary euthanasia, the issue remains: should such a belief be enshrined in legislation? Related to this question are a number of others. Is there not a danger that legalised euthanasia will put undue pressure on medical practitioners and nurses, subtly altering their duty to care? Is it possible to devise a law which is not open to abuse? If euthanasia is legal, might not an old person feel pressured to die because they are burden to their relatives? These are important questions.
I will conclude with a quote from the 1994 report of the Select Committee on Medical Ethics of the House of Lords. I do not have time to read all of it but just their concluding remarks:
We believe that the issue of euthanasia is one in which the interest of the individual cannot be separated from the interest of society as a whole.
(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to speak on the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996, or what has become known as the Andrews' bill. My contribution tonight will not be a long one, but one which comes from deep inside me in considering the issues. To follow a man of the cloth in this situation does make one feel rather humble.

SPEECH.PARA: The first issue I want to deal with is what is loosely thrown around as states rights. I think the issue of states rights is so often misused to make a particular point, because Australia is a federation. One of the reasons we have enjoyed so much stability in this country and have been so receptive to so many people making this country their home is the strength of that federation. The strength of that federation is epitomised by what is carried out in this chamber of all the parliaments of Australia.

Certainly, in my time here almost every principal piece of legislation that has been passed here has been a modification to a much stronger view than had emanated out of the other place. We talk about state rights, but it is a lot more than state rights. It is our federation that makes Australia a very tolerant place for dealing with the many issues that we face. I would suggest that without federation, this country would be nowhere near as tolerant as it is.

Some time ago, I made a public statement that I would not be supporting the Andrews bill. In saying that, I would like to thank the many people who have written to me and phoned me on this issue. I have heard almost every conceivable thought or view on this legislation. I have certainly been canvassed more widely than I have been on any other piece of legislation that has ever come to my attention either pre coming into this chamber or since I have been here. So it has certainly raised an enormous interest. As to the community push, I measure from the mail that I have received in my office from all around Australia and overseas that 70 per cent of the people who have written support the Northern Territory legislation.

Having been brought up in a very strong, strict Anglican family, the position one adopts is often dependent on one's life experience. In relating to federal legislation such as this, one can go no closer than to one's own mother and father and the life experience one has had with them. Unfortunately, it took my mother nearly four years after a series of strokes over a short period of time to pass away. That was a very difficult, harrowing experience. Equally unfortunately, my father was killed in a car accident. He just disappeared in a flash.

I remember well that when the police arrived at home I was drafting sheep. I asked, `Can I finish before I talk to you?' I thought I was about to have a summons issued to me. Then they explained to me what had happened. Both those very different experiences certainly had a big impact on my reaction to life and death and how things happen.

The other close experience I have had with death concerns my younger brother, the fifth‐born in our family. I was in Bali, and my sister was there. We got news that Phillip had had a massive stroke and passed away. My friends in Bali took me up to a Hindu temple. I prayed with them, and that is probably the most peaceful experience of my life. I had never been in a Hindu temple before that and I have never been back since. One day I will go back when I feel comfortable about doing it again.

These experiences impact very much on one's thoughts when one deals with life and death. Having had these experiences, and dealing with the Andrews bill, I wish to read a short statement that I made some time ago with regard to this piece of legislation. It reads:

BREAK.PARA: After much discussion and reviewing of the issues at hand, I have decided that I will not be supporting the Andrews Bill if in fact it ever reaches the Senate.
Of course, it has now reached the Senate. It continues:
I am strongly of the opinion that this is a very discriminatory Bill—discriminating against people—
I underline the word `people'—
in the Northern Territory.

Whilst I accept the fact that the Commonwealth has the law on its side to overturn the legislation passed by the Northern Territory Government, I believe that in this case it would be a misuse of the power. If the Northern Territory Act had been passed by a State Government, the Commonwealth would not be in a position to over‐ride that State's right.

From that point of view, I would certainly agree with what Senator Woodley had to say, that this has to be looked at more from the national angle rather than the angle of the Northern Territory. But that could well be a debate for another time. It continues:
I think it is wrong for the Federal Government to treat the citizens of a Territory differently to the citizens of the States.

I would like to make it clear that my decision is based on the fact that I firmly believe each State and Territory has the right—both moral and legal—to pass laws which affect its people. Any intervention by the Commonwealth must be able to be applied consistently right across Australia—
That is, to all citizens. It continues:

The very basis of Federation was that the State's would retain their autonomy—they would retain their rights. As Australia has grown as a nation, I feel it is incumbent on the Commonwealth to treat the Territories the same as the States.

Finally, I want to canvass one other issue—it has received some publicity, and I have had a number of phone calls about it—that is, my voluntary decision to pair with former Senator Woods on this position after he had spoken to me.

He explained to me at that time that he had a very strong view, which I respect, and it is the opposite of mine. As we all know, at that time Senator Woods was under a degree of pressure. He said to me, as I am sure he would have said to somebody else had I said no, that he would stay here until after the vote was taken on the issue if he could not get a pair. It seemed to me that it would have been unreasonable to force him to stay here under the unfortunate circumstances that he found himself in.

I say to those people who have phoned me, and I have had a couple of letters about it, that in no way has it changed my position on it. Nonetheless, at that particular time I believed—I still do—that that was the right thing for me to do in the circumstances which former Senator Woods had found himself in. I do not regret it, but I would like to put on the public record an explanation for it.

Once again, I say to the very many people who are very sincere on both sides of the debate that I appreciate very much the letters that I have received, the phone calls, the comments and the discussions. It certainly has made me a more understanding and wise person.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this important euthanasia debate and will not speak for long. I know that there is a large number of speakers, and it is important that this debate be progressed as quickly as possible. So I plan to keep my remarks shorter than I would like to on what I regard as a very important bill.
