SPEECH.PARA: This debate has been conducted in a way in which I have never seen a debate conducted in this parliament. You have to go back a couple of decades at least, perhaps to 1974, to find a similar debate where there was a conscience vote on legislation. I was not around at that time. I cannot remember the way that debate was conducted, but it seems to me that, despite the very high emotion which this issue correctly arouses in a large number of people, the debate has been conducted, for the most part, in a very civil manner. People have respected the views of others who do not share their position on the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996. In that sense, it has been quite an historic debate, whatever the outcome of the vote may be.

I wish to make my position quite clear. I will be supporting the Euthanasia Laws Bill. Before I state my substantive reasons for that, I would like to look briefly at the issue of states rights which, I think, has correctly caused concern amongst a number of people. Senator Brown, Senator Woodley and Senator Crane have raised that issue. My record would show that I have always been a strong supporter of states rights. Senator Brown, I noticed that you, on a number of occasions, have been more than willing to support the use of international treaties to override states rights. That is your view and I do not intend to exchange political point scoring on that matter in the context of this debate.

Coming from a position of a person who strongly supports states rights, I do not find myself in the dilemma which other people, who perhaps have an equally shared view on states rights, do. I may be wrong. I may have a similar position to Senator Abetz on this issue. It seems to me that the Commonwealth does have express constitutional power regarding its territories. Section 122 of the Australian constitution confers a power on the Commonwealth to make laws for the government of any territory. I am a states righter and a constitutionalist. It is sometimes very easy, in relation to states rights and human rights, to suggest that that somehow resolves a difficult dilemma.

The reality is that it is important for a constitution to be supported and, if we wish to change it, that that constitution be changed in the appropriate manner. I have no difficulty on that issue regarding states rights issues. The Northern Territory is a territory. I know many people in the territory feel passionately about this issue, on both sides, but the Commonwealth does have a constitutional right in relation it.

Equally, I think that the Northern Territory is as populous as a single federal electorate—a bit more perhaps—and it has enacted a law which affects the rest of Australia. Patients have already come from elsewhere in Australia to access euthanasia under the Northern Territory's laws. So I do not find difficulty on the so‐called states rights issue.

On the substantive issue—the appropriateness of the bill—one of the things which has turned my mind on this issue is that, in the first place, I have never met a doctor who has not explained to me that palliative care and the use of drugs can often shorten life. That, in fact, occurs very regularly in the society as people seek to treat the sick and dying. I am not a medical doctor. My understanding is that it may not be satisfactory in 100 per cent of cases, but in the vast majority of cases there is, and should be, treatment for the sick and the dying to alleviate pain, and the use of drugs to alleviate pain will often shorten life.

There is a vast distinction between what I regard as current practice and perhaps giving a lethal injection or ending a person's life in a precipitative manner. The Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee report suggested that the intention is the key factor and said:

Dying is a natural process and all people have a right to refuse treatment. But that is not euthanasia. Nor is the administration of substances intended to alleviate pain and discomfort which have the `double effect' of hastening death.

Many believe that the current position which exists might be enhanced by legislation to legalise voluntary euthanasia. In the first part, it will only serve to vastly complicate the doctor‐patient relationship from one of healing and withdrawing treatment, perhaps where requested, to providing active assistance in suicide on request. Many doctors are quite rightly asking: what would flow from this?

Equally, Madam President, I find myself in some agreement with Senator Woodley about the slippery slope which he referred to. I am concerned—and one of my colleagues who raised this with me some time ago may well have spoken on this—that the right to die provided under the Northern Territory law may well turn into a duty to die. That is the slippery slope to which I do not propose to lend any weight.

Death and particularly of death from a prolonged disease or injury has a devastating effect on families. No-one would deny that. It arouses quite appropriately huge emotions. There may be tragic cases—and other speakers have given examples of these—where undue pressure might be applied on patients so that they feel that they do not have the right to die but a duty to die.

I conclude by saying that this is an important debate and it is appropriate that this parliament engage in this debate. This debate has been conducted in a fashion which I have not seen before in this parliament and which I certainly welcome. Senators can reflect on this very serious and weighty problem and come to a conclusion, and perhaps a conclusion which differs from their colleagues, but nonetheless respect for different views is retained. For those reasons, I will be supporting the Euthanasia Laws Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —There are five principal points which I wish to outline in relation to the Andrews bill. Firstly, I will be voting against the Andrews bill. Secondly, I believe the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act contains the proper safeguards for both terminally ill patients and medical practitioners and so deserves my support. Thirdly, I accept that, as the constitutional laws of Australia now stand, the Northern Territory has the right to draw up and pass legislation dealing with the life and death of its citizens. The Commonwealth does indeed have the right to overturn their legislation. If the Northern Territory were a state the Commonwealth would not have that right. This is a strange anomaly for our citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: Fourthly, I do not agree that the states and territories should have the power over life and death. I think that the Commonwealth constitution is the only place in which the absolute human rights and obligations of Australians should be determined. Issues such as control and power over life and death should be solely within the prerogative of the Commonwealth. They are not at present. Fifthly, the forthcoming constitutional convention provides the perfect opportunity for the power over life and death to be raised and considered as a possible amendment to the Commonwealth constitution.

Control and power over life and death is a most fundamental matter. One thing this euthanasia debate has emphasised, apart from the tolerance and civility of our society when encountering issues as deep and as serious as these, is that society does deeply value life and is deeply engrossed by death. Neither war nor capital punishment nor abortion nor birth policies can ever be dealt with without the upmost gravity and care.

BREAK.PARA: Medical and scientific advancements have enhanced the opportunity for previously infertile couples to reproduce, which is a control over life. Equally important advancements in medicine have enabled medical practitioners to considerably prolong the life of patients, including terminally ill patients. These medical achievements have led us to question the use of drugs to control the time of death.

Considerable research, statistical evidence and studies reveal that both passive and active euthanasia is widely practised in Australia. This is despite a lack of comprehensive legislation in all states in the case of passive euthanasia and despite illegality in the case of active euthanasia. All Australian jurisdictions make some sort of provision for dealing with passive euthanasia and for dealing with suicide. In two states and the Australian Capital Territory there is legislation which sets out guidelines for the withdrawal or withholding of treatment for terminally ill patients. There are also common law rights which make some provision for patient control over death. Essentially, it is legal for a competent adult to refuse medical treatment at common law.

Active voluntary euthanasia however is criminally sanctioned in law. It is a criminal offence in all Australian states and territories to deliberately act to bring about the death of a person. For as long as the practice and beliefs of medical practitioners and Australian citizens who practice euthanasia remains inconsistent with existing law, it undermines our legal system and denies us the opportunity to debate the ethics of this issue. It also generates a climate of secrecy which is inherently risky for all parties. If we continue to pretend that active euthanasia is not already practised, we will be denying ourselves the opportunity to debate the ethics and to set standards and limits that may be legally sanctioned.

At the moment, active voluntary euthanasia is something akin to prostitution in our society—we know it goes on but many like to pretend that it does not. With euthanasia such a climate is conducive to risk: firstly, for medical practitioners who may be subject to prosecution, although the courts have generally treated so‐called mercy killers with considerable leniency; secondly, for patients who may be coerced into assisted suicide.

While I have real worries about active voluntary euthanasia, I have a very strong belief in the right of an individual to voluntarily choose their own destiny. I am therefore willing to support a system which is carefully constructed and establishes proper safeguards for those involved. I believe that the Northern Territory's Rights of the Terminally Ill Act satisfactorily enacts safeguards which protect both the terminally ill patient and the medical practitioner.

In terms of our federal structure, control over issues of life and death is given to both the states and the Commonwealth. The power over life and death that our governments can exercise concerns six areas. Only one of these is the sole prerogative of the Commonwealth.

Those six are: firstly, war—the Commonwealth has a sole prerogative there; secondly, capital punishment—that can be exercised by both the Commonwealth and the states; thirdly, abortion—Commonwealth and states; fourthly, euthanasia—Commonwealth and states; fifthly, birth control, such as contraception or methods of population control—Commonwealth and states; and, sixthly, birth promotion, such as IVF—both Commonwealth and states. Under the present Australian federal constitutional system, we cannot avoid the fact that states and territories do have the power to legislate on these issues. Their constitutional power has to be recognised and accepted. This is not to say that I would be reluctant to contemplate a constitutional change to this power, far from it.

In my view, in Australia—with its small population and fairly homogenous society—fundamental human rights issues, such as control and power over life and death, should be solely within the province of the Commonwealth, not the states or territories. I would welcome, therefore, a referendum or constitutional convention to change the situation by placing fundamental human rights prerogatives within the exclusive preserve of the Commonwealth constitution. It is our pre-eminent constitution. It is higher law. It does, and should, stand above the subordinate and supporting and complementary constitutions of the states.

This objective should be pursued as part of the proposed amendments to the Commonwealth constitution to be considered at the constitutional convention in November this year. In this way, these rights and powers can be determined by the people of Australia by referendum. These sorts of matters have to be determined by the people, and in this way so could this issue of euthanasia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —Death is life's final momentous event. It can come upon us softly and sweetly. It can be the end of a cruel and protracted process during which pain and suffering sap our human resources and drain our will to live. If our particular fate is to experience a journey towards death full of agony and anguish, should we be barred from seeking a kinder and shorter one? After all, we would be doing no more than winning by human intervention what many of our fellow citizens have the good fortune to gain by natural causes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory of Australia passed the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act on 25 May 1995 and amendments were made to it on 28 June 1996. The statute gives a person facing a cruel and painful death the right to choose an easy one. He or she can have the help of a medical practitioner if that doctor is willing to provide it.

The Legislative Assembly possesses the power by which it passed the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995 because of the Northern Territory (Self‐Government) Act, a statute enacted by the federal parliament in 1978. Four people have lawfully met their deaths pursuant to its provisions since 1 July 1996 when it came into operation, and in each case Dr Nitschke prepared the killing process. Now the Commonwealth legislature is debating the Euthanasia Laws Bill, which proposes to remove that power.

The member for Menzies, Mr Kevin Andrews, introduced a bill into the House of Representatives on 9 September 1996. The effect of the federal parliament passing it will be to override a valid exercise of power by the democratically elected Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory and to make euthanasia a crime there no matter what the circumstances. There are good reasons for rejecting the Euthanasia Laws Bill. Are there better ones for passing it?

The intentional killing of a human being is an elemental event. It is a momentous act. Its gravity should never be discounted. That it may be common in the world does not make valid its endorsement. Dying is more than a physical transformation for the individual facing death. Generally, the process evokes spiritual, cultural and social responses to it both from him or her and from a wider range of people.

Any death is a communal concern. The manner of its coming influences society's perception of how things should be, of how its laws should operate, of how its culture should develop, of how people should live together and of how readily killing should be countenanced. John Donne wrote in 1624 that:

No man is an Island, entire of itself; every man is a piece of the Continent, a part of the main; if a clod be washed away by the sea, Europe is the less, as well as if a promontory were, as well as if a manor of thy friends or of thine own were; any man's death diminishes me, because I am involved in Mankind; And therefore never send to know for whom the bell tolls; it tolls for thee.

These words have been quoted again and again since they were written over 350 years ago. They have the ring of truth. On 14 May 1971, in delivering his decision in an action by the state of Victoria against the Commonwealth, the Chief Justice, Sir Garfield Barwick, said:

I have observed elsewhere that the Constitution does not represent a treaty of union between sovereign and independent States. It was the result of the will and desire of the people of all the colonies expressed through referenda to be united in one Commonwealth with an agreed distribution of governmental power.
He went on to say:

Thus though by their union in one Commonwealth the colonists became Australians, the territorial boundaries of the former colonies were retained for the purposes of the distribution of governmental power and function.

Unlike those regions which are now states, the Northern Territory was never a self-governing colony which entered into a process to federate with the others and in so doing surrendered powers to the Commonwealth. It has never been the subject of an enactment pursuant to the provisions of section 121 of the constitution. Its status, though great, is less than that of the states.

There are 148 seats in the House of Representatives, any one of which contains approximately the same number of voters as do any of the others. In the Northern Territory, there are enough electors to justify it having one member in Canberra. These are the same limited number of people—and good people—who choose the Legislative Assembly, which passed the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995. That legislation has grave ramifications for all Australians. Given this, should the democratic rights of all voters throughout the Commonwealth be treated as subordinate to those of the relatively few who live in the Northern Territory?

The specific entitlement of territorians to self‐government rather than their general democratic rights may provide the strongest argument for rejecting the Euthanasia Laws Bill. Where the Commonwealth parliament has for two decades encouraged in territorians the reasonable expectation that they are to be masters of their own fate, some may argue that it has exercised an arbitrary power when it in effect vitiates an act passed by their assembly. There are reasonable and compelling reasons for the federal legislature to act on this occasion.

The Rights of the Terminally Ill Act deals with a central issue of life, namely, whether anybody should ever be allowed to bring it to an end by an act of intentional killing and, if so, under what circumstances. Within the Northern Territory itself, there is great unease and contention engendered by the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act. Its second reading was delivered by a margin of a single vote. A great proportion of the indigenous people there are much disturbed by it being part of the law under which they live. And so are many from other communities.

BREAK.PARA: The Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee held an inquiry into matters to do with the euthanasia bill. It and its secretariat have done much to ensure that the present debate is a good and fruitful one. They deserve thanks for their outstanding work. The inquiry showed that expert opinion both in Australia and throughout the world is fundamentally divided on the merits of euthanasia. People generally are riven over the issue. Given this, it is poor public policy to have the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act operating in the Northern Territory as near lone legislation existing anywhere in the world.

When the Northern Territory assembly passed the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995, no medical practitioner there nor anywhere else in Australia was facing prosecution for any offence allegedly committed by him or her in facilitating euthanasia. As far as is known, none was under investigation in respect of such a matter. This is in spite of evidence put before the Senate committee that medically assisted euthanasia has occurred on a significant number of occasions in contemporary Australia.

Prosecutors hold a discretion as to whom they will proceed against. On 13 September 1996 Mr Rex Wild QC, the Director of Public Prosecutions in the Northern Territory, gave advice to the Attorney‐General about the euthanasia bill. It contained the following paragraph:

As a matter of strict law, no medical practitioner would be entitled to involve himself in any way with a conscious decision to allow a patient to die if the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995 is invalidated. That is not, as I understand it, the intended result of the Northern Territory Legislation. In what circumstances a prosecution would be launched, given the width of the prosecutorial discretion, is another matter.

Since Bushells case in 1670, juries have had a constitutional right to return the verdict they consider appropriate. They are judges not only of the facts but also of whether or not in all the circumstances a crime has been committed.

In the context of the present debate, prosecutorial discretion and juries provide better means of dealing with hard cases than does legislation. Of course I do not support euthanasia in any event, but where hard cases are put forward it is to be remembered that, for those who do believe in euthanasia, then in the interests of good public policy it is better for those cases to be dealt with by prosecutors and juries rather than by legislation.

A statute of any parliament giving state approval to an act of deliberate killing is a chilling instrument. I would like to emphasise that. Where the state chooses to give sanction to killing and where we as legislators approve of that, then there is a sea change in the sort of society we legislate for. Legislative creep is a common occurrence. As a number of speakers before me have said, there is too high a risk of it happening in the present instance to allow the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act to continue.

I give some examples of where there has been legislative creep in this parliament over the years. In the chamber I see Senator Patterson who, I must say, in the face of my opposition, raised questions about how the tax file number would be used and how the Australia card might spread if it or something like it were to be allowed. I thought it could be confined and I think Senator Patterson would agree that the tax file number is more and more commonly used.

Another example is the spread of the use of telephone tapping. We were assured when I first came into the parliament that if we allowed a particular authority to use it, it would not spread beyond that. It has spread, and the use of tax file numbers and telephone tapping is now accepted much more readily than when legislation allowing them was introduced.

A goodly proportion of Australian citizens including me hold religious, cultural and social beliefs which reject euthanasia. A person's stance on a particular matter should not be labelled invalid simply because it is based on his or her faith. Faith can engender wrongs and injustices but it has underpinned some of history's paramount civilisations, much of its pre‐eminent art and science, and a great deal of its prime law. In the present instance, I see my beliefs in respect of eutha nasia as meeting the demands of good public policy. In other words, I am saying that my instincts, the whole of my being, if you like, revolt against the idea of euthanasia.

I cannot allow that to be the sole factor in deciding whether or not I will vote for the Andrews legislation. But it is a starting point that I can use to then test my beliefs against the evidence and against the situation as I find it. In this case I have found that the two coincide. I am reassured by that because this debate—when we look at it—is not between a group of people who say that whoever wants to undergo assisted suicide can, and, on the other side, a group of people who say that that cannot be done. In other words, the debate is not between those who would allow assisted self‐killing and those who would not. It is between those who would allow it in a very limited class of cases and those who would not allow it at all. That reassures me because it is not only my instincts but the instincts of nearly everybody who will take part in this debate tonight that people should not be allowed to surrender their lives too readily.

If we really believe that people should have a choice to die, why should we not allow the young and the healthy to die and to have people assist them? And why should that assistance be confined to the doctors? Why should that assistance not be given by whoever is an efficient death dealer? When you look at the principles that are in contention here, we are not talking about broad rights. People here are not saying, `There should be a right to die; there should be a right for people to kill themselves; there should be a right for people to assist others to kill themselves if they so want.' That is not what people are saying. They are saying that in a very limited class of cases there ought to be a right to die.

If people are saying that then it means that everybody in this debate gives great value to life. It means that everybody in this debate believes that there ought to be protection of other people's lives even when those other people want to kill themselves, except in a very limited number of cases. If people do say that the sanctity of life is such that it should be protected even where the young and the healthy want to kill themselves then why do they draw the line where people are terminally ill? And why do they draw the line for people who are sane, who have a self‐perception? This bill, as Senator Murray says, is a very restrictive bill. Why is this bill restrictive? It is restrictive because people are frightened, people are scared, people are terrified that if this thing is allowed to get away where is it going to end?

People are struggling to define where they will allow self‐inflicted death to occur. This very narrow, confined permission is itself perhaps the greatest argument against any death being permitted under the circumstances where somebody assists the suicide of somebody else. I will be interested to see if those following me in this debate get to their feet and say, `This is a universal right; anybody should be able to kill themselves, and anybody who is willing to help him or her do that should be allowed to do it and there should be no ramifications.'
The benefits provided by the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995 are far outweighed by the good which will come from its invalidation. The Senate ought to give passage to the Euthanasia Laws Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —The Euthanasia Laws Bill and its effect, if enacted, on the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act call for a dispassionate examination of two fundamental principles that lie at the heart of the kind of society in which Australians wish to live. First, there is a moral question. Second, there is a legal question. The first question calls for reconciliation between the rights of an ordered, principled society to ensure that human life is not deliberately extinguished, and the autonomous right of an individual to bring to an end a life which for medical reasons is unendurable. That such a person has a legal and moral entitlement to bring his or her own life to an end is unquestionable.

SPEECH.PARA: The public policy question is whether society should permit a consenting person who is unable to end his or her own life to request and obtain the assistance of another person to terminate their life. As a matter of public policy, the state has an overwhelming interest in protecting the weak, the vulnerable and the differently abled—sometimes described as a burden on society.

In a pluralistic and diverse society life is not protected at any cost. For example, most Australian states have enacted legislation dealing with brain death. At common law, patients have the right to refuse medical treatment even if that treatment may prolong life. Medical treatment can be withdrawn or withheld from both competent or incompetent patients if that treatment is futile or burdensome. It is assumed by health workers and families involved that doctors are not acting unlawfully if they administer pain relieving drugs to a terminally ill person which have the so‐called double effect of hastening the death of the patient, provided the intention is to alleviate pain and not bring about the patient's death.

Advances in modern palliative techniques are truly impressive, and if readily available meet the needs of most terminally ill patients for an easeful death. Although views differ as to whether palliative care is universally successful in alleviating pain and distress, it may be assumed for the purposes of argument that there are a small number of dying patients—said to be between two and five per cent—in unendurable physical or physic pain that palliative care cannot sufficiently ease. Amongst that number are those who wish to be killed deliberately and rapidly within the confines of the law rather than being allowed to die more slowly within the existing pragmatic framework of palliative care.

Assuming once again for the purposes of argument that sufficient safeguards could operate to protect the vulnerable and that consent is fully informed and freely given, the question is whether society should yield to that expression of individual choice or whether we as a society are justified in denying to a few fellow citizens assistance for the form of relief they seek. Are there risks to society collectively that outweigh individual freedom of choice to end a life in this manner? I have come to the view that extending end of life options to include a formal regime for voluntary euthanasia or physician assisted suicide does pose appreciable risks to the way our society is presently ordered and is not in the public interest.

I can readily appreciate that when confronted with the question, `If a hopelessly ill patient in great pain, with absolutely no chance of recovery, asks for a lethal dose so as not to wake again, should a doctor be allowed to give a dose or not?', a great number of Australians would answer `Yes'—motivated, as most of us are, by compassion for the hopelessly ill and the desire to alleviate individual suffering. For law makers, however, the proposition that deliberate killing if certain conditions are fulfilled should be excepted from the general prohibition against murder raises broader implications for society than does endorsing the right to freedom of choice of a small number of individuals who want assistance to hasten their own death.

The law moulds and shapes values and attitudes as much as it reflects and reinforces those values. To legally sanction a regime for terminating human life challenges the ethical underpinnings of the law which strenuously protects human life. It sends a powerful message that some human life is not worthy of that protection. Legally accommodating that small number of persons who are able to give fully informed and voluntary consent to have their lives terminated in circumstances where palliative care fails them has to be measured against the safeguards that can be imposed to ensure that others do not submit to euthanasia involuntarily.

The class of potentially vulnerable people are a large percentage of those suffering terminal illness who are too young, too old, too feeble, too much afflicted by inappropriate family pressures or not mentally competent to comprehend the variety of choices available to them. Most poignant of all is the plight of the terminally ill who could be assisted by a trained palliative care team but who, due to geography, finances, scarce facilities or even cultural barriers, such as those confronting Aboriginal communities, do not receive adequate palliative care.

Opinions differ as to whether the act imposes sufficient safeguards so that only those who expressly choose euthanasia will receive it. However, a fundamental premise of society that regulates our legal and social relationships is that we may not kill intentionally or even negligently without being visited with severe consequences and the disapproval of society. The House of Lords Select Committee on Medical Ethics observed that the effect of the prohibition of intentional killing `protects each one of us impartially embodying the belief that we are all equal'. According to this principle, each human life has value, no matter how bleak the prognosis, how reduced the quality of that life or how pathetic individual circumstances may be. Each life is entitled to the full protection of the law.

An individual may decide for himself or herself that life is not worth living. But once society concurs, moral responsibility shifts from the individual to the collective. The way is then open for erosion of the legal premise that accords every life equal value and to allow others to substitute their own judgment as to whose life is worth living anyway. This potentially exposes those who cannot make informed decisions about their own quality of life choices to decisions being made for them based on subjective judgments and tacit assumptions of others as to what sort of life is worth preserving. American, E Grant, in his article Mercy killing—how America's courts have set the stage contends:

Decision making by substitute judgment has become so ingrained in American health care law that if active euthanasia is declared to be a right for competent individuals, it will probably be extended by this principle to the incompetent as well.

A revealing footnote I have found in one of the judgments involving doctor assisted suicide currently being appealed to the United States Supreme Court laid the groundwork for end of life decisions being made by others, thus:
A decision of a duly appointed surrogate decision maker is for all legal purposes the decision of the patient himself—

and should not be considered `involuntary'. The tendency to make substitute judgments has profound implications for people with disabilities, be they newborn or suffering progressive disabling disease, be they mentally incompetent or even in a coma. In a paper presented at the Rights Ethics and Justice for People with Disability Conference last year, lawyer Jennifer Fitzgerald observed:

It is through society's growing willingness to make quality of life judgments that the lives of people with disability become endangered. It is through this willingness that people with disability lose protections, basic protections to their lives which other members of society enjoy.

Whatever moral framework informs one's views about voluntary euthanasia, it would be patronising to say the least to impose those views on a fully informed, freely consenting, competent adult seeking assistance to die if, as a community, we could be confident about the effectiveness of legislative or other safeguards.

The Dutch experience of a permissive regime for active voluntary euthanasia and its relevance in the Australian context has been the subject of vigorous academic debate and widely divergent views. What the Dutch experience does demonstrate, however, is the impossibility of effectively and safely regulating euthanasia in practice.

The 1995 review Notification Procedures for Physician-assisted Death in the Netherlands shows that most acts of euthanasia requiring strict compliance with guidelines are not reported. Official studies suggest that only 18 per cent were reported in 1990 and 41 per cent in 1995. For reasons that are not clear, it appears that assisting physicians report many deaths that have been brought about as a result of medical intervention to end the patient's life as being due to natural causes.

Whatever the true position, it seems uncontestable that a not insignificant number of lives have been terminated in the Netherlands without an explicit request from the patient. Of those terminated on request, there is no way of knowing the quality of that consent when the guidelines are simply not adhered to. If the Netherlands experience is any guide, a law permitting what is said by recent research to be a widespread practice in Australia will do little to encourage a transparent, accountable and open process.

This prompts me to ask: how effective is a legal regime that seeks to impose objective criteria on medical judgments that are essen tially subjective, such as the doctor's intention in administering drugs to his or her patient? In that regard, there have been no criminal prosecutions of doctors in Australia in relation to administration of pain relieving drugs that have hastened death. Natasha Cica in her paper on active voluntary euthanasia notes that there has been no judicial clarification in the Australian context rendering doctors immune from liability for killing simply because the circumstances are characterised as ones where there was no intention to cause death.

The reality is that, in this area of intensely personal and private behaviour governed by the subjective state of mind of the relevant doctor, it would be extremely difficult for a prosecution to succeed. This may well be an area of the law which is unenforced and, for all practical purposes, unenforceable. It begs the question whether, in any Australian state or territory, there is any purpose to be served by a legislative regime providing for active voluntary euthanasia that is likely to be followed more in the breach than the observance and that may not have much bearing on what end of life decisions are actually made in practice.

I am not convinced that legislation for active voluntary euthanasia is workable and safe. Whilst the terminally ill must be able to avail themselves of the greatest possible latitude in palliative techniques, when balancing the potential risks to the vulnerable in society—the elderly, the frail, the incompetent and the disabled—against the interests of those terminally ill patients who are insufficiently assisted by palliative care and also capable of providing fully informed consent to termination of their life, the majority should prevail. In coming to this conclusion I have relied on assurances from palliative care specialists that physical pain, if not all degrees of existential distress, can be sufficiently palliated in virtually all cases.

As to the legal question, there cannot be much doubt that the Commonwealth parliament has power pursuant to section 122 of the constitution to enact the bill which will remove the power of the ACT, Norfolk Island and the Northern Territory to enact laws to permit voluntary or involuntary euthanasia and will override the act. A more difficult question is: when is it appropriate to do so?

I have difficulty with the notion that, despite the constitutional framework of the self‐governing territories, territorians should be subject to Commonwealth interference in an area where the states have power to enact comparable laws, and the Commonwealth's ability to override such laws would be, at the very least, restricted, if not invalid. It is foreseeable that, having outlawed voluntary euthanasia in the territories, if the bill is carried, one or more states will enact such a law that will be beyond the reach of the Commonwealth in any event.

I also have reservations with the notion that, by virtue of my position as an individual in federal parliament, my conscience is somehow to be regarded as superior to, better informed than or one that in the circumstances ought override the consciences of other democratically elected representatives of a body politic.

Conscious though I am of objections of territorians, I believe that legislating for active voluntary euthanasia is an exceptional measure, that it has the potential to affect people outside the jurisdiction of the territories and that where the Commonwealth has power it should govern in the interests of and to protect the lives of all Australians. I am satisfied in these circumstances the Commonwealth can and should intervene as an exercise of good public policy.

I have also taken into account claims that Commonwealth intervention will lead to legal uncertainty. I do not think that by overriding the act the legal position affecting conventional medical end of life decisions will be any less certain. For reasons I have mentioned, it is unlikely that such decisions will be affected in practice. Whilst it is clearly arguable that the expression `intentional killing', which the act prohibits and does not define, can be construed broadly, probabilities favour the view that the expression `intentional killing' has a well defined and narrow meaning as enunciated in case law and will not interfere in conventional medical end of life decisions and would not lead to uncertainty.

BREAK.PARA: The most enduring legacy arising from this debate ought to be an understanding of the critical importance of good palliative care and a commitment to improving its availability to dying patients. If the bill is carried there will be nothing less than a moral imperative to improve the range of palliative facilities throughout Australia.

Compassion means not only controlling pain but assisting patients holistically to maintain dignity, self-determination and courage. It means finding better ways to help patients whose suffering, characteristically, has not been amenable to palliation, such as those progressively disabled by motor neurone disease. It means funding palliative care where it is needed—in homes, hospices and hospitals. In short, it means a lot of taxpayers' money, especially as the population ages. The dictates of conscience demand nothing less. For these reasons, and, I must admit, not without a great deal of reflection, I support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I value the opportunity to take part in a debate of such great importance, but I will not keep the Senate long. I wish only to make as clear as I can why I will vote as I intend. As many senators would know, in 1993 I was diagnosed with cancer for the first time. Associated treatment included radiation which was excruciatingly painful. Yet over several days I could get no relief from pain from a much vaunted pain control clinic. I mention this because the fear of pain is a major element in the move for voluntary euthanasia. We are told that better palliative care is the answer, and I am sure it is vitally important. I am all for better palliative care, but I do not accept that medical science has all the answers in pain control and I believe it is arrogant in the extreme for some doctors to make that claim.

SPEECH.PARA: Questions of pain and pain control are not the only ones which exercise my mind, and yet they tend to dominate the debate. Someone I love very much will very likely die from choking to death. That thought is with me always. It cannot help but influence my views. I know that if my family were to find an understanding doctor, we might be able to ensure that an overdose of a drug administered by a doctor for `pain relief' would give final release from a hideous and ghastly death. But I find that process quite dishonest and unacceptable.

Why do some in our society accept that a doctor and/or the family has the right to decide the occasion of death by the use of a lethal level of pain‐killer and yet the law decrees that there is no such right of decision for the dying themselves? By its legislation, the Northern Territory has ensured that right for the dying rather than for their doctor or their family and, hence, has stripped away some of the hypocrisy which is implicit in the present situation. Society conveniently closes its eyes to what I would describe as the involuntary euthanasia which exists at present for those who are no longer able to make that decision. I find it amazing that many in the medical profession are unwilling to assist a dying patient who chooses to die with dignity, yet are willing to produce a similar result based only on their own judgment and the urging of the family. The territory legislation enables people to die with dignity, if that is their choice. It does not compel them to do so. It was enacted by the Northern Territory in a legitimate exercise of its legislative power. I recognise that the Commonwealth has the power to overturn the territory legislation, but it is not required to do so.

I have lived a long and an active life. I have twice gone under anaesthesia for serious surgery. Inevitably, each occasion was a matter of deep soul‐searching and caused me to focus more than ever before on my own mortality. My continuing good health is a matter of great joy to me and to my family. I thank God for it and I hope it may long continue. But, if a day comes when I am facing a long and painful death and am still of the view that I hold today, I wish to have the right to knowingly choose the time of my death and the circumstances in which I die. Even more so, I passionately want to have that right for those I love. The Northern Territory has lawfully given that right to Australians and it has been hedged about with proper safeguards. I only wish that right was more readily available to those of us who live in the rest of Australia.

At the end of the day, we are each guided by our own personal beliefs and values. Last night in the debate, the question was raised as to who—outside this chamber in wider Australia—is in favour of legalising euthanasia, because we have all received correspondence, particularly those of us who are against legalising euthanasia. In answer to that question, I would say that the people who make up the numbers of the surveys we read about in the newspapers are those who have had first‐hand experience of the agonising or desperately undignified death of somebody near and dear to them and those many older Australians who have already received a diagnosis of a terminal illness and know that in time they themselves will be facing a very difficult death. They tend not to be members of organisations and, thus, their views are not so easily heard, particularly by members of parliament and in letters received, et cetera.

I accept that many people hold views opposed to my own. I respect their views. I ask only that they respect my conscientiously held beliefs. My beliefs have been arrived at over time and through my experience of life as I have found it. They are heightened by the needs of those I dearly love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric
SPEECH.PARA: The prohibition of intentional killing is the cornerstone of law and of social relationships. This prohibition protects each one of us impartially, embodying the belief that all are equal.

So said the House of Lords Select Committee on Medical Ethics. I respectfully concur. If we reject the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996, we will, as a Senate, be signalling to all the world that we wish to diminish that fundamental and impartial protection. My standpoint is unambiguously opposed to euthanasia. On a previous occasion—on 21 June 1995—I set out in this place the reasons why I oppose euthanasia. More recently—on 6 November 1996—I outlined to the Senate why states rights do not equate with territory rights.

It is somewhat unfortunate that I need to repeat some of those comments, given some of the contributions in this debate. The simple fact is that the federal parliament was clothed with a power to legislate in respect of the territories. That power was suggested by the founding fathers and then given to us by the people of Australia voting in a referendum. They gave us no such power in relation to the states. Given that the people of Australia have not given us such a power in relation to the states, it is appropriate that we consider the differentiation between a state and a territory. Section 122 of the constitution makes that point very clear.

For those who talk about self-government of the territories, let me simply remind this chamber that the self-government so-called is severely restricted. The Northern Territory is not allowed to legislate in respect of industrial relations, in respect of uranium mining and in respect of land rights. Every single act of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly and indeed every regulation could be overturned by the executive pen of His Excellency in council. So it is very much a limited form of self-government.

While some may regret that one law applies in relation to the territories and another in relation to the states, the fact is that the people of Australia did not clothe the Australian parliament with such a power. That is why the proposal being mooted by Senator Bob Collins is not a fair dinkum proposal. I think everybody knows that the federal parliament does not have the power to make a euthanasia law in respect of all of Australia. But, if we have the power in respect of the territories, I think we have an obligation to consider the use of it in exceptional circumstances. Clearly, it is difficult to imagine anything more exceptional than euthanasia.

Let me say that I have found the contribution of senators promoting the concept of territory rights somewhat heart‐warming, and I say `somewhat' with a smile on my face. I wonder where you all were when the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill was being debated—when Tasmania's democratically enacted laws were clearly upheld by the people of Tasmania, and opinion poll after opinion poll was telling us that the people of Tasmania wanted their democratic rights protected? Where were they?

TALK.START.PARA: —I was there with you.

—I know Senator Boswell was. Senator Harradine, I and a few others—we took to the ramparts on that issue. It is somewhat disingenuous for those people and honourable senators who had no regard for state rights to somehow beat their breasts about territory rights as though that is something that is of some concern to them.

BREAK.PARA: I found it very interesting that Senator Brown in his contributions especially last night talked about the importance of territory rights and the democratically elected parliament. Who was the person who could not win the debate over the Franklin dam in his own home state of Tasmania? It was none other than Senator Brown. What did he do? He tiptoed off to Canberra to get the Commonwealth government to override the Tasmanian legislature. I think the comments made by the honourable senator last night just do not ring true, unless the seed of state rights and territory rights was always there somewhere in the embodiment of Senator Brown but only germinated of late. If that is the situation that has arisen, I welcome that change of heart and I look forward to its ongoing growth.

Some people have suggested that the Euthanasia Laws Bill will create a degree of uncertainty. Until judicially interpreted, the meaning of every piece of legislation has a degree of uncertainty. Even our constitution, which has been in existence for 96 years, is still the topic of argument in the High Court virtually every day of the week to determine what it actually means.

Similar criticisms can be levelled at the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995. Some would argue that under that Northern Territory legislation people diagnosed with diabetes, although they have the possibility of a 30-year life span or more, have an incurable disease and if those people do not want to avail themselves of the medication available because they find it unacceptable they would then be classified as being able to access that legislation. That argument was very validly put to us during the Senate hearings on this bill. So there is the uncertainty about the Northern Territory legislation as well.

The only real and substantive argument in relation to uncertainty in the Andrews bill is in the term `intentional killing'. There are basically two approaches—the narrow approach and the broader approach. Whilst some witnesses argued for the possibility of a broad interpretation during the committee hearings, not a single witness put to us that that interpretation should be adopted. Indeed, the explanatory memorandum to this bill and the contributions to this second reading debate will ensure that the narrow reading of the term `intentional killing' will be adopted.

There will always be uncertainty. And if there is not—with respect to my profession—then lawyers will create it. So our collective minds should not be exercised overly about the possibility of uncertainty, but the degree of uncertainty. The evidence of Mr Dabb, who is First Assistant Secretary in the Criminal Law Division of the Attorney‐General's Department, is very instructive in this regard. He said to the committee:

The bill has to me all the signs of being drafted with a high degree of professional competence and I would assume that expert legal advice has gone into the drafting of this bill. It seems to strike the right balance between simplicity and not becoming over complicated in trying to deal with every situation.

A more concerning argument exposing uncertainty is how one would codify the circumstances in which a life can be extinguished through euthanasia. Where a human life is at stake the possibility of uncertainty or possibility for mistakes ought be eradicated. Hence our rejection of the death penalty. Exactly the same principles apply in respect of euthanasia. As a lawyer, I have no doubt that misinformation is fed to courts despite all the checks and balances of our judicial system. Mistakes are made and if we had the death penalty, innocent people would meet their death.

Similarly with the euthanasia laws: when you have state sanctioned killing, what can arise? As Senator Herron pointed out very well last night, you can have misdiagnosis and people honestly believe they have a terminal illness, they are put into the terminal care ward, given 14 days to live and they, in fact, survive and live for another 19 years. People, being scared of the future they might face, will access that on the basis of a wrong diagnosis. A person with more than 20 years of life left in them may access this legislation on a mistaken belief.

Indeed, we know of situations in hospitals all around the world where somebody goes in for, let us say, an appendix operation and comes out with an accidentally amputated foot. The medical profession makes mistakes. Are we ever going to countenance the possibility that there is going to be a medical mistake with euthanasia? I could not live with that on my conscience as I could not live with it in the event of the death penalty being misapplied.

Let me just indicate to you that after the Port Arthur massacre, where I lost a friend, I was very tempted to consider whether the death penalty should not be reintroduced. But I had to tear myself away from that personal experience, that personal emotion. It is very difficult to do that but you have to move yourself away and look at the principled position and say, `Is it an appropriate law just for this circumstance or for all circumstances?' That is what needs to exercise our minds.

One issue that concerns me is the impact on the Aboriginal community of this country. It has been, I think, neglected in all those speeches in favour of the Northern Territory legislation. Today, I think, most honourable senators would have received a letter from the Northern Land Council pleading with us to support the Andrews bill because of their concern:
It is already having a major effect on public health by increasing their—
the Aboriginal community's—
fear of accessing the health system.

When you have somebody like Chips Mackinolty coming before you, you cannot help but be persuaded. It was simply overwhelming, a man who personally believes in euthanasia, who absolutely believes in it, a man who was appointed by the pro‐euthanasia Northern Territory government to conduct the education campaign among the Aboriginal community. He has 16 years of experience with the Northern Territory Land Council and other Aboriginal communities and was clearly a good choice. He believed in euthanasia, he had a good working knowledge of the Aboriginal community and he had good relationships with them.

After having conducted his education campaign he came to us as a committee and said, `Get rid of the legislation, override the Northern Territory because this is having a significant impact on the health of the Aboriginal community.' We heard some quite inappropriate—I will use temperate language—suggestions in the Northern Territory of churches being up to no good within Aboriginal communities. The evidence clearly was that even those Aboriginal communities that did not allow a single Christian into them were as vehemently opposed to euthanasia as those who had a Christian ethic.

If we are genuinely concerned about the health of the Aboriginal community in this country, especially in the Northern Territory, that alone would be sufficient reason for us to reject the Northern Territory legislation and support the Andrews bill. Indeed, we were told:
We had to tell people that at Tennant Creek hospital and at Alice Springs hospital nothing like this—
namely, euthanasia—
could ever happen, because we did not want people to decide that they were not safe at these hospitals. We had to tell them that it was only available at Darwin.

The Aboriginal communities were deliberately misled as to the extent of this legislation to try to make them come to the outlying medical centres. But take the tip, as soon as euthanasia is committed at one of these outlying places, at Tennant Creek, Alice Springs or wherever, the Aboriginal community will say, `You lied to us; you misled us; we have no faith whatsoever in your Western medicine.' We all know, do we not, that the Aboriginal community in this country need as much support with their health as they can possibly get. To have some piece of legislation such as this that can really turn the Aboriginal community away from accessing those health facilities is a matter of great concern and something which ought be exercising our minds very heavily.

Time is slipping by. Let me quickly comment about the assertion that this is about the right to choice. There is no right of unfettered choice in this regard. Suicide is not a crime and we as a community spend millions of dollars trying to convince people not to commit suicide. We try to help them. The Rights of the Terminally Ill Act in the Northern Territory does not so much change the law for the patient as it changes the law for the doctor, the third party. The only thing that changes is that what currently is illegal for the doctor will become legal. That is nothing to do with personal choice; it has got everything to do with giving a licence to doctors to kill.

And the unfortunate thing is that when I ask people—witnesses—about this so‐called right to die, all of a sudden they say, `Oh no, no, you have to put restrictions on it.' According to who? According to their values. But, supposedly, Christians and others in this debate are not allowed to put their values into the debate; they are not allowed to put them into the melting pot, but these people somehow are.

There is no absolute right to die, according to these people. They say it has to be according to some sort of safeguard. What is the safeguard? That there is a third party involved. Do you know what that means? A third party has to make the decision and, along with the patient who has come to the conclusion that their life is no longer worth living, come to that conclusion as well and say, `I agree, your life is not worth living and that is why I am willing to inject you with a poisonous substance to kill you.' The concept that any human being can say of another, no matter what their circumstances, `Your life is not worth living' is something that goes against every strand of my being. It is something that I really, unfortunately, cannot relate to.

When you have the potential for guilt feelings for those that linger on—and Senator Harradine mentioned Sir Mark Oliphant's quite astounding, horrible and inhumane commentary—and when you have people such as the former Governor‐General Bill Hayden saying, `There is a point when the succeeding generations deserve to be disencumbered', to coin a clumsy word, `of some unproductive burdens', that is economic rationalism gone mad, is it not? Are we, as a Senate, going to say, `Yes, the views of Bill Hayden, Sir Mark Oliphant and whoever else are worthy of consideration?' They are abhorrent. They are abhorrent, because no matter what your circumstance, your life is precious and your life is worthwhile.

The concept of dying with dignity is something that I find very concerning in the context of this debate. To refer to various physical circumstances as being somehow involved with dignity is of real concern to me, because there is a disturbing equation between having dignity and being without disability. The term has been used as though there is a loss of dignity if someone who has previously been without disability takes on a disability in the course of a terminal illness.

We have had a lot of anecdotal evidence before us, but can I just finish on this note: no question as serious as euthanasia should be settled on individual cases; a general principle must be found which transcends particular cases. As with capital punishment, one principle which could be universally applied is that human life should be valued to the extent that puts it beyond the state. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eggleston, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —Many arguments have been submitted in the debate over the legalisation of voluntary euthanasia by the Northern Territory. This issue is one which has led to much consideration by members of this parliament and it is an issue that has led me to reflect on my clinical experience as a medical practitioner to assist me in reaching my conclusions about this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that the basic presumption underlying the Northern Territory euthanasia law is that the care of the terminally ill in this country is not adequate. Based on my own experience of some 27 years as a practising medical clinician, I have to say that I disagree with the presumption that the care of the terminally ill in Australia is deficient. I believe that, for the most part, the care provided for the terminally ill is satisfactory. It is my experience that the great majority of people with terminal illness have a peaceful death and just quietly slip away. However, I do recognise that there is a small percentage of so‐called hard deaths, said by those involved in palliative care to be about five per cent of all deaths.

Within recent years, I have experienced such a hard death from cancer in a member of my own family and I place that on record to make the point that I have personal experience of such sad events. Thus I am not just speaking from the detached view of a medical clinician or as a legislator concerned with matters of principle.

Other speakers tonight have referred to the fact that polls show strong support for the Northern Territory euthanasia law. I suspect that much of the public support for euthanasia arises from fear of what the process of dying may involve in terms of discomfort and pain. In today's culture we do not talk much about death and dying; it is one of the great taboos of our society. Unlike those who lived in past times, modern people are not familiar with dying and death and so fear what death my involve and seek a mechanism whereby they may intervene and avert what they believe will be unpleasant events. However, I repeat that, in my experience, most people die peacefully and the techniques of palliative and terminal care ensure that there is little suffering.

With respect to the argument that doctors do sometimes unnecessarily pursue futile treatments, I must point out that it seems to be often overlooked that patients do have a common law right to decline medical treatment. Terminally ill patients, or patients who have incurable diseases, are able, through the common law and through state and territory legislation, to request the withholding of medical treatment. The South Australian law entitled the Natural Death Act, or the Victorian legislation entitled the Refusal of Medical Treatment Act, are examples of laws giving the patient or patients the right to refuse medical treatment. These acts allow a patient to refuse futile treatment even if this treatment would prolong their lives.

BREAK.PARA: Another important argument used by those who support the Northern Territory legislation is that the medical profession needs to be subject to regulation in the care of the terminally ill, both to protect society and to give doctors immunity from prosecution. Senator Brown used this argument tonight.

Ensuring that the process of dying for the terminally ill is not uncomfortable is the objective of palliative and terminal care. To that end, in my experience, doctors and nurses involved in the care of the terminally ill provide counselling, sedation and analgesia or pain relief. At times, part of the overall management of such patients involves shortening the period of dying, if I might put it that way. In my experience, this is achieved by passive means such as not aggressively treating a chest infection in a patient with lung cancer, so that the patient dies peacefully from pneumonia rather than from the sometimes hideous effects of the secondary deposits of cancer.

It is also true that the medications used for sedation and pain relief may bring death sooner, but surely this is part of the accepted role of the physician in our culture and has long been accepted in the annals of case law as such. The legal situation is that, provided the actions of a doctor are basically concerned with treating the medical condition of the patient, there is no need for extra legal protection of doctors.

As for the general issue of the need for society to regulate terminal care, I have to say that in our culture death is usually a private family matter and that neither the terminally ill person nor their family wants to have every step of the treatment program scrutinised by a committee. I think such regulation would be cumbersome, undesirable and unnecessary. My view is that physicians do what they do for the dying in good faith and on the basis of the ethical traditions of their profession. It seems to me that the interests of society are well served by leaving things the way they are and that there is no case for meddlesome regulations of the kind that others seem to feel are appropriate.

My chief concern about this law, however, is that it sets a precedent for state authorised killing of people. I have devoted a great deal of thought to the question of whether it is possible to establish permanent legal limitations to such state authorised killing. After much discussion with many people, including some eminent lawyers, I have come to the conclusion that it is not possible to establish such limits. It is because of the inability of the law to provide such limitations that I support the Andrews bill. It is my view that the sanctity of human life is one of the core values of our culture, and it profoundly concerns me that the chief effect of the Northern Territory legislation, undoubtedly, will in practice be to undermine that key principle.

While the Northern Territory legislation is limited to voluntary requests for assisted suicide by terminally ill patients, I am deeply concerned about the possible extension of the concept of state authorised killing to other categories of people such as the aged, the disabled, unwell babies and people with chronic illness of various kinds. That these concerns are not just hypothetical considerations is shown by the fact that the author of the Northern Territory legislation, Marshall Perron, is now on the public record as saying that he believes that in due course the legislation should be extended to quadriplegics and people with diseases such as multiple sclerosis.

In the Senate inquiry, Professor Helga Kuhse of the Monash Medical Ethics Centre, when asked about extending the categories of people defined in the Northern Territory legislation, said that she thought in 20 years or so, when there had been time for cultural acceptance of euthanasia, the categories of persons who are eligible for euthanasia could be extended beyond the terminally ill, as is provided for in the current Northern Territory legislation. It is my view that it is not too much to say that the authors of the Northern Territory legislation—and I include Professor Kuhse and the Monash Medical Ethics Centre among the spiritual authors of this legislation—see the present legislation as just the first step and have clear intentions of extending state authorised killing to other categories of people.

Professor Kuhse has long been an advocate of euthanasia, and it is important for senators to know that she does not regard respect for the sanctity of human life as a fundamental tenet of a civilised society. I quote from her writing in 1985:
. . . the doctrine of the sanctity of human life as understood in the Western tradition since Christianity prevailed is not in any sense a fundamental tenet of a civilised society.
One would have to describe this as an interesting point of view and at variance with accepted concepts of civilised society.

In considering my position on this matter, I have been very mindful that both the UK and Canada have rejected the idea of introducing legislation for voluntary euthanasia. The parliaments of both the United Kingdom and Canada came to the conclusion that it was not possible to limit the extent of state authorised killing once the basic principle had been established and the precedent set. The December 1993 report of the House of Lords Select Committee on Medical Ethics stated:

. . . we do not think it is possible to secure limits on voluntary euthanasia. It would be impossible to frame safeguards against non-voluntary euthanasia if voluntary euthanasia were to be legalised. It would be next to impossible to ensure that all acts of euthanasia were truly voluntary, and that any liberalisation of the law was not abused.
The 1994 report stated:

There is insufficient reason to weaken society's prohibition of intentional killing which is the cornerstone of the law and social relationships—it protects each one of us impartially, embodying the belief that we are all equal.

The evidence from other countries of legislating for euthanasia suggest that there are inadequate safeguards for removing potential sources of abuse. The slippery slope argument suggests that once euthanasia is permitted on a small scale, it will become more acceptable, hence the categories of those permitted to use euthanasia will widen. A witness from the House of Lords inquiry suggested that once active termination of life is a matter of choice for the competent people in society, the grounds for excluding non‐competent people from such treatment becomes harder to defend.

The law is not very adept at categorising people. It is equally not competent in providing checks on such categorisation. How can anyone be 100 per cent certain that such safeguards had been adhered to? If a person has died from a lethal injection and suspicions arise as to whether this person fitted the category deemed legal for euthanasia to be carried out and consented to, how could such a situation be rectified after the act had been done? After all, the patient would be dead and unable to answer any questions on the matter.

One must consider the experience in Holland, the only country in contemporary times where euthanasia has been condoned. According to Dr Williamsen, speaking in a recent debate on ABC's Late Night Live program, there are now at least three incidents of involuntary euthanasia in Holland every day, that is, euthanasia without consent. In the program, Dr Williamsen, who is a Dutch doctor and a researcher in this field, said that he did not regard three acts of involuntary euthanasia a day as many. When you think about it, it is just about 1,000 or so people a year being put to death by lethal injection without consent—that is my interpretation, of course, not Dr Williamsen's. I find the admission about what is happening in Holland very disturbing, to say the least.

What might be the situation 30 years or so from now in Australia if the Northern Territory legislation is allowed to stand? In evidence before the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee, Professor Helga Khuse stated that she envisages that by that time the laws authorising euthanasia could be extended to sick babies. What about the disabled? In the same Late Night Live debate that I referred to earlier, a paraplegic Canadian woman spoke of how vulnerable and defenceless the disabled would become if euthanasia were accepted by society.

I would like to say a little more about the possible impact of legalised euthanasia on the disabled. At the end of last year, a Canadian academic, Dr Gregor Wolbring, visited Canberra. He is a well‐respected academic mathematician and was also a thalidomide baby. He has no legs and only poorly formed hands, so he has to get around in an electric chair. He made the point that in modern society he would never have been born because his mother would have been pressured to terminate her pregnancy, and, if the Northern Territory legislation had been in force for some time and the killing of unwell babies had become culturally acceptable, he would have been given a lethal injection.

People who are born with disabilities usually do not see life in negative terms but as a challenge to overcome their disabilities and to do the things they want to do. The world is better off giving disabled people the opportunity to enjoy their lives rather than introducing the possibility that disabled people in general will simply be killed as a matter of routine because it is assumed that their lives are of no value, as the Canadian woman on Late Night Live feared.

What about the elderly in nursing homes and those with chronic psychiatric and other illnesses who need a lot of nursing care? One can imagine that in an era of cultural acceptance of euthanasia, those who administer health budgets will find the option of the $30 lethal injection more attractive than the $20,000 or $30,000 annual recurring cost of institutional care for such people.

In summing up, I support the Andrews bill chiefly because I believe that, were the Northern Territory legislation allowed to stand, it would lead to an undesirable change in the fundamental tenet of our society of respect for the sanctity of human life and that this in turn could lead to the kind of undesirable outcomes I have referred to in this speech. I urge my fellow senators to think beyond the immediacy of the sad stories of the small percentage of so-called hard deaths and give consideration to the broader long-term implications for our society that would follow if the Northern Territory legislation were to stand. I urge my colleagues to support the Andrews bill and strike down this pernicious Northern Territory legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibbs, Sen Brenda

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in opposition to the private member's bill on euthanasia currently before the Senate. This bill is about rights—the rights of the territories to pass and enact legislation and the rights of terminally ill people who, in full possession of their senses, choose to end their lives with the dignity they deserve. It is also very much about choice—the choice made by people who are suffering prolonged pain, in full knowledge of the agony they will endure until their death, of accepting or rejecting voluntary euthanasia.

SPEECH.PARA: Many of the proponents of the Andrews bill talk about palliative care. It is made out to be the ultimate answer to anyone suffering from a terminal illness. This is not always the case. From my readings, I have found that terminally ill patients rarely request euthanasia. Palliative care has made many advances and can control the pain and other distressing symptoms of many such patients. However, there are still many conditions and illnesses for which pain and extreme suffering are either difficult or impossible to eliminate.

The suffering of the terminally ill is not always in the form of physical pain. It can also mean the impairment of all mental and physical bodily functions, paralysis, uncontrollable breathlessness, inability to swallow, continual choking and complete and utter dependence on others. Suffering from a variety of these symptoms and the knowledge that you have a limited time in which to live can be unbearable. Palliative care, no matter how progressive, cannot alleviate this type of suffering. It also needs to be remembered that the government, in the last budget, cut palliative care funding by 10 per cent.

It is an absolutely ridiculous situation where a doctor can legally give a patient pain‐killing drugs, even where the administering of the drugs is known to speed up the death of the patient, yet to administer treatment at the patient's request, with the direct intention of terminating the patient's life, is considered to be murder. There is no law against a person committing suicide. Yet the terminally ill, under this legislation, will not have any control over their lives.

I recently spoke to a registered nurse from my home state of Queensland. She recounted details of terminally ill patients with intractable vomiting. These patients can go on with constant vomiting for months. At the same time, they are barely able to eat, speak or breathe. They are so weak that they cannot even clean their own faces. No‐one on either side of this debate would want to see anyone endure that sort of suffering. One can only imagine the stress and heartache of families watching their loved one go through this agony.

Until now I have not spoken of the removal of the territory's power to make laws, and let's not pretend that this is limited to euthanasia. The passage of this bill will set a precedent that will effectively veto any real power which the territories have. It will leave the way open for a federal government to overturn any territories' legislation. While some have suggested that this will politically make territorians second‐class citizens, I would further suggest that we may as well begin dismantling the territories' governments, if this bill is passed, because they will effectively have no control over their own destiny. Today it might be the euthanasia laws that we are considering overturning, but tomorrow and in the future it could be laws on homosexuality, cannabis and abortion—the list goes on.

If we take some sort of high moral ground on this issue, it will not be long before we start looking at a whole range of other so‐called `important' or `crucial' issues. What self‐respecting aspiring politician would want to run for office for a position within a government where they cannot implement any policies that would go against the wishes of a federal parliament or a government of the day? We may as well appoint an administrative team to run the Northern Territory as well as the Australian Capital Territory. At least public servants would not try to implement too many of their own ideas.

I started my speech by stating that this debate was all about rights. Choosing to end your life with dignity is a basic human right. When a person is diagnosed as terminally ill, it is the most important time for them to have access to that basic human right and to have a choice of dying with dignity.

How do we know that death is not a beautiful thing? If life on this earth is so unbearable, death is sublime. I have always believed in God or a superior being and I believe that we all have a certain time in this life and then our spirit goes home.
