This, of course, is tragic for those who are left behind, but our life is complete.

With respect to the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act, some would say that legislation is conservative. In fact, there is more scope for assisting a person to die under common law than there is under the Northern Territory legislation. Choosing to die within the confines of the legislation and all its safeguards would not impinge on the rights or choices of others. Quite the opposite, it creates an audit trail with procedures and safeguards so that a doctor cannot make any decisions in isolation and is not open to accusations of abuse. In contrast, the common law provides a much easier defence for doctors and is more easily abused.

Therefore, legislation enacted by the Northern Territory will make it more difficult for euthanasia to be carried out, rather than easier, which prompts the question: why are so many against the legislation? The Northern Territory legislation is a desirable alternative to the present system where doctors often make life and death choices for terminally ill patients, without proper safeguards because of concern about the legal consequences if they openly canvass such options. The Northern Territory legislation curtails some of the things that doctors practice now, and, I might add, often without discussing it with the patient.

At present, the laws in the other states and territories are regularly ignored by both medical professionals and the authorities. Ostensibly, the laws are there to stop active voluntary euthanasia completely. The reality, however, is that doctors often do help terminally ill patients to die through the administration of drugs. Doctors who do so at the request of patients are not prosecuted even though they are helping someone to die. Some 2,300 deaths each year are the result of such voluntary euthanasia. There are also some 4,400 deaths per year caused by doctors who administer drugs with the express intention of ending a patient's life without any such request by the patient. These doctors are playing God and have completely taken away the most basic right of a patient.

BREAK.PARA: The medical fraternity cannot bury their heads in the sand. Doctors do assist in voluntary and active involuntary euthanasia. However, there are no formal safeguards for the doctors or for the patients.

The Northern Territory legislation will protect doctors and the actions they might decide to take. It very cautiously gives terminally ill patients under certain defined circumstances the right to end their lives with the concurrence of three doctors. This is surely not opening the door to various forms of legalised killing that some are suggesting. It is regulating what is already happening and giving patients the rights they deserve. It is protecting patients and doctors.

It is bringing into the open what has been secretive and hidden for too long. It is bringing secretive practices under scrutiny and putting in place safeguards for the doctor and the patient. It brings the rights of the patient back to the patient and stops doctors from playing God. Ironically, it is the Andrews bill that is obscure and unclear. It has been badly drafted and does not define terms such as euthanasia, intentional killing, mercy killing or the assisting of any person to terminate his or her life. There was evidence to the Senate committee that there would be serious unintended consequences of this bill. I conclude by saying that I totally oppose this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Euthanasia Laws Bill is perhaps one of the most important pieces of legislation that the Senate has considered since Federation in 1901. The significance of this bill is reflected by the fact that every senator is able to exercise his or her vote in accordance with their respective consciences. In our political system this is indeed a rare occurrence.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill deals with the question of euthanasia and, as such, it sets out to override the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995 which came into force on 1 July 1996. Since that date a number of people have terminated their lives in accordance with the legislation. The bill, which has become known as the Andrews bill, also precludes the governments of the Australian Capital Territory and Norfolk Island from enacting similar legislation.

I support the Andrews bill for reasons which I shall now outline. The bill was overwhelmingly supported by the House of Representatives. On 7 November last year it was referred to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, which, at that time, I had the privilege to chair. The committee received 12,577 submissions, which is a record for any committee of the federal parliament. The committee conducted a number of hearings in both Darwin and Canberra and witnesses included representatives of territory governments, Aboriginal groups, lawyers, doctors, Christian churches and representatives from groups opposing and supporting voluntary euthanasia. The submissions were extensive with over 93 per cent opposing euthanasia.

Before I continue, let me pay tribute to the work of the committee secretariat, and in particular the secretary, Neil Bessell, who I note is in the chamber tonight. May I thank the secretary and his staff who worked untiringly on this report which I believe comprehensively covers the issues. I commend the report to the Senate and reject strongly any criticism in relation to the work of the committee. That criticism is totally unfounded.

The bill raises constitutional, legal, political and moral questions. At the outset, let me deal with them in order of complexity and importance. Firstly, I will deal with the constitutional aspects of this bill. Throughout this inquiry the question was raised as to whether the Commonwealth government had the power to pass this legislation. The territories, which are yet to become states, derive their power to legislate from the Commonwealth. Pursuant to section 122 of the constitution, the Commonwealth has the power to override territory legislation.

There was overwhelming evidence before the committee that section 122 provided the legislative authority for this bill and indeed this point was conceded by the Northern Territory. In the final analysis there can be no doubt that there is a constitutional basis for the legislation. Any objection to this bill in relation to comity between parliaments is one based more on convention and I will discuss this in the political context.

Before I do, however, I will turn to the legal effects of passing this bill. The issues can be conveniently covered by these questions: will the Andrews bill achieve what it sets out to do, what effect if any would the bill have on existing legislation in the Northern Territory, and will the bill have any unintended consequences? With respect to the first and second questions, the evidence before the committee clearly indicated that the Euthanasia Laws Bill if passed would outlaw voluntary euthanasia in the Northern Territory. The bill would therefore achieve its objective. In relation to the second question, it would not affect any other Northern Territory legislation.

From evidence presented to the committee, it appears that the bill therefore will not have any unintended consequences. In short, as stated by officers of the Commonwealth Attorney‐General's Department, the bill is well drafted and will work effectively. There is no unforeseen consequence as far as the Northern Territory legislation is concerned.

There was, however, some uncertainty expressed about the terminology used in the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995. To this extent, I would refer senators to the evidence adduced before the committee that supported the proposition that the Northern Territory legislation is in itself uncertain and capable of clarification only by judicial interpretation. On balance, I believe that the evidence was persuasive and highlighted potential flaws in the Northern Territory legislation. I am indebted to Senator Coonan for outlining in detail the problems with the terminology contained in that legislation.

Let me now turn to the political context of this matter. In this area of consideration, we have the question of territory rights, concerns expressed by Aboriginal communities and the question of palliative care. Australia is a federation made up of six states and a number of territories. The constitution clearly provides the Commonwealth with various heads of power in relation to legislation whilst leaving the remainder to the states. Quite clearly, the territories are subject to Commonwealth legislative power, although since 1978 the Northern Territory has had self‐determination. As such, there is a general rule of comity between parliaments and, in accordance with convention, parliaments do not normally override each other.

Although I am a proponent of what has been termed state rights or, more appropriately, state responsibilities, the question of state rights does not arise in this instance and it is generally accepted that, should a state pass a law similar to that of the Northern Territory, the Commonwealth government would not have the power to pass a bill overriding such state laws. The position in relation to the territories is, therefore, quite different. In this case, the Northern Territory legislation is unprecedented and the matter before us deals with life and death. In the circumstances, I believe that the Commonwealth is entitled to pass the Andrews bill.

There is also the issue of the Northern Territory's desire to become a state, and I might just touch on that. The evidence before the committee presented by the Northern Territory supported the proposition that, if passed, this bill would not impede the territory's quest to become a state. It is a quest to which I am sympathetic, I might add, and to the people of the Northern Territory I would say that the passing of this bill will not pose any obstruction to their quest to become a state. I think that is a very important point because there was some concern expressed about that and the evidence before the committee was overwhelming that that was not a problem.

Let me now touch on some concerns dealing with Aboriginal communities. One of the terms of reference of the Senate committee concerned the views of Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory. Senator Abetz mentioned the powerful evidence given by Chips Mackinolty in this regard. The committee heard convincing evidence that there was no place for euthanasia in Aboriginal culture. The committee heard evidence which indicated that, as a result of the Northern Territory legislation, Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory had lost confidence in their health system. That is, they were afraid of that system because they believed it was involved in the taking of lives. I believe that, in view of that, that is indeed a very serious matter for the Northern Territory government to consider and perhaps one which should have been considered more carefully at the passing of its legislation.

Let me now turn to the question of palliative care, which received much attention during the committee's inquiry. Palliative care can involve the administration of pain‐killers with the intention of relieving pain albeit that death may result. This situation must be clearly distinguished from euthanasia where the intention is to kill. The government recognises the importance of palliative care and this week, in an interview on the Sunday program, the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) recognised this point.

The Commonwealth provides palliative care funding to the states through two main sources: the palliative care program and Medicare agreements. Even though the Commonwealth made $55 million available to the states through the palliative care program between 1993 and 1997, some states did not take up their full funding allocation, hence the states underspent on the program by $8.5 million. As a result, a review of the palliative care program has been commissioned by the Commonwealth. The review is examining the effectiveness and appropriateness of the current services and it will advise on the future development and delivery of services.

In addition to the review, the Commonwealth has three national projects in train. These relate to palliative care data definitions, performance indicators and suitable standards for national accreditation of palliative care services. Of course, like any other health measure, palliative care must be looked at within the bounds of budgetary constraints. As stated earlier, this situation is unprecedented and political considerations need to be looked at in the context of the overarching moral concern.

One of the most important aspects of the committee's inquiry involved the question of the `slippery slope'. Dr John Keown, an international expert from Cambridge University, conducted extensive research into the law and practice of euthanasia in the Netherlands. From two studies conducted in 1991 and 1995 respectively, he concluded that voluntary euthanasia in the Netherlands had resulted in instances of non-voluntary euthanasia. The House of Lords Committee on Medical Ethics expressed findings consistent with Dr Keown after conducting its own inquiry into the situation in the Netherlands.

Senator Eggleston has just indicated eloquently how some regard the Northern Territory legislation as just a first step along the way, and that is one of the grave fears that I hold in relation to the Northern Territory's legislation. Voluntary euthanasia involves an individual terminating his or her life with the direct assistance of a third party. In accordance with the Northern Territory law, the state would sanction such a move. Albert Schweitzer once said that the mark of a civilised man was respect for life. The taking of life has always been looked upon by civilised society as a very serious thing indeed. Life is sacred and we must approach our daily lives on that basis. Of course, there are extreme circumstances where the taking of it is allowed such as in cases of self-defence.

During this inquiry people have argued that our lives are our own and that we should have the freedom to choose. It was John Donne, the poet, back in 1624 who stated that no man was an island. He went on to say:
. . . any man's death diminishes me, because I am involved in Mankind;
Indeed, Apostle Paul, in his letter to the Romans, stated:
None of us lives to himself, and none of us dies to himself.

All human beings have a vital concern in anyone ending their life. We should not have the ability, I believe, to treat our life as a commodity. We should not have the power to terminate our lives with the sanction of the state.

What sort of message would we be sending to the youth of this country who are experiencing one of the highest rates of youth suicide in the world? Our guiding principle in all matters should be for the preservation of life. The sanctity of life must not be diminished. The encyclical letter entitled The Gospel of Life is of assistance, and I quote:

When the prevailing tendency is to value life only to the extent that it brings pleasure and well‐being, suffering seems like an unbearable setback, something from which one must be freed at all costs. Death is considered "senseless" if it suddenly interrupts a life still open to a future of new and interesting experiences. But it becomes a "rightful" liberation once life is held to be no longer meaningful because it is filled with pain and inexorably doomed to even greater suffering.

Whilst I respect some of the arguments that are brought in opposition to my view and whilst I appreciate the suffering by people who have terminal illnesses, I cannot in all conscience oppose this bill. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later time.
Leave granted; debated adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Ellison) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to speak about concerns that I and many of my constituents have about the government's cuts to legal aid. Our legal system, like those in most democratic societies, does not automatically give its citizens justice; it gives people a chance at justice. And whether it is a reasonable chance or not depends on how easy it is to access the legal system and the support available to people to navigate and negotiate their way through that system.

SPEECH.PARA: While some of my Senate colleagues and colleagues in that other place have made mention of problems facing the community as a whole as a result of these cuts, I would prefer to highlight the problems caused for people who are perhaps going to suffer the most as a result of the draconian slashing of the legal aid budget by the Liberal government.

It is those in our community who are most at risk, who are not able to afford expensive lawyers, who are trying to escape domestic violence—and these are most often women—who will be the ones that suffer the greatest with the diminished access to legal aid. I know that many women's legal resources centres have written to senators and members highlighting the fact that over 30,000 women apply for domestic violence restraining orders in Australia each year and that about 60 per cent of these women have dependent children. Those figures perhaps highlight how terribly affected by these callous and short‐sighted budget cuts the women and children attempting to escape domestic violence are going to be.

The Chief Justice of the Family Court of Australia, Alastair Nicholson, has been quite scathing in his criticisms of the cuts to legal aid—and rightly so. More than half the people who come before the Family Court have legal aid assistance and, without a well resourced and effective legal aid system, equality before the law will become a principle of the past.

Legal aid provides an important safety net for many Australians who would not otherwise be able to get legal advice or representation. When you cut legal aid funding, you effectively cut access to justice and put at risk the rights of those in our community who already find the legal system difficult and out of reach.

Prior to the last election, the coalition promised to maintain funding to legal aid, to match and extend Labor's good record on access to justice measures and to redress imbalances which disadvantaged women in the legal system. Well, obviously that was not considered a core promise by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) or the Treasurer (Mr Costello) or the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams), because we now see them slashing funding to legal aid by over $120 million over the next three years. The members of the government should be in no doubt that such drastic cuts will hurt the people that should actually be protected by government.

However, it is not just women's legal centres that have contacted me raising concerns about the cuts to legal aid. The International Commission of Jurists, the National Association of Community Legal Centres, the Lawyers Reform Association, the New South Wales Council for Civil Liberties and many more organisations have written to me expressing their outrage at the governments cuts. They also highlight a very important point—that legal aid is part of the provision of social welfare, and access to justice is a right of all Australians and should continue to be, regardless of the costs.

It is perhaps an interesting point of comparison that the United Kingdom government presently spends $65 per capita on legal aid funding and Australia spends merely $13. The Attorney-General recently said on the ABC that legal aid should not be exempt from cuts in the budget process. Well, I say that there are some issues, like education, like health, like legal aid, that are so important and essential to all Australians that they should indeed be exempt from such cuts.

I do not believe the Australian community will be very understanding or forgiving of a government that disregards and in fact discards many Australians in their time of greatest need—nor do I think they should be forgiving of the government. A government that so vigorously implements short‐sighted policies under the guise of budgetary responsibility will run the serious risk of the community being very short‐sighted about the government's future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 11 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to recent Telstra advertising which indicate that analog mobile phones will remain the only receptors in some rural areas after the year 2000: is this the case; if so, why.
(2) Which rural or regional areas will remain unable to receive clear digital reception after the year 2000 (please list the locations).
(3) Is it planned that these areas will ever get digital reception; if so, when.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It may be the case in some rural areas that after the year 2000 analogue AMPS will be the only terrestrial technology which provides mobile telecommunications coverage.

To address the concerns of rural mobile phone users who currently receive an AMPS service, but who would not necessarily be within the radius of digital (GSM) coverage, the Government has obtained the in‐principle agreement of the carriers to retaining some AMPS spectrum in certain existing rural planned service areas. This spectrum will be retained until there is alternative technology for the delivery of mobile telephony with a reasonably equivalent quality of service and breadth of coverage available in that planned service area.

A review of rural planned service areas will be conducted in 1999 to determine those areas in which spectrum will need to be retained. It is expected that normal commercial development of new services and technologies will achieve the desired outcome of providing alternative services to existing AMPS mobile phone users by the end of 1999.

(2) At this stage it is not possible to identify the specific locations which will remain unable to receive digital coverage after the year 2000. The carriers are continually extending their GSM networks as well as enhancing their existing GSM coverage. Also, after 1 July 1997, there will be open competition in the telecommunications industry. This environment will provide greater incentives for companies to provide services using the most appropriate technology, which in turn can lead to a greater choice for consumers and greater coverage.

As noted in (1) above, a review of rural planned service areas will be conducted in 1999 to determine those areas which will not receive an alternative mobile service on the closure of the AMPS network. (As the review will only take account of those areas which currently receive an AMPS mobile service; it will not identify locations which are outside the coverage of both digital and analog services.)

(3) It is likely that some areas of Australia may never receive mobile coverage from digital or any other terrestrial technology, as approximately 90% population coverage accounts for only around 5% coverage of the land area of Australia. However, new satellite based systems using low earth orbiting (LEO) satellites are currently being developed. These will be provided on a global, rather than a national basis and are expected to be available from 1999 onwards. Current indications are that services provided using these systems will be considerably cheaper and will use much less cumbersome equipment than the present generation of satellite based mobile phone services. The services will operate with dual‐mode handsets, enabling the subscriber to switch to the cheaper terrestrial GSM service where available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 17 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of increasing levels of radiation in the populated areas of Australia in the radiofrequency and microwave communication bands covering the range 60 MHz—3 GHz, and recently acquired evidence for adverse effects of such radiation on health, is the Minister aware of the current level of exposure of the Australian population to radiation of this type.

(2) Is the Minister aware that detailed surveys of exposure of the United States of America population to this radiation have been carried out in 15 American cities and shows that only 0.5 per cent of the population were receiving exposure at levels greater than 1 W/cm2 at the time of the survey.
(3) Is there data showing the proportion of the population in Australian cities exposed to radiation beyond this level.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There have been no detailed surveys of the exposure of the Australian population to radiofrequency radiation in the range 60 MHz to 3 GHz. Some specific measurements have been made by the Australian Radiation Laboratory and the Communications Laboratory. Those sample measurements taken around cell‐phone base‐station transmitters show that signal levels in publicly accessible areas around the transmitter are typically less than 1 W/cm2.

(2) I have been advised that the survey referred to was published in 1980 and hence predates much of the change that has occurred in telecommunications. Its relevance to current circumstances is therefore doubtful.

(3) At present there is no data showing the proportion of the population in Australian cities exposed to levels greater than 1 W/cm2. However, the NHMRC could consider the value of proposals directed at measurement of RFR exposure of the Australian population within the context of the overall EME research program.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 17 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the current arrangements that are being, or have been, made by Telstra for the promised provision of 140 positions in Hobart and Burnie, Tasmania.

(2) Can an assurance be given to the people of Tasmania that all of the promised 140 positions will be filled by currently unemployed Tasmanians and that full and adequate training will be provided where necessary for the new employees.
(3) Can it be confirmed that the promised jobs are genuine new full‐time equivalent positions and that they are not jobs that are being transferred from elsewhere within Telstra.
(4) Can an assurance be given that none of the positions will come complete with an incumbent.

(5) (a) Is there an arrangement between the Minister and Senator Harradine which states that Telstra will accelerate the provision of Integrated Services Digital Network (ISDN) services to Tasmania to achieve 70 per cent customer penetration by June 1997, and 90 per cent penetration by December 1997; (b) what is the present penetration level; and (c) will the committed targets be reached by the promised dates.
(6) What financial allocation has been made to Telstra to create the 30 new jobs estimated by Telstra that are required to provided the promised ISDN services to Tasmania by the promised dates.
(7) What financial allocation has been made to the Telstra Tasmanian works programme to meet the promised ISDN services by the promised dates.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from Telstra, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Telstra advises that it is currently seeking new accommodation at both Hobart and Burnie that will accommodate the eventual growth of 70 staff at each centre over the period 1997/98 to 1999/2000.

(2) Telstra has indicated that it expects that Tasmanians will be included in the recruitment process, with the majority of the 140 positions expected to be filled by external recruitment. Telstra undertakes to provide full training to these new staff.

(3) Telstra advises that the additional positions are to cover growth for the new Telstra Call Connect product. New products are traditionally handled nationally from two or three sites. Telstra Call Connect will be similarly handled out of a number of selected sites, in this case, including Hobart.
(4) The positions are new and will not come with any incumbents.
(5) (a) The national programme of accelerated provision of ISDN services was announced by myself on 25 September 1996 and the details for Tasmania were confirmed in my statement of 5 December 1996.
(b) Telstra advises that at end of January 1997, ISDN will be available to exchanges serving 76% of Tasmanian customers.
(c) Telstra advises that the June 1997 target has already been exceeded and it is on schedule to provide ISDN to exchanges serving 90% of Tasmanian customers.
(6) & (7) Telstra advises that the necessary capital and resource allocations have been included in Telstra's Business Plan and works program to meet ISDN commitments to Tasmania.
